EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure strengthened over the area on May 28 and May 29 and resulted in widespread triple digit heat on the 29th as the main upper ridge axis moved over Central California. An upper trough pushed into Central California on the May 30 and May 31  displacing the high pressure area and bringing cooler temperatures along with windy conditions to the west side of the San Joaquin Valley on the 30th and over the Kern County Mountains and Deserts on the 31st. Several reporting stations on the west side of the San Joaquin Valley measured wind gusts exceeding 40 mph on the 30th and several stations in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts measured gusts exceeding 50 mph on the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jawbone Canyon RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 64 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure rebuilt over Central California during the morning of the 17th. With low clouds having dissipated the day before, dense fog reformed across portions of the San Joaquin Valley from Fresno southward during the evening hours on the 16th and continued through the morning of the 17th before lifting into a low cloud deck.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Fresno.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: President's Day weekend got off to a warm and dry start across the area, but the weekend ended on the chilly side as a strong cold front pushed across Central California on the evening of February 18. Gusty winds accompanied the front and continued behind the cold front overnight and well into the President's Day holiday before diminishing by afternoon. Several locations in the San Joaquin Valley measured wind gusts between 35 and 45 mph while several stations in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts reported wind gusts between 45 and 55 mph with a few low impact indicator locations reporting stronger gusts. In addition to the strong winds, light snow fell across portions of the Kern County Mountains in post frontal showers and several locations picked up between a dusting to an inch of snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bear Peak RAWS measured a peak wind gust of 81 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure brought a prolonged period of unseasonably warm temperatures to begin February as temperatures were 10 degrees or more above seasonal normals across much of the are for the first 10 days of the month. A low pressure system dropping into the Great Basin on the 10th brought a period of increased winds to the Kern County Mountains and Deserts during the late morning and early afternoon as strong mid level winds mixed down to the surface where there were numerous reports of gusts between 45 and 50 mph. Another trough pushed through the Great Basin on the evening of the 11th through the morning of the 12th which pushed a cold front through Central California and brought another period of increased winds to the area and there were several reports of wind gusts between 50 and 55 mp in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts. this system also brought some light precipitation to the area with amounts generally less than a tenth of an inch of liquid precipitation in post-frontal showers on the 12th. A weak tornado briefly touched down in rural farmland near Sanger during the late morning of the 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bear Peak RAWS on an exposed ridge top reported a peak wind gust of 62 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season Atmospheric River impacted the area in early April. A very moist airmass made landfall across the North Bay before moving southward across the rest of the Bay Area. The Oakland sounding measured record PWAT values of 1.69. The absence of large scale forcing prevent record breaking rainfall. Enough rain did fall, however, to cause minoir/nuisance flooding across much of the region. Numerous flood advisories were issued. Storm total rainfall amounts up to 7 were reported. The bulk of the impacts were felt on April 6,7.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roadway flooding reported at I-880 N and High Street off ramp.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: While fog was more localized on February 2, the large ridge centered off the California coast strengthened overnight resulting in dense fog becoming more prevalent during the morning of February 3 a low level inversion persisted over the San Joaquin Valley. The fog dissipated by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Hanford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The large upper ridge remained centered off the California coast through the morning of the 5th, and areas of dense fog formed toward daybreak across the western San Joaquin Valley. Many school districts either had delayed openings or delay or cancelled morning bus service, California Highway Patrol was pacing traffic on State Routes 198 and 41. The fog dissipated by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Atwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The large upper ridge remained centered off the California coast through the morning of the 5th, and areas of dense fog formed toward daybreak across the western San Joaquin Valley. The fog dissipated by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Hanford. California Highway Patrol was pacing traffic between Cairo Ave and Excelsior Ave. Several school districts opened late and delayed or cancelled bus service due to dense fog.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure over the northeast Pacific on the 17th moved southeast, reaching northern California on the 18th. This system brought high winds and snowfall to the Sierra Nevada and northeastern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station WMSRS, 9 miles northeast of Chalfant reported a wind gust of 125 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extended winter storm began in 02/28/18 and continued into March.  Several locations in Siskiyou county got heavy snow on the last night of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter in Tennant reported 12.0 inches of snow in 24 hours ending at 01/1730 PST. The timing of the snow was unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A short wave aloft brought a band of precipitation into a cold air mass that was already in place over northern California in the morning hours on this date.  This caused a brief but intense snow event over the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A CoCoRaHS observer 10 E Orleans reported 4.0 inches of snow ending at 0800 PST.  The snow began sometime after midnight.

CZ_NAME: EAST BAY HILLS AND THE DIABLO RANGE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak short wave trough brought scattered thunderstorms to the region towards the end of February. This system brought gusty winds and small hail to the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reported a tree had fallen on a vehicle. Wind speed unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A period of localized freezing rain occurred in northcentral Mendocino County on February 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two collisions occurred due to freezing rain on February 24th south of the Leggett area. The first collision occurred at 830 AM PST, and was located on US-101 north of mile post marker 101 MEN 83.35. One person sustained suspected minor injuries. The second collision, which occurred at 845 AM PST, was located on US-101 south of mile post marker 101 MEN 81.98, and there were no injuries sustained.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak short wave trough brought scattered thunderstorms to the region towards the end of February. This system brought gusty winds and small hail to the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mainly smaller than pea-sized hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several reports via social media of small hail around Millbrae/Burlingame. Hail size around or smaller than peas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure over the northeast Pacific on the 17th moved southeast, reaching northern California on the 18th. This system brought high winds and snowfall to the Sierra Nevada and northeastern California.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season Atmospheric River impacted the area in early April. A very moist airmass made landfall across the North Bay before moving southward across the rest of the Bay Area. The Oakland sounding measured record PWAT values of 1.69. The absence of large scale forcing prevent record breaking rainfall. Enough rain did fall, however, to cause minoir/nuisance flooding across much of the region. Numerous flood advisories were issued. Storm total rainfall amounts up to 7 were reported. The bulk of the impacts were felt on April 6,7.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: West Railroad Ave closed near Cypress Ave due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The large area of high pressure which prevailed over the area toward the end of January continued to hold it's grip on Central California as February began. Area of dense fog formed in the southwestern portion of the San Joaquin Valley on the morning of February 1 and patches of dense fog persisted until late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below 200 feet was reported in the Hanford area at 328 am PST and remained under a quarter mile through 930 am PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: While fog was more localized on February 2, the large ridge centered off the California coast strengthened overnight resulting in dense fog becoming more prevalent during the morning of February 3 a low level inversion persisted over the San Joaquin Valley. The fog dissipated by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Atwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level trough dug southward across the Pacific Northwest during February 18th and 19th. Numerous hail showers developed along the coast, and snowfall occurred across the interior mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public report of 4.0 inches of snow at an elevation of 1700 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level trough dug southward across the Pacific Northwest during February 18th and 19th. Numerous hail showers developed along the coast, and snowfall occurred across the interior mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter reported 8 inches of snow falling during the overnight period. Elevation was 2800 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level trough dug southward across the Pacific Northwest during February 18th and 19th. Numerous hail showers developed along the coast, and snowfall occurred across the interior mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter measured 8 inches of snow that occurred overnight, with snow drifts to 1 foot. Elevation of observation was 2800 feet. Location was 40.47N/-123.67W.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extended winter storm began in 02/28/18 and continued into March.  Several locations in Siskiyou county got heavy snow on the last night of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A CoCoRaHs observer 5.1 NW Mount Shasta City reported 14.0 inches of snow in 24 hours ending at 01/0800, but a good portion of it fell before midnight.  A spotter in Mount Shasta City reported 6.0 inches of snow ending at 01/0230 PST.  The Mount Shasta Ranger Station reported 13.0 inches of snow in 24 hours as of 01/0800 PST.  The cooperative observer in McCloud reported 12.0 inches of snow in 24 hours ending at 01/0900 PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain, falling across the Thomas Fire burn scar, resulted in significant mud and debris flows across sections of Ventura county. Highway 101, a main route from Ventura to Santa Barbara, was closed in several locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported a mud and debris flow across Highway 150, near Steckel Park. Heavy rain, exceeding USGS thresholds, generated the debris flow.

CZ_NAME: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS EXCLUDING THE SANTA MONICA RANGE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty northerly winds developed in the mountains of Ventura and Los Angeles counties. Wind gusts up to 60 MPH were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty northerly winds developed across the mountains of Los Angeles county. Some reports from local RAWS stations include: Chilao (gusting to 58 MPH) and Sandberg (gusting to 60 MPH).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season Atmospheric River impacted the area in early April. A very moist airmass made landfall across the North Bay before moving southward across the rest of the Bay Area. The Oakland sounding measured record PWAT values of 1.69. The absence of large scale forcing prevent record breaking rainfall. Enough rain did fall, however, to cause minoir/nuisance flooding across much of the region. Numerous flood advisories were issued. Storm total rainfall amounts up to 7 were reported. The bulk of the impacts were felt on April 6,7.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reporting mud/dirt/rocks covering northbound Highway 1 near Anderson Canyon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through the region bringing narrow bands of heavy rain (cold frontal rain bands) and gusty winds. No flooding was reported as a result of the heavy rain and no wind damage was reported. Convection behind the front produced isolated small hail in San Benito County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter reported hail at school peak gabilan range.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure brought a prolonged period of unseasonably warm temperatures to begin February as temperatures were 10 degrees or more above seasonal normals across much of the are for the first 10 days of the month. A low pressure system dropping into the Great Basin on the 10th brought a period of increased winds to the Kern County Mountains and Deserts during the late morning and early afternoon as strong mid level winds mixed down to the surface where there were numerous reports of gusts between 45 and 50 mph. Another trough pushed through the Great Basin on the evening of the 11th through the morning of the 12th which pushed a cold front through Central California and brought another period of increased winds to the area and there were several reports of wind gusts between 50 and 55 mp in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts. this system also brought some light precipitation to the area with amounts generally less than a tenth of an inch of liquid precipitation in post-frontal showers on the 12th. A weak tornado briefly touched down in rural farmland near Sanger during the late morning of the 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado briefly touched down in rural farmland between Riverbend Ave. and Goodfellow Ave. southeast of Sanger and was captured on video and relayed to the NWS by a media source.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level trough dug southward across the Pacific Northwest during February 18th and 19th. Numerous hail showers developed along the coast, and snowfall occurred across the interior mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail covered road led to a 19 vehicle accident at the intersection of Highway 101 and Highway 255. 16 injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain, falling over the Thomas Fire burn scar, resulted in significant mud and debris flows around the community of Montecito. Rain gauges in the area indicating rainfall rates exceeding the USGS thresholds for both 30 minute and 1 hour rainfall. The most significant mud and debris flow occurred along Bella Vista Drive, near Romero Canyon Road.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported significant mud and debris flows near the community of Montecito. Along Bella Vista Drive, near Romero Canyon Road, a 12-14 foot wide mud and debris flow was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain, falling across the Thomas Fire burn scar, resulted in significant mud and debris flows across sections of Ventura county. Highway 101, a main route from Ventura to Santa Barbara, was closed in several locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported a mud and debris flow across Highway 101, near Mussel Shoals. Heavy rain, exceeding USGS thresholds, generated the debris flow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty northerly winds developed in the mountains of Ventura and Los Angeles counties. Wind gusts up to 60 MPH were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty northerly winds developed across the mountains of Ventura county. The RAWS sensor at La Granada Mountain reported winds gusting to 60 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level trough dug southward across the Pacific Northwest during February 18th and 19th. Numerous hail showers developed along the coast, and snowfall occurred across the interior mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail/snow pellet covered road led to a 7 vehicle accident. Approximately a half inch of hail accumulated on the roadway. CHP reports that the multi-vehicle crash involved a motorcyclist who suffered minor injuries to her leg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably cold temperatures and frost caused potentially significant damage to the 2018 Central Valley almond crop harvest by happening during the sensitive blooming phase. Temperatures in many locations reached or fell below the critical bloom temperature of 27. Some in the agricultural community were projecting frost damage ...worst since perhaps the 1970s. (AgFax Tree Crops, Feb 26, 2018). ||Snow fell in the Sierra, with unusually cold temperatures allowing snow down into the Sierra foothills, to elevations as low as 1400 feet. This caused some travel slow downs and delays in areas that usually don't see accumulating snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Low elevation snow caused minor travel delays in the Motherlode. Weather spotters reported 1 of snow in Placerville, a trace at Shingle Springs(elevations 1400 feet), and a trace in Auburn (elevation 1500 feet).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably cold temperatures and frost caused potentially significant damage to the 2018 Central Valley almond crop harvest by happening during the sensitive blooming phase. Temperatures in many locations reached or fell below the critical bloom temperature of 27. Some in the agricultural community were projecting frost damage ...worst since perhaps the 1970s. (AgFax Tree Crops, Feb 26, 2018). ||Snow fell in the Sierra, with unusually cold temperatures allowing snow down into the Sierra foothills, to elevations as low as 1400 feet. This caused some travel slow downs and delays in areas that usually don't see accumulating snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow caused chain controls and travel delays in the Sierra, with road sensor data showing speeds briefly dropping to around 15 mph on I80 near pass level on the 19th and again on the 22nd. Caltrans reported 6 of snow at Soda Springs, 3 at Kingvale. Kirkwood Ski Resort reported 10 of new snow. Other reports include 6 at Bear Valley Ski Resort, 6 at Squaw-Alpine Ski Resort, 5 at Sugar Bowl Ski Resort, 4 at Tahoe Donner Ski Resort, and 2 at Dodge Ridge Ski Resort.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low elevation snow caused significant travel problems as well as school delays and closures in the foothills. Snow also resulted in chain controls and travel slowdowns in the mountains. The snow continued into early March, bringing additional impacts.||Thunderstorms with large amounts of small hail blanketed portions of the Sacramento, causing major travel problems. Funnel clouds were also reported in the Sacramento area, but no tornado touchdowns observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At least one funnel cloud was reported near Sacramento International Airport. No touchdown or damage was observed.

Hail fell 2 to 4 inches deep in portions of north Sacramento and Natomas. Snow plows were required to remove hail in some areas. |Some damage was done to awnings and parking lot covers. The California State Library roof suffered damage and leaked, with hundreds of rare books soaked with water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level storm system moved east across northwest California, resulting in high elevation snow, coastal hail, and a tornado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Ford F-150 with rear tire chains became stranded in deep snow drifts produced by heavy snow during the previous 24 hours. A family of 3 was subsequently rescued by helicopter at an elevation of 4007 feet. Snow was not falling at the time of rescue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: South winds supported upslope flow with cold air in place, allowing heavy snow to develop over portions of northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter 1WSW Mount Shasta reported 4.0 inches of snow in 3 hours ending at 21/1856 PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dry cold front pushed southward through California during the evening over November 9. A cold airmass pushed into the area behind the front and as winds diminished overnight across the Kern County Deserts temperatures plummeted into the 20's at most locations. This resulted in the first hard freeze of the season in the Kern County Deserts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several locations reported minimum temperatures below 28 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a significant dry period of 45 straight dry days across most of the central California interior. A low pressure system pushed inland over northern California on November 21 and brought a period of generally light to moderate precipitation to the area from the afternoon of November 21 through the morning of November 22 as an associated cold front pushed southward through central California. The precipitation fell mainly in the form of snow above 7000 feet resulting in this system being the first significant winter storm of the season for the higher elevations of the Southern Sierra Nevada where 8 to 16 inches of snow fell. Much of the San Joaquin Valley picked up between a quarter to three quarters of an inch of an inch of rainfall after going totally dry for a month and a half. There were several reports of nuisance flooding although damage was minimal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Chilkoot Meadow SNOTEL (7147 feet) picked up an estimated 11 inches of new snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving low pressure system pulled a plume of moisture over the Mojave Desert, resulting in unseasonably heavy rain and some flash flooding. The unusually humid conditions also led to patchy dense fog.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Devil's Golf Course Road and Salt Creek Road were closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm coverage increased over portions of Mono County the 12th through the 14th. On the 12th, the strongest storms, over parts of central and southern Mono County, produced from around 0.25 to as much as 1.14 inches of rainfall. Thunderstorm coverage decreased the 13th, but then increased the 14th, with many of the storms being located in along the Eastern Sierra. These storms produced around 0.40 to as much as 1.18 inches of rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: RAWS, 1 mile northwest of Toms Place (elevation 7103 feet) reported 1.14 inches of rainfall in a 6-hour period from 12 July 1604PST to 12 July 2204PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed behind a cold front that passed through the area on the 25th. These thunderstorms caused minor roadway flooding and small hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: BB sized hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed behind a cold front that passed through the area on the 25th. These thunderstorms caused minor roadway flooding and small hail.
Low pressure over the northeast Pacific on the 18th moved southeast, reaching northern California on the 19th. This system brought high winds and snowfall to the Sierra Nevada and western Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eighteen-hour snowfall amounts ranged from 4 inches at lake level in the Tahoe Basin to as much as a 11 inches at the higher elevations around Lake Tahoe.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure over the northeast Pacific on the 18th moved southeast, reaching northern California on the 19th. This system brought high winds and snowfall to the Sierra Nevada and western Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station DYLC1 2 miles north of Doyle (elevation 4320 feet) reported a wind gust of 59 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure built back into California on the 23rd. With clear skies, light winds, residual low level moisture and inversion conditions over the San Joaquin Valley, areas of dense fog formed during the early morning hours of January 24th. The fog dissipated at most locations by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Merced and Atwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure built back into California on the 23rd. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold frontal system pushed through Central California on the 25th producing widespread light precipitation across the area as 5 to 10 inches of new snowfall above 7000 feet. High pressure strengthened off the California coast behind this system on the 26th and build inland by the morning of the 27th. Freezing fog impacted travel along State Route 58 during the early morning hours of the 27th. An area of dense fog later formed along the State Route 99 corridor late in the morning from Merced to Madera. The fog dissipated by midday.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Merced and Atwater.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing Fog was reported in Tehachapi.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level low over the northeast Pacific on the 24th moved southeast, reaching northern California on the 25th. The initial shortwave brought high winds and snow to the north-central Sierra Nevada. A secondary shortwave brought another round of snow to the Sierra Nevada the 25th into the 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station SSYC1 Surprise Valley RAWS reported a wind gust of 66 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Squaw Crest mesonet reported a wind gust of 94 mph with 58 mph sustained winds near the observation time.

The initial shortwave brought high winds and snow to the north-central Sierra Nevada. A secondary shortwave brought another round of snow to the Sierra Nevada the 25th into the 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall was greatest in the Lake Tahoe Basin where amounts ranged from 2 inches at lake level to as much as 12 inches near the Sierra Crest west of the lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak shortwave passed over Northern California on the night of the 26th into the early morning hours of the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A dry slab avalanche was triggered by a snowboarder on North Castle Peak near the Donner Summit Area at 0905PST 27 January. The crown height was 1 foot. The avalanche length and width were 150 feet and 60 feet, respectively. No injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure continued to strengthen it's grip on California during the last few days of January. Warming aloft resulted in a strengthening near surface inversion in the San Joaquin Valley and with mainly clear skies and light winds, an area of dense fog formed over  the center of the San Joaquin Valley which impacted travel along State Routes 99 and 198 as well as resulting in several school districts opening late and delaying bus service. The fog burned off by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Merced and Atwater.

The fog burned off by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several School districts had delayed openings or bus service due to dense fog.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Areas of dense fog formed once again overnight in the San Joaquin Valley as persistent high pressure brought clear skies, light winds and continued inversion conditions over the valley. The fog became dense in several locations during the early morning hours and resulted in several auto accidents along State Route 198 near Hanford. Several school districts had delayed openings and cancelled morning bus service as a result of the widespread dense fog on the morning of the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility of 100 feet or less was reported by California Highway Patrol along State Highway 41 near the Nebraska Ave intersection. Several school districts had delayed openings due to dense fog.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Areas of dense fog formed once again overnight in the San Joaquin Valley as persistent high pressure brought clear skies, light winds and continued inversion conditions over the valley. The fog became dense in several locations during the early morning hours and resulted in several auto accidents along State Route 198 near Hanford. Several school districts had delayed openings and cancelled morning bus service as a result of the widespread dense fog on the morning of the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility less than a quarter mile was reported in Fresno, Merced and Atwater. Several school districts had delayed openings due to dense fog.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm coverage increased over portions of Mono County the 12th through the 14th. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: January 2018 began with strong high pressure dominating over Central California. The high broke down by the 4th as a low pressure system pushed through Northern California bringing generally light precipitation to the area although a few locations picked up between a quarter and half an inch of rainfall. A few inches of snow fell above 8000 feet. Another low pressure pushed through Northern California on the morning of January 6 which brought half an inch to an inch of rain to much of Yosemite Park and Mariposa Counties with lesser amounts further south. Snow was mainly confined to elevations above 8000 feet with this system. A strong low pressure system moved southward off the Central California coast then pushed inland across Southern California between the morning of the 8th and the evening of the 9th. This system produced more substantial rainfall across the area with many locations in the Southern Sierra Nevada picking up between an inch and 2 inches of liquid precipitation. Strong southerly flow ahead of the system resulted in warming across the area ahead of the low and snow levels were above 10000 feet on the 8th when most of the precipitation fell. As the low moved closer to the area on the morning of the 9th, strong downslope winds developed in the south end of the San Joaquin Valley and the valley facing slopes of the Kern County Mountains. Winds along interstate 5 frequently gusted above 50 mph and the Grapevine Peak RAWS (which is on an exposed ridge top) gusted up to 94 mph. Areas of street flooding were reported in the Bakersfield area on the morning of the 9th, and some mudslides were produced by heavy rainfall closing roads at the intersection of Cuddy Valley Road and Mil Portero Highway west of Frazier Park and on Redrock Randsburg Road in the Kern County Desert. Colder air pushed into the area on the back side of the low lowering the snow levels to 5000 to 5500 feet where a few inches of snow fell in post-frontal showery precipitation. A few thunderstorms were observed in the south end of the San Joaquin Valley in the unstable airmass. The precipitation had ended by the morning of the 10th as the low moved out of the area. However, upslope low clouds lingered in much of the San Joaquin Valley and the lower foothills of the Southern Sierra Nevada and Kern County Mountains while dense fog slowed down traffic along Interstate 5 in the Grapevine area and along Highway 58 near Tehachapi. Most of the low cloud deck cleared out by the evening of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pictures indicating roadway flooding in downtown Bakersfield near the intersection on Union Ave. and Truxton Ave. were received on Facebook and Twitter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Areas of dense fog formed once again overnight in the San Joaquin Valley as persistent high pressure brought clear skies, light winds and continued inversion conditions over the valley. The fog became dense in several locations during the early morning hours and resulted in several auto accidents along State Route 198 near Hanford. Several school districts had delayed openings and cancelled morning bus service as a result of the widespread dense fog on the morning of the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility less than a quarter mile was reported in Visalia. Several school districts had delayed openings due to dense fog.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Areas of dense fog formed once again overnight in the San Joaquin Valley as persistent high pressure brought clear skies, light winds and continued inversion conditions over the valley. The fog became dense in several locations during the early morning hours and resulted in several auto accidents along State Route 198 near Hanford. Several school districts had delayed openings and cancelled morning bus service as a result of the widespread dense fog on the morning of the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility less than a quarter mile was reported in Hanford. California Highway patrol was pacing traffic along State Highway 198 between the Kings/Tulare County line and Armona as several fog related minor auto accidents were reported. Several school districts had delayed openings due to dense fog.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow impacted travel across the mountains of northern interior California. Thunderstorms brought a funnel cloud and small hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A rotating wall cloud with a funnel cloud was reported by a trained spotter, viewed just to the southwest of Loma Rica. No contact with the ground was observed. Pea size hail was also reported with this storm.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported a total of 24 of snow at Kingvale, between January 24-26.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Caltrans reported a total of 10 of snow at Cabbage Patch 6800', 6 at Camp Connell 5000', bringing chain controls and travel delays to Hwy 4.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Low elevation snow impacted Highway 89 with chain controls and delays.  Caltrans reported 14 of snow measured at Eskimo Hill, elevation 6000'.

Colder air pushed into the area on the back side of the low lowering the snow levels to 5000 to 5500 feet where a few inches of snow fell in post-frontal showery precipitation. A few thunderstorms were observed in the south end of the San Joaquin Valley in the unstable airmass. The precipitation had ended by the morning of the 10th as the low moved out of the area. However, upslope low clouds lingered in much of the San Joaquin Valley and the lower foothills of the Southern Sierra Nevada and Kern County Mountains while dense fog slowed down traffic along Interstate 5 in the Grapevine area and along Highway 58 near Tehachapi. Most of the low cloud deck cleared out by the evening of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public report of mudslide closing the intersection of Cuddy Valley Rd. and Mil Portero Hwy 8W Frazier Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: January 2018 began with strong high pressure dominating over Central California. The high broke down by the 4th as a low pressure system pushed through Northern California bringing generally light precipitation to the area although a few locations picked up between a quarter and half an inch of rainfall. A few inches of snow fell above 8000 feet. Another low pressure pushed through Northern California on the morning of January 6 which brought half an inch to an inch of rain to much of Yosemite Park and Mariposa Counties with lesser amounts further south. Snow was mainly confined to elevations above 8000 feet with this system. A strong low pressure system moved southward off the Central California coast then pushed inland across Southern California between the morning of the 8th and the evening of the 9th. This system produced more substantial rainfall across the area with many locations in the Southern Sierra Nevada picking up between an inch and 2 inches of liquid precipitation. Strong southerly flow ahead of the system resulted in warming across the area ahead of the low and snow levels were above 10000 feet on the 8th when most of the precipitation fell. As the low moved closer to the area on the morning of the 9th, strong downslope winds developed in the south end of the San Joaquin Valley and the valley facing slopes of the Kern County Mountains. Winds along interstate 5 frequently gusted above 50 mph and the Grapevine Peak RAWS (which is on an exposed ridge top) gusted up to 94 mph. Areas of street flooding were reported in the Bakersfield area on the morning of the 9th, and some mudslides were produced by heavy rainfall closing roads at the intersection of Cuddy Valley Road and Mil Portero Highway west of Frazier Park and on Redrock Randsburg Road in the Kern County Desert. Colder air pushed into the area on the back side of the low lowering the snow levels to 5000 to 5500 feet where a few inches of snow fell in post-frontal showery precipitation. A few thunderstorms were observed in the south end of the San Joaquin Valley in the unstable airmass. The precipitation had ended by the morning of the 10th as the low moved out of the area. However, upslope low clouds lingered in much of the San Joaquin Valley and the lower foothills of the Southern Sierra Nevada and Kern County Mountains while dense fog slowed down traffic along Interstate 5 in the Grapevine area and along Highway 58 near Tehachapi. Most of the low cloud deck cleared out by the evening of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported flooding and debris across Redrock-Randsburg Rd. near Cantil and the road was closed to traffic.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow impacted travel across the mountains of northern interior California. Thunderstorms brought a funnel cloud and small hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Low elevation snow impacted Interstate 5 with chain controls and long delays from Fawndale Rd. northward. This area was also closed for several hours due to a jacknifed big rig near Castella. Traffic backed up to Pine Grove Ave, by Shasta Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow impacted travel across the mountains of northern interior California. Thunderstorms brought a funnel cloud and small hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Caltrans reported a total of 20 of snow at Soda Springs, between January 24-26. This brought chain controls to mountain freeways such as I80 and Highway 50, with vehicle spin outs, and long travel delays.||Ski resorts reported heavy snow, with storm totals of 24 at Squaw Valley, 23 at Tahoe Donner, 20 at Boreal, 18 at Sugar Bowl, and 12 at Bear Valley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow impacted travel across the mountains of northern interior California. Thunderstorms brought a funnel cloud and small hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Low elevation snow impacted Highway 299 and 70 with chain controls and delays.  Snotel at Lower Lassen Peak at 8250' reported 19 of snow. Coop observer at Chester reported 7 of snow, with 4 falling in just 2 hours.  There was 1 of snow measured at Shingletown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An incoming front brought winds to some locations in northeast California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The RAWS at Timber Mountain recorded a gust to 66 mph at 24/1303 PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of large long period northwest swell arrived at the beaches between the 16th and 20th of January. This brought high surf to west and northwest facing beaches with peak sets occurring in southern San Diego County. Significant beach erosion was reported along with isolated coastal flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mission Beach Lifeguards reported 8-10 ft surf on both the 19th and 20th, with most other sites reporting 5-9 ft surf. Windansea and Black's Beach both reported sets to 10 ft on the 20th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of large long period northwest swell arrived at the beaches between the 16th and 20th of January. This brought high surf to west and northwest facing beaches with peak sets occurring in southern San Diego County. Significant beach erosion was reported along with isolated coastal flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread 4-8 ft surf was reported along with occasional 9-10 ft sets at Huntington Beach and San Clemente.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of large long period northwest swell arrived at the beaches between the 16th and 20th of January. This brought high surf to west and northwest facing beaches with peak sets occurring in southern San Diego County. Significant beach erosion was reported along with isolated coastal flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Huntington Beach Lifeguards reported mild to moderate beach erosion.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of large long period northwest swell arrived at the beaches between the 16th and 20th of January. This brought high surf to west and northwest facing beaches with peak sets occurring in southern San Diego County. Significant beach erosion was reported along with isolated coastal flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mission Beach Lifeguards reported average sets to 8 ft and peak sets of 12 ft on the 16th, 8 ft surf lingered through the 17th. Surf in the 5-8 ft range was widespread along the coast via lifeguard and Surfline reports. Peak sets to 10 ft were reported at Black's Beach. The Ocean Beach Pier was closed due to the high surf. A surfer was pulled out to sea by a strong rip current at Ocean Beach.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of large long period northwest swell arrived at the beaches between the 16th and 20th of January. This brought high surf to west and northwest facing beaches with peak sets occurring in southern San Diego County. Significant beach erosion was reported along with isolated coastal flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Coastal flooding occurred in the parking lots of Aliso and Capistrano Beaches, and along the Strand in Oceanside during the morning high tide. A significant amount of sand was lost at Solana Beach, with 50 ft of sand erosion from the beach in Oceanside.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of large long period northwest swell arrived at the beaches between the 16th and 20th of January. This brought high surf to west and northwest facing beaches with peak sets occurring in southern San Diego County. Significant beach erosion was reported along with isolated coastal flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lifeguards at Huntington Beach reported 8-10 ft surf. Reported sets across the rest of the counties coastline were in the 4-8 ft range.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm coverage increased over portions of Mono County the 12th through the 14th. On the 12th, the strongest storms, over parts of central and southern Mono County, produced from around 0.25 to as much as 1.14 inches of rainfall. Thunderstorm coverage decreased the 13th, but then increased the 14th, with many of the storms being located in along the Eastern Sierra. These storms produced around 0.40 to as much as 1.18 inches of rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station HGNC1, 3 miles east of Meyers (elevation 7741 feet) reported 0.80 inches of rainfall in a 24-hour period from 13 July 2000PST to 14 July 2000PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moderate strength trough of low pressure swept through the SoCal Bight with gusty winds, mountain snow and heavy rainfall. Rainfall totals of 1-2 inches occurred over the coast and valleys, with isolated amounts of 6-8 inches along favored coastal slopes. Snowfall was 2 to 8 inches above 6,000 ft with up to 12 inches on the higher peaks. Wind caused major damage to the historic Bay Theater in San Diego. Around 10 swift water rescues were reported in the Inland Empire and San Bernardino County Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A van drove into flood waters flowing through the normally dry Lytle Creek, resulting in a swift water rescue.

Around 10 swift water rescues were reported in the Inland Empire and San Bernardino County Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three people and a dog were rescued by helicopter from the Santa Ana River Channel at Agua Mansa Rd. and Riverside Ave. in Colton. Several other individuals were swept down stream and rescued in Riverside.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure strengthened off the coast of Baja and built northward into California on the 11th bringing a drying trend across the area. However, inversion conditions, mainly clear skies and light winds in the San Joaquin Valley resulted in the formation of dense fog which lowered visibility to below a quarter mile in Fresno, Visalia and Hanford and impacted travel along State Routes 99, 198, 43 and 41. Several school districts had either  delayed openings or bus delays as a result of the dense fog. The fog dissipated by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Fresno.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of snow impacted the area over roughly a 36 hour period. Peak snowfall amounts of 12 inches were reported above 7000 ft (12 inches at Green Valley Lake). Between 5,500 ft and 7,000 ft amounts were in the 2-8 inch range. Big Bear Lake and Wrightwood reported 2 inches, with 8 inches in Running Springs.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A minor debris flow was reported along Green River Rd. in Corona. The flow was associated with the Canyon 1 Fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak trough and associate cold front brought light showers and breezy winds. A light coating of snow caused issues in the mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A light coating of snow required chain controls.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure over the northeast Pacific on the 18th moved southeast, reaching northern California on the 19th. This system brought high winds and snowfall to the Sierra Nevada and western Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station JDPC1 9 miles northwest Frenchman Lake (elevation 6812 feet) reported a wind gust of 68 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure over the northeast Pacific on the 18th moved southeast, reaching northern California on the 19th. This system brought high winds and snowfall to the Sierra Nevada and western Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station TADC1 2 miles northeast of Donner Peak (elevation 7399 feet) reported a wind gust of 64 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure strengthened off the coast of Baja and built northward into California on the 11th bringing a drying trend across the area. However, inversion conditions, mainly clear skies and light winds in the San Joaquin Valley resulted in the formation of dense fog which lowered visibility to below a quarter mile in Fresno, Visalia and Hanford and impacted travel along State Routes 99, 198, 43 and 41. Several school districts had either  delayed openings or bus delays as a result of the dense fog. The fog dissipated by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Visalia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The high strengthened over Central California on morning of the 12th and with mainly clear skies, light winds and a low level inversion over the San Joaquin Valley a strip of dense fog formed along the center portion of the valley extending from the Merced area to north of Delano causing travel delays and delayed openings for several school districts. The fog persisted between Merced and Madera until midday, but most of the valley cleared out by afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported dense fog on State Route 152 from Los Banos to Turner Island and on State Route 41 near the Manning Ave. intersection.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak trough and associate cold front brought light showers and breezy winds. A light coating of snow caused issues in the mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A quick burst of snow produced snow covered roads in Cuyamaca, at Mt. Laguna and along Sunrise Hwy and State Route 79.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface high built over the Great Basin, resulting in offshore pressure gradients and Santa Ana Winds in SoCal on the 27th, 28th and 29th of January. The east/west nature of the gradients favored San Diego County for the strongest winds. A peak wind gust of 89 mph was reported at Sill Hill.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The mesonet station at Sill Hill reported periodic gusts in the 60-80 mph range over a period of roughly 30 hours. A max gust of 89 mph was recorded. Winds were not as pronounced at other mountain mesonet stations with peak gust mostly in the 35-65 mph range. No major damage reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface high built over the Great Basin, resulting in offshore pressure gradients and Santa Ana Winds in SoCal on the 27th, 28th and 29th of January. The east/west nature of the gradients favored San Diego County for the strongest winds. A peak wind gust of 89 mph was reported at Sill Hill.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple mesonet stations reported peak wind gusts in the 58-63 mph range. Winds were focused toward the eastern portion of the valleys. No major damage reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface high built over the Great Basin, resulting in offshore pressure gradients and Santa Ana Winds in SoCal on the 27th, 28th and 29th of January. The east/west nature of the gradients favored San Diego County for the strongest winds. A peak wind gust of 89 mph was reported at Sill Hill.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple mesonet stations reported winds in the 50-65 mph range over the eastern valleys. A peak of 68 mph occurred at Alpine Raws between 0652 and 0752 PST. No significant impacts reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface high built over the Great Basin, resulting in offshore pressure gradients and Santa Ana Winds in SoCal on the 27th, 28th and 29th of January. The east/west nature of the gradients favored San Diego County for the strongest winds. A peak wind gust of 89 mph was reported at Sill Hill.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusted in the 60-74 mph range at Fremont Canyon. Other stations in the Santa Ana Mountains saw lighter winds, though Pleasants peak did have a peak gust of 65 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface high built over the Great Basin, resulting in offshore pressure gradients and Santa Ana Winds in SoCal on the 27th, 28th and 29th of January. The east/west nature of the gradients favored San Diego County for the strongest winds. A peak wind gust of 89 mph was reported at Sill Hill.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The mesonet station in Fremont Canyon reported a brief period with wind gusts in excess of 70 mph. Pleasants Peak also gusted to 66 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Daytime heating and ample moisture along the periphery of a ridge caused scattered convection over western Nevada and the eastern Sierra July 19th through the 25th. Several storms produced heavy rainfall which led to flash flooding and debris flows. Hail was also reported with some storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Department of Transportation (Caltrans) reported a debris flow just east of Tioga Pass on State Route 120 in Mono County, closing a three mile stretch of the road from US Highway 395 to the debris flow site. According to The Mercury News, a car was hit by a rock at 1600PST. Within 20 minutes, an active debris flow was declared. The road remained closed until 21 July 1930PST. No nearby gauges were available to estimate the rainfall amounts near the debris flow path. No damage/cleanup estimates were available.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The high strengthened over Central California on morning of the 12th and with mainly clear skies, light winds and a low level inversion over the San Joaquin Valley a strip of dense fog formed along the center portion of the valley extending from the Merced area to north of Delano causing travel delays and delayed openings for several school districts. The fog persisted between Merced and Madera until midday, but most of the valley cleared out by afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Fresno, Madera, Merced and Atwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The high strengthened over Central California on morning of the 12th and with mainly clear skies, light winds and a low level inversion over the San Joaquin Valley a strip of dense fog formed along the center portion of the valley extending from the Merced area to north of Delano causing travel delays and delayed openings for several school districts. The fog persisted between Merced and Madera until midday, but most of the valley cleared out by afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Hanford and Lemoore. California Highway patrol reported visibility below a quarter mile on State Route 198 between 1st Ave. to the Avenal Cut Off Rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Fog again formed overnight in the San Joaquin Valley on the morning of the 13th, but lifted into a status deck as a moderate offshore flow provided for a lifting mechanism. Dense fog persisted in potions of Kern and Tulare Counties in the south end of the valley including the Bakersfield area to 200 to 500 feet through the late morning hours until the fog lifted into a low cloud deck.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported dense fog reducing visibility down as low as 200 feet along State Route 99 from Sherwood Ave in McFarland to County Line Rd in Delano. Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Bakersfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The low cloud deck that prevailed over much of the San Joaquin Valley on the 13th persisted through the afternoon of the 14th. This inhibited fog from forming on the morning of the 14th. However, a weak system moving north of the area helped break up much of the stratus deck which allowed for dense fog to form on the morning of the 15th as winds became light and skies cleared out. California Highway Patrol paced traffic along Interstate 5 for several hours until the fog lifted into a stratus deck by midday.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported dense fog on Interstate 5 from State Highway 198 to Panoche Rd. and in and around Coalinga.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The low cloud deck that prevailed over much of the San Joaquin Valley on the 13th persisted through the afternoon of the 14th. CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface high built over the Great Basin, resulting in offshore pressure gradients and Santa Ana Winds in SoCal on the 27th, 28th and 29th of January. The east/west nature of the gradients favored San Diego County for the strongest winds. A peak wind gust of 89 mph was reported at Sill Hill.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Highland Springs mesonet reported gusts in excess of 58 mph for 3 hours. Winds were significantly lower across the rest of the Inland Empire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper level low off the shore of southern California moved inland across the Southern Sierra Nevada on the 8th and 9th, bringing snowfall to locations above 7500 feet in Mono County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mammoth Mountain and June Mountain Ski areas reported between 12 to 18 inches of snowfall in 24 hours with mesonets in the area below 7500 feet reporting between 0.60 to 0.97 inches of rain in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoonal moisture and atmospheric instability resulted in widespread thunderstorm activity in Riverside and San Bernardino counties on July 7th. A large thunderstorm from the San Bernardino Mountains moved south into Banning and brought gusty winds to the area. Sylvan Park was the hardest hit, where numerous trees were damaged. Winds were estimated to be 56 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large thunderstorm cell progressed south off of the San Gorgonio Mountain into Banning on July 7th around 1100 PST.  It brought strong winds to the Banning area, in particular, Sylvan Park. Numerous trees were damaged from winds in the park. After a storm survey, the winds in Sylvan Park were estimated to be 56 knots from the thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of two storm systems, one off the northern California coast and one southwest of Los Angeles, produced heavy rainfall across the central coast over January 8th to the 9th. Rain caused minor roadway flooding and a few small debris flows.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roadway flooding reported at 3601 Telegraph Ave. Eight inches of standing water blocking the off ramp.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread dense fog formed once again across the San Joaquin Valley on the evening of the 15th and the morning of the 16th as the anticipated storm that supposed to impact the area remained to the north of the area and skies cleared out. Visibility was below a quarter mile across most of the valley on the morning of the 16th. This resulted in several school districts having delayed openings and bus delays or cancellations. The fog lifted into a stratus deck by late morning then stratus broke up by late afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported dense fog on State Route 152 between State Route 59 and Los Banos.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Fog reformed in the San Joaquin Valley during the late evening hours of the 17th and continued through the morning of the 18th. However, the coverage of dense fog was not extensive as it was during the previous three mornings. Travel was impacted for periods of time along State Highway 99. A frontal system moved through the area from the evening of the 18th through the morning of the 19th which mixed out the atmosphere and  ended the cycle of fog and low clouds over the San Joaquin Valley for a few days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Atwater.

CZ_NAME: SOUTHERN MONTEREY BAY AND BIG SUR COAST
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system over the eastern Pacific generated large swell along the central coast. This led to a High Surf Warning due to wave heights of 17 to over 20 feet at periods of 18 to 20 seconds. Surfers were rescued in Santa Cruz, Capitola during the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Half Moon Bay Buoy reported wave height of 23 ft at 17 seconds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This low pressure system which moved through the area on the 19th brought light precipitation to much of the area and a few inches of snow to the higher elevations of the Southern Sierra Nevada while 1 to 2 inches snow fell over the passes in the Kern County Mountains. Another low pressure system moved through the Pacific Northwest on the 22nd pushing a cold front through Central California. Upslope clouds behind the front banked up in the Kern County mountains producing freezing drizzle near Frazier Park.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported drizzle with low clouds turned to black ice on Cuddy Valley Rd 8 WNW Frazier Park which caused a vehicle to hit a tree. The driver was injured and taken to a hospital for treatment and the car was totaled.

An inch of snow was reported down to Lakehead at 1500 feet elevation, with light accumulations down to 1200 feet at O'Brien.  There was 6.5 of snow reported 5 miles northwest of Mt. Shasta.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first part of this storm consisted of warm air advection precipitation that spread through the northern Sierra. Moist upslope flow brought precipitation into Mono County at the same time. The second part of this storm moved into the Sierra Nevada on the 21st and 22nd in the form of a fairly significant atmospheric river, tapping a deep plume of moisture moving in from the Eastern Pacific.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station RUBC1 near Meeks Bay reported 4.80 inches of storm total rainfall from 20 March 0600PST to 23 March 0600PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although the cold airmass over the San Joaquin Valley moderated somewhat on the February 24, clear skies and light winds overnight resulted in another morning of subfreezing temperatures on the east side of the San Joaquin Valley on the morning of February 25. Overnight temperatures in the valley moderated the next two mornings as a low pressure system brought widespread clouds and precipitation into the area by February 26. While this system brought some generally light precipitation to the area through the morning of February 27 as most of the moisture and dynamics with this system remained over Northern California, there were some impacts to travel in the Southern Sierra Foothills and the Kern County Mountains as snow levels lowered to around 2000 feet. Temperatures across the area were well below normal for the last 10 days of February following an unseasonably warm start to the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several locations reported minimum temperatures between 28 and 32 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably cold temperatures and frost caused potentially significant damage to the 2018 Central Valley almond crop harvest by happening during the sensitive blooming phase. Temperatures in many locations reached or fell below the critical bloom temperature of 27. Some in the agricultural community were projecting frost damage ...worst since perhaps the 1970s. (AgFax Tree Crops, Feb 26, 2018). ||Snow fell in the Sierra, with unusually cold temperatures allowing snow down into the Sierra foothills, to elevations as low as 1400 feet. This caused some travel slow downs and delays in areas that usually don't see accumulating snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Almond trees were in critical bloom and early nutlet stage during the freeze/frost event. Damage has been projected as significant, but it is too early for specific details. Temperatures at Crabtree Weather Station reached 24 on the 19th, 22 on the 20th, 25 on the 21st. Temperatures at Stockton Metropolitan Airport reached 28 on the 20th and 21st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably cold temperatures and frost caused potentially significant damage to the 2018 Central Valley almond crop harvest by happening during the sensitive blooming phase. Temperatures in many locations reached or fell below the critical bloom temperature of 27. Some in the agricultural community were projecting frost damage ...worst since perhaps the 1970s. (AgFax Tree Crops, Feb 26, 2018). ||Snow fell in the Sierra, with unusually cold temperatures allowing snow down into the Sierra foothills, to elevations as low as 1400 feet. This caused some travel slow downs and delays in areas that usually don't see accumulating snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Almond trees were in critical bloom and early nutlet stage during the freeze/frost event. Damage has been projected as significant, but it is too early for specific details. Temperatures at Sacramento International Airport reached 26 on the 20th, 27 at Sacramento Mather Airport and at McClellan Airfield. Vacaville Nut Tree Airport reached 28 on the 20th and 21st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold low pressure system dropped south from the Pacific Northwest during the afternoon of February 22 bringing increased winds and showery precipitation to much of the area. Several locations in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts reported wind gusts between 35 and 45 mph while a few low impact indicator sites reported stronger gusts. In addition to the increased winds, much of the Southern Sierra Nevada picked up between 5 and 10 inches of new snow while lesser amounts accumulated in the Southern Sierra Foothills and Kern County Mountains where there where travel was adversely impacted as the snow level lowered to near 1500 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jawbone Canyon RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 59 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper trough over the Great Basin provided for a cold northerly flow over central California for several days beginning on the afternoon of February 19. This resulted in a cold and dry airmass becoming settled over the San Joaquin Valley by the morning of February 20 as the valley experienced its coldest morning in several years at many locations as many reporting stations reported several hours of subfreezing temperatures. Since many trees and plants were already in bloom, numerous crops experienced significant damage from the cold overnight temperatures. The snap pea crop was nearly wiped out entirely and several nut orchards experienced significant crop damage as the almond crop was especially hit hard. Damage to citrus was somewhat migitated by the fact that much of the crop had already been harvested.  The damage would have been significantly greater if not for frost protection measures taken by several growers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several locations reported minimum temperatures below 28 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With a cold airmass remaining in place over the San Joaquin Valley, clearing skies and light winds allowed for temperatures to drop below the freezing mark on the morning of February 24 after clouds and increased winds kept temperatures up the morning before.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several locations reported minimum temperatures between 28 and 32 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Torrential rain from an atmospheric river with locally heavy convective showers brought flash flooding to portions of the northern Sierra and Motherlode foothills. The heaviest flooding was in Groveland, where 4-5 of rain fell, combining with 8-9 of rain in higher elevations upstream. There was also widespread damage in Tuolumne County to roads from debris flows, soil erosion, erosion of water conveyance systems, sewer systems that were inundated with excess water and debris. Roads damaged inluded state Highways 49 and 132. Moccasin Dam was damaged and came close to failure, with  road closures. A tornado struck an amphitheater in Wheatland and caused minor damage. Heavy snow caused travel problems over Sierra highways.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Combie road flooded due to overtopping of the adjacent Ragsdale Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Daytime heating and ample moisture along the periphery of a ridge caused scattered convection over western Nevada and the eastern Sierra July 19th through the 25th. Several storms produced heavy rainfall which led to flash flooding and debris flows. Hail was also reported with some storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported minor roadway flooding along Valley Road and Hunter Avenue in Chalfant Valley at 19 July 1550PST. No damage estimates were available.

Roads damaged inluded state Highways 49 and 132. Moccasin Dam was damaged and came close to failure, with  road closures. A tornado struck an amphitheater in Wheatland and caused minor damage. Heavy snow caused travel problems over Sierra highways.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extensive flooding in downtown Groveland, as floodwaters ran down the main street, Highway 120. Property was damage and water rescues for stranded residents. There was significant damage done to Groveland Community Hall and Mary Laveroni Community Park. Preliminary estimates from Tuolumne County are approximately $8 million for 16 damaged sites along county maintained roads. A very large portion of these damages are seen in the sinkhole at Ferretti Road and slides and embankment loss on Priest Coulterville Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused a railroad bridge in Marysville to sink. The bridge spans the Yuba River. Rail traffic over the bridge was shut down. A diesel pipeline attached to the bridge also had to be shut down. Union Pacific Railroad drove in new piles to stabilize the bridge. Repairs were completed on March 27.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level low over the northeast Pacific on February 28th moved southeast, reaching southern Oregon/northern California on the 1st of March. This system brought high winds and snowfall to the Sierra Nevada and western Nevada through the 3rd. Several school and business closures occurred due to the heavy snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Interstate 80 closed from Colfax, CA, to the Nevada State line due to high winds, heavy snowfall, and whiteout conditions. The closure of Interstate 80 lasted from the early afternoon of 1 March through the late morning of 2 March. Chain and snow tires were required on several roads around the Greater Lake Tahoe Area. A snowboarder became lost during the blizzard conditions the night of the 1st and was found deceased near Squaw Valley Ski Resort 2 March at 1017PST. The cause of death from several reports is undetermined. Wind gusts during peak blizzard conditions ranged from 47 to 63 mph in the Greater Lake Tahoe area below 8,000 feet MSL, with the highest wind gust of 146 mph reported at 1 March 2134PST from a mesonet atop the summit of Squaw Valley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper trough over the Great Basin provided for a cold northerly flow over central California for several days beginning on the afternoon of February 19. This resulted in a cold and dry airmass becoming settled over the San Joaquin Valley by the morning of February 20 as the valley experienced its coldest morning in several years at many locations as many reporting stations reported several hours of subfreezing temperatures. Since many trees and plants were already in bloom, numerous crops experienced significant damage from the cold overnight temperatures. The snap pea crop was nearly wiped out entirely and several nut orchards experienced significant crop damage as the almond crop was especially hit hard. Damage to citrus was somewhat migitated by the fact that much of the crop had already been harvested.  The damage would have been significantly greater if not for frost protection measures taken by several growers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several locations reported minimum temperatures between 28 and 32 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep, cold low pressure system and associated cold front brought high winds to portions of the Mojave Desert and Owens Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak gust was measured 4 miles NW of Independence.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The cold airmass over the San Joaquin Valley remained in place as clear skies and light winds prevailed overnight. Radiational cooling allowed for temperatures to drop below the freezing mark for several hours once again during the morning of February 21.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several locations reported minimum temperatures between 28 and 32 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although a storm was expected to bring increasing clouds to the area on the morning of February 22, this system took a little longer than anticipated to reach Central California and skies remained clear in the San Joaquin Valley for much of night allowing for another night of radiational cooling to take place. Temperatures dropped below the freezing in the San Joaquin Valley for several hours for the third consecutive morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several locations reported minimum temperatures between 28 and 32 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Daytime heating and ample moisture along the periphery of a ridge caused scattered convection over western Nevada and the eastern Sierra July 19th through the 25th. Several storms produced heavy rainfall which led to flash flooding and debris flows. Hail was also reported with some storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol indicated a two-lane road closure of Lundy Lake Road, about 5 miles northwest of Mono Lake, due to a rock slide/debris flow across the roadway. The Lundy Raws sensor recorded 0.75 inches of rain in a 3 hour time period before the slide occurred. No damage estimates were available.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mountain snow continued into early March, with storm totals up to around 5 feet. There were also periods of heavy rain in the Central Valley and foothills.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mother and son died after returning from a day of skiing to their vacation condominium in Kirkwood. A chunk of snow about the size of a trailer fell from the roof of their vacation condominium, burying them under about 3 feet of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Torrential rain from an atmospheric river with locally heavy convective showers brought flash flooding to portions of the northern Sierra and Motherlode foothills. The heaviest flooding was in Groveland, where 4-5 of rain fell, combining with 8-9 of rain in higher elevations upstream. There was also widespread damage in Tuolumne County to roads from debris flows, soil erosion, erosion of water conveyance systems, sewer systems that were inundated with excess water and debris. Roads damaged inluded state Highways 49 and 132. Moccasin Dam was damaged and came close to failure, with  road closures. A tornado struck an amphitheater in Wheatland and caused minor damage. Heavy snow caused travel problems over Sierra highways.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A period of heavy rain upstream from Moccasin Dam, in which about three inches fell during four hours led to significant erosion and at least one landslide. It caused a massive amount of water and debris to run downhill into the Moccasin Reservoir. The water level rose to 3 times the normal reservoir capacity and the emergency spillway was utilized. There was severe erosion of the emergency spillway and potential for the dam to fail.  The Power house and staff at the Moccasin Fish Hatchery were evacuated due to potential failure. All the fish in the Moccasin Creek Hatchery were killed when it flooded from the water coming over the emergency spillway.  The National Weather Service issued a flash flood warning associated with the probable dam failure, and the sheriff advised residents to avoid the area as a matter of public safety. The warning was reduced to a watch until the reservoir was drained and then the watch was canceled once the reservoir was drained.||Cleanup and repair efforts associated with a major storm that damaged Tuolumne County's Moccasin Creek Dam in March is expected to cost roughly $43 million, according to an estimate by the San Francisco Public Utilities Commission, which owns and operates the dam. That total includes $3.2 million in damage to the state fish hatchery at Moccasin Creek, which lies downstream.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although the cold airmass over the San Joaquin Valley moderated somewhat on the February 24, clear skies and light winds overnight resulted in another morning of subfreezing temperatures on the east side of the San Joaquin Valley on the morning of February 25. Overnight temperatures in the valley moderated the next two mornings as a low pressure system brought widespread clouds and precipitation into the area by February 26. While this system brought some generally light precipitation to the area through the morning of February 27 as most of the moisture and dynamics with this system remained over Northern California, there were some impacts to travel in the Southern Sierra Foothills and the Kern County Mountains as snow levels lowered to around 2000 feet. Temperatures across the area were well below normal for the last 10 days of February following an unseasonably warm start to the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several locations reported minimum temperatures between 28 and 32 degrees.

Numerous road closures were reported, including I80 east of Applegate due to heavy snow, Carson Pass/SR-88 and Hwy 50 between Twin Bridges and Meyers for avalanche control, Hwy 89 between Truckee an d Alpine Meadows due to a collision involving 20 vehicles, Hwy 50 eastbound at Sly Park Rd, westbound of Meyers due to snow downed power lines, and Hwy 20 east of Nevada City due to heavy snow.

One person sustained a serious lower body injury. A second guest had to be rescued, but was taken to the base of Squaw Valley and released. Three others left unharmed, according to KOLO8 News Reno.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An avalanche at Mammoth Mountain occurred at approximately 1015PST on 3 March during a avalanche hazard mitigation search performed by the area ski patrol. The snow slid down down a steep run and funneled into a narrow chute named Upper Dry Creek before coming to a stop a the base of a chairlift. Six Mammoth Mountain employees at the lift were partially caught but freed themselves quickly, suffering only minor injuries. Source: Los Angeles Times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although a storm was expected to bring increasing clouds to the area on the morning of February 22, this system took a little longer than anticipated to reach Central California and skies remained clear in the San Joaquin Valley for much of night allowing for another night of radiational cooling to take place. Temperatures dropped below the freezing in the San Joaquin Valley for several hours for the third consecutive morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several locations reported minimum temperatures between 28 and 32 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first part of this storm consisted of warm air advection precipitation that spread through the northern Sierra. Moist upslope flow brought precipitation into Mono County at the same time. The second part of this storm moved into the Sierra Nevada on the 21st and 22nd in the form of a fairly significant atmospheric river, tapping a deep plume of moisture moving in from the Eastern Pacific.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public in Homewood measured 5.30 inches of storm total rainfall from 20 March 1133PST to 23 March 1133PST. 0.89 inches of that rainfall fell from 22 March 1133PST to 23 March 1133PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold low pressure system dropped south from the Pacific Northwest during the afternoon of February 22 bringing increased winds and showery precipitation to much of the area. Several locations in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts reported wind gusts between 35 and 45 mph while a few low impact indicator sites reported stronger gusts. In addition to the increased winds, much of the Southern Sierra Nevada picked up between 5 and 10 inches of new snow while lesser amounts accumulated in the Southern Sierra Foothills and Kern County Mountains where there where travel was adversely impacted as the snow level lowered to near 1500 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bird Springs Pass RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 68 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level system with a strong cold front moved through the Bay Area at the turn of the month with precipitation beginning late the evening of the 28th. This system brought widespread rainfall causing localized roadway flooding, strong winds, lightning, and small hail. Gusts in the mountains reached 60 mph and hail was seen up to 1/2 an inch. The bulk of the precipitation and subsequent impacts were seen in early March.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roadway flooding reported at 3601 Telegraph Ave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably cold temperatures and frost caused potentially significant damage to the 2018 Central Valley almond crop harvest by happening during the sensitive blooming phase. Temperatures in many locations reached or fell below the critical bloom temperature of 27. Some in the agricultural community were projecting frost damage ...worst since perhaps the 1970s. (AgFax Tree Crops, Feb 26, 2018). ||Snow fell in the Sierra, with unusually cold temperatures allowing snow down into the Sierra foothills, to elevations as low as 1400 feet. This caused some travel slow downs and delays in areas that usually don't see accumulating snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Almond trees were in critical bloom and early nutlet stage during the freeze/frost event. Damage has been projected as significant, but it is too early for specific details. Temperatures at Fairfield- Travis Air Force Base reached 24 on the 20th, 26 on the 21st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably cold temperatures and frost caused potentially significant damage to the 2018 Central Valley almond crop harvest by happening during the sensitive blooming phase.
