(AgFax Tree Crops, Feb 26, 2018). ||Snow fell in the Sierra, with unusually cold temperatures allowing snow down into the Sierra foothills, to elevations as low as 1400 feet. This caused some travel slow downs and delays in areas that usually don't see accumulating snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Almond trees were in critical bloom and early nutlet stage during the freeze/frost event. Damage has been projected as significant, but it is too early for specific details. Temperatures at Beale Air Force Base and Marysville reached 24 on the 20th, 26 at Oroville Municipal Airport and 27 at Chico Municipal Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably cold temperatures and frost caused potentially significant damage to the 2018 Central Valley almond crop harvest by happening during the sensitive blooming phase. Temperatures in many locations reached or fell below the critical bloom temperature of 27. Some in the agricultural community were projecting frost damage ...worst since perhaps the 1970s. (AgFax Tree Crops, Feb 26, 2018). ||Snow fell in the Sierra, with unusually cold temperatures allowing snow down into the Sierra foothills, to elevations as low as 1400 feet. This caused some travel slow downs and delays in areas that usually don't see accumulating snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Almond trees were in critical bloom and early nutlet stage during the freeze/frost event. Damage has been projected as significant, but it is too early for specific details. Temperatures at Redding Municipal Airport reached 24 on the 19th, 26 on the 21st. Red Bluff Municipal Airport reached 26 on the 19th and the 21st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mountain snow continued into early March, with storm totals up to around 5 feet. There were also periods of heavy rain in the Central Valley and foothills.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Travel disruptions occurred from periods of heavy snow, with chain controls and slowdowns. Plumas County schools were closed. Lower Lassen Peak reported 28 of new snow on March 2, Quincy 5.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mountain snow continued into early March, with storm totals up to around 5 feet. There were also periods of heavy rain in the Central Valley and foothills.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 24 hour total rainfall was 1.60. Some wet snow mixed in at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mountain snow continued into early March, with storm totals up to around 5 feet. There were also periods of heavy rain in the Central Valley and foothills.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Major travel disruptions occurred from very heavy snow coupled with gusty winds. Whiteout conditions prompted the closure of a 70-mile stretch of I80 in both directions, from around noon to 3 pm on March 1. Highway 88 near the Kirkwood ski resort was also shut down for several hours. Caltrans road sensors also recorded significant delays and major slow downs on I80 on March 4th. Highway 50 and other mountain highways were also heavily impacted with chain controls and slowdowns. ||Caltrans reported the following 24 hour snow totals at Donner Summit (elevation 7,239 feet) on I80: 8 on March 1, 18 on March 2, 8 on March 3, 8 on March 4, for a storm total of 62. There was a storm total of 58 measured at Kingvale, elevation 6100 feet.||Accumulating snow was reported down into the lower Sierra, with a storm total of 13 at Camino (3100 feet).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure swept in from the west. It was accompanied by a plume of subtropical moisture and a weak Pacific cold front. Moderate rain began before day break on the 22nd and continued through most of the day in the Inland Empire and along the coastal slopes. Peak rain amounts were around 3 inches along the coastal slopes of the San Bernardino County Mountains. Rainfall was significantly lighter in San Diego County, with only a couple hundredths at San Diego International. Meanwhile gusty winds affected the mountains and deserts. Impact were minimal, with a few reports of flooded roadways in San Bernardino County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Southern California Logistics Airport in Victorville reported a peak wind gust of 58 mph. Peak gusts of 54 and 53 mph also occured at Apple Valley Airport and a mesonet station in Lucerne Valley.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad trough and weak Pacific cold front sweeped through the region late on the 2nd and into the 3rd. Rainfall was light with some impacts from snowfall in the mountains of Riverside and San Bernardino County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple locations in the San Bernardino County Mountains reported 1-3 inches of snow. Snow Valley had the highest total with 4-8 inches of new snow reported on the morning of the 4th. Chain controls were needed along Highways 18 and 38.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad trough and weak Pacific cold front sweeped through the region late on the 2nd and into the 3rd. Rainfall was light with some impacts from snowfall in the mountains of Riverside and San Bernardino County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several inches of snow resulted in chain controls along portions of Highways 74 and 243.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level system with a strong cold front moved through the Bay Area at the turn of the month with precipitation beginning late the evening of the 28th. This system brought widespread rainfall causing localized roadway flooding, strong winds, lightning, and small hail. Gusts in the mountains reached 60 mph and hail was seen up to 1/2 an inch. The bulk of the precipitation and subsequent impacts were seen in early March.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: News report states roughly 1200 customers around the Bay Area are without power.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a significant dry period of 45 straight dry days across most of the central California interior. A low pressure system pushed inland over northern California on November 21 and brought a period of generally light to moderate precipitation to the area from the afternoon of November 21 through the morning of November 22 as an associated cold front pushed southward through central California. The precipitation fell mainly in the form of snow above 7000 feet resulting in this system being the first significant winter storm of the season for the higher elevations of the Southern Sierra Nevada where 8 to 16 inches of snow fell. Much of the San Joaquin Valley picked up between a quarter to three quarters of an inch of an inch of rainfall after going totally dry for a month and a half. There were several reports of nuisance flooding although damage was minimal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hockett Meadows SNOTEL (8600 feet) picked up an estimated 8 inches of new snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of low pressure affected far southeast California on March 14. This low pressure system resulted in strong and gusty southwest to west winds across western Imperial for most of the day; peak wind gusts were in excess of 40 mph. A Wind Advisory was issued and was in effect for the afternoon and evening hours; areas affected included the Salton Sea and surrounding communities such as Salton City. The strong gusty winds were sufficient to flip over a big rig semi-truck driving about 1 mile northwest of Salton City. No injuries were reported but there was damage reported to both the semi-truck and the road.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty winds developed in the area around Salton Sea during the afternoon hours on March 14. The gusty winds were in advance of a large area of low pressure impacting the desert southwest. Wind gusts in excess of 40 mph were observed and a Wind Advisory was in effect for much of far southeast California including the Salton Sea. According to a public report, gusty winds flipped over a big rig driving about 1 mile northwest of the town of Salton City. CALTRANS and the California Highway Patrol confirmed the report and indicated that it was indeed wind related. No injuries were reported although there was some damage to both the semi-truck and the road.

This system brought widespread rainfall causing localized roadway flooding, strong winds, lightning, and small hail. Gusts in the mountains reached 60 mph and hail was seen up to 1/2 an inch. The bulk of the precipitation and subsequent impacts were seen in early March.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Accumulating hail reported in Kensington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave rounded the base of a longwave trough over the West Coast, passing over Northern California the morning of the 22nd, which brought snow to the eastern Sierra and northeastern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol stated that a GMC pickup driven by a male was heading south on US 395 near Green Creek Road when it lost control on the snow covered roadway and overturned into Virginia Creek. Authorities say both passengers were able to get out of the truck as it started to fill up with water. Fire crews cut the driver out of the truck, where he was transported to Mammoth Lakes Hospital by Mono County Paramedics. He was pronounced deceased at the hospital at approximately 0905PST 23 February. Troopers stated that icy roads may be to blame. Source of the report: Reno KTVN 2 News.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure swept in from the west. It was accompanied by a plume of subtropical moisture and a weak Pacific cold front. Moderate rain began before day break on the 22nd and continued through most of the day in the Inland Empire and along the coastal slopes. Peak rain amounts were around 3 inches along the coastal slopes of the San Bernardino County Mountains. Rainfall was significantly lighter in San Diego County, with only a couple hundredths at San Diego International. Meanwhile gusty winds affected the mountains and deserts. Impact were minimal, with a few reports of flooded roadways in San Bernardino County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple reports of roadway flooding were reported, including a road closure at a low water crossing and street flooding near Muscoy.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of short waves brought showers to northern California. A cold air mass was already in place, so snow fell at much lower elevations than normal for this time of year.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter 2 SSW Weed reported 8.0 inches of snow ending at 01/0700 PST. Most of the snow fell between 0000 and 0500 PST. A CoCoRaHs observer 5.1 NW Mount Shasta reported 24 hours snowfall totals of 14.0 inches on the morning of 03/01/18, followed by totals of 5.0 inches on 03/02/18 and 6.5 inches on 03/03/18. By that time the snow depth was 24 inches. There were travel delays on the highways due to snowy conditions and traffic accidents.

Low marine layer clouds brought dense fog into San Diego County the morning of September 22nd. The fog moved into the valley areas of San Diego County on the  between approximately 6 AM and 7 AM PST on the 22nd, and dropped visibility to nearly 500 ft at the NWS office. The fog began to clear after sunrise.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An NWS employee reported dense fog and visibility around 500 feet between 6 AM and 7 AM PST on the 22nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of storm systems with a subtropical moisture stream swept through the region between the 20th and 22nd of March. This subtropical moisture was also associated with an upper level trough and surface cold front. These systems resulted in minor roadway flooding and debris flows as well as downed trees and power outages due to gusty winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roadway flooding reported near Rohnert Park Expressway and Stony Point Road.

CZ_NAME: NORTHERN SALINAS VALLEY / HOLLISTER VALLEY / CARMEL VALLEY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of storm systems with a subtropical moisture stream swept through the region between the 20th and 22nd of March. This subtropical moisture was also associated with an upper level trough and surface cold front. These systems resulted in minor roadway flooding and debris flows as well as downed trees and power outages due to gusty winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gusty winds blew through portions of Monterey County causing local power outages in North Salinas, Marina, and Fort Ord. At the peak, nearly 4,000 people were without power. Gusty winds went through the Santa Clara Valley as well,  including Hollister gusting to 45 mph https://www.thecalifornian.com/story/news/2018/03/20/more-than-3-000-residents-north-salinas-without-power/444246002/.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter 1 WSW Mount Shasta City reported 6.0 inches of snow during this interval.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of short waves moving through over a cold air mass brought heavy low elevation snow to parts of northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter at Tennant reported 8 inches of snow in 24 hours ending at 24/0839 PST. Another 4 inches of snow accumulated overnight, ending at 25/0729 PST.  The total on the ground by that time was 16 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge and light winds resulted in dense fog in northern San Diego County the morning of September 17th. Visibility of less than 1/4 SM was reported at Carlsbad Airport and Camp Pendleton from 3 AM - 6 AM PST.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Carlsbad Airport ASOS reported less than 1/4 SM visibility between 3 AM and 5 AM PST. Also, Camp Pendleton reported visibility less than 1/4 SM between 4 AM and 6 AM PST.

CZ_NAME: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS EXCLUDING THE SANTA MONICA RANGE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter storm impacted Southwestern California in early January. This storm generated heavy rainfall with totals ranging from 1-4 inches across the coasts and valleys with up to 7 inches over some foothill and mountain areas. At times, the rainfall was very intense, generating mud and debris including a deadly mud and debris flow in the community of Montecito. In the mountains, significant snowfall occurred at the resort level with over 6 inches of snow accumulation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter storm impacted the mountains of Los Angeles county. At Mountain High Ski Resort, 6 to 8 inches of snowfall was reported around 7000 foot elevation. Additionally, southerly winds, gusting to 50 MPH, were reported.

In the mountains, significant snowfall occurred at the resort level with over 6 inches of snow accumulation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter storm impacted the mountains of Ventura county. At around 7000 foot elevation, 6 to 8 inches of snowfall was reported along with southerly winds, gusting to 50 MPH.

CZ_NAME: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS EXCLUDING THE SANTA MONICA RANGE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong surface high pressure over the Great Basin generated strong Santa Ana winds across the mountains of Ventura and Los Angeles counties. North to northeast winds, gusting up to 70 MPH, were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong Santa Ana winds impacted the inland mountains of Los Angeles county. Some peak wind gusts from local RAWS include: Camp Nine (gusts to 70 MPH) and Mill Creek (gusts to 58 MPH).

These systems resulted in minor roadway flooding and debris flows as well as downed trees and power outages due to gusty winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Beginning at 5:30 AM PDT the stream gauge at Laguna de Santa Rosa at Stony Point Road was in flood stage.  The gauge dropped below flood state at 12:30 PM PDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter storm impacted Southwestern California in early January. This storm generated heavy rainfall with totals ranging from 1-4 inches across the coasts and valleys with up to 7 inches over some foothill and mountain areas. At times, the rainfall was very intense, generating mud and debris including a deadly mud and debris flow in the community of Montecito. In the mountains, significant snowfall occurred at the resort level with over 6 inches of snow accumulation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Due to heavy rain, a significant mud and debris flow closed the Pacific Coast Highway around the intersection of Topanga Canyon Boulevard. Over three feet of mud was reported across the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong surface high pressure over the Great Basin generated strong Santa Ana winds across the mountains of Ventura and Los Angeles counties. North to northeast winds, gusting up to 70 MPH, were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong Santa Ana winds impacted the mountains of Ventura county. Wind gusts up to 70 MPH were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong surface high pressure over the Great Basin generated strong Santa Ana winds across the mountains of Ventura and Los Angeles counties. North to northeast winds, gusting up to 70 MPH, were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong Santa Ana winds impacted the Santa Monica Mountains in Los Angeles county. The RAWS sensor at Malibu Hills reported northerly winds, gusting to 60 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold air associated with a series of upper-level troughs yielded high elevation snow, as well as small hail along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter measured 3 inches of snow at an elevation of 3750 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold air associated with a series of upper-level troughs yielded high elevation snow, as well as small hail along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter estimated 1 inch of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold air associated with a series of upper-level troughs yielded high elevation snow, as well as small hail along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six inches of storm total snow reported at an elevation of 3750 feet.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snow of 4 inches at an elevation of 3750 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low pressure system crossed Northern California on April 19. This system was moisture deficient and produced only scattered light showers. However, it did produce strong winds in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts. Several locations measured wind gusts above 45 mph while gusts above 60 mph were reported in the Mojave area. A tractor trailer was blown over at the intersection of SR 58 and SR 14 north of Mojave which was closed for a few hours during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jawbone Canyon RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 70 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported road closure of SR 58 at exit 165 north of Mojave due to strong wind gusts. A tractor trailer was blown over. The Mojave Airport AWOS reported a peak wind gusts of 60 mph at that time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure brought dry conditions and much above normal temperatures to the area between April 21 and April 26. Some all time record highs were broken across the area on the 23rd and 24th. An upper trough then pushed into the Pacific Northwest on April 27 with several impulses associated with this system crossing Northern California on the April 28 through April 30 bringing much cooler temperatures and increased winds to the area. On the evening of the 29th through the early morning of the 30th, strong wind gusts impacted the Kern County Mountains and Deserts where there were several reports of wind gusts exceeding 60 mph. A tractor trailer was blown over on its side near Mojave forcing another shutdown of SR 58. The strong winds finally subsided by the morning of April 30.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bird Springs Pass RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 80 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level storm system impacted the Pacific Northwest during the first week of April. This storm system, combined with moist westerly flow encountering the coastal mountains, resulted in heavy rainfall over Northwest California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rock and mudslides reported by law enforcement. Estimated storm total rainfall was 4 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level storm system impacted the Pacific Northwest during the first week of April. This storm system, combined with moist westerly flow encountering the coastal mountains, resulted in heavy rainfall over Northwest California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated 2.5 inches of rain. Report of water over roadway with numerous vehicles hydroplaning.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused a sink hole to form, which partially swallowed a car resulting in one injury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A relatively fast moving shortwave trough dug south over the northeastern Pacific the 9th and progressed across the Sierra Nevada the 10th through the 12th. This weather system brought high winds and light snow to the Sierra Nevada and Eastern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station JDPC1, 9 miles northwest of Frenchman Lake (elevation 6812 feet) reported a wind gust of 64 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A relatively fast moving shortwave trough dug south over the northeastern Pacific the 9th and progressed across the Sierra Nevada the 10th through the 12th. This weather system brought high winds and light snow to the Sierra Nevada and Eastern California.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: April 2018 began with high pressure over the region which kept a dry airmass and much warmer than normal temperatures over the area. An upper trough off the Pacific Northwest coast pulled a deep plume of tropical moisture northward and brought periods of moderate to heavy precipitation to the area from the late evening of April 6 through the afternoon of April 7. This system was unusually warm for early April and snow levels were above 11000 feet for most of the duration of this event. Several stations over the higher elevations of the Southern Sierra Nevada measured between 2 and 3 inches of rain which resulted in accelerated snow melt and rapid runoff into the rivers over the higher elevations. River flooding was reported along the Merced River above New Exchequer Dam and several roads in Yosemite National Park were closed as a result. In addition there were reports of minor roadway flooding and rock slides in the Southern Sierra Foothills near Mariposa and over the higher Sierras south of Yosemite Park. Flooding was also reported in the Merced area and near Livingston during the morning of April 7. This storm also produced strong wind gusts over the Kern County Mountains and Deserts with several indicator sites reporting wind gusts above 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported the intersection of Liberty Ave. and Cressley Way was completely flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season deep upper level trough moved southward along the California coast bringing rain and gusty winds to the region. Scattered convection was produced in the wake of an associated cold front bringing widespread small hail, thunder, and lightning to the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Media reported that a private jet was struck by lightning 5 miles west of Mineta San Jose International Airport.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Merced River at Pohono Bridge exceeded it's food state of 10 feet between the morning of April 7 and the afternoon of April 8. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure returned to the area on April 8 and kept dry conditions through the morning of the 10th. A weak low pressure system pushed through Central California during the afternoon and evening of the 10th and brought a few light showers as well as much cooler temperatures. Another low pressure system moved through Central California on the evening of April 11 through the morning of April 12. This system produced strong wind gusts across the Kern County Mountains and Deserts where several stations reported wind gusts exceeding 58 mph. In addition, several reporting station in the San Joaquin Valley had gusts exceeding 40 mph. Although this system was moisture deficient, showers produced some light precipitation during the morning of April 12 mainly over the Southern Sierra Nevada with light snowfall being observed above 7000 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bear Peak RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 63 mph.

In addition, several reporting station in the San Joaquin Valley had gusts exceeding 40 mph. Although this system was moisture deficient, showers produced some light precipitation during the morning of April 12 mainly over the Southern Sierra Nevada with light snowfall being observed above 7000 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bird Springs Pass RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 72 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season deep upper level trough moved southward along the California coast bringing rain and gusty winds to the region. Scattered convection was produced in the wake of an associated cold front bringing widespread small hail, thunder, and lightning to the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Social media video showing small hail in Pacific Grove.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Pacific storm system brought a short period of severe downslope winds to the Owens Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak gust was measured 4 miles NW of Independence.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another in a series of potent Pacific storms brought high winds to the Owens Valley and Mojave Desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak gust occurred 5 miles NW of Independence. Highway 395 was closed to high profile vehicles after a few nearly blew over.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another in a series of potent Pacific storms brought high winds to the Owens Valley and Mojave Desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust occurred 5 miles NW of Independence.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another in a series of potent Pacific storms brought high winds to the Owens Valley and Mojave Desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: These gusts occurred 3 miles NNW of Joshua Tree.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak trough passed through the Pacific Northwest, bringing gusty winds to the desert slopes in Southern California from the 6th through the 7th. There were no significant impacts reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusted over 60 mph in Burns Canyon over a 3 hour period. Winds were lighter in the rest of the San Bernardino County Mountains.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An incoming front brought high winds to isolated locations in northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Timber Mountain RAWS recorded a gust to 59 mph at 11/1203 PST, and gusts to 58 mph at 11/1303 PST and 11/1403 PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An incoming front brought high winds to isolated locations in northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rush Creek RAWS recorded a gust to 58 mph at 15/1303 PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A relatively fast moving shortwave trough dug south over the northeastern Pacific the 9th and progressed across the Sierra Nevada the 10th through the 12th. This weather system brought high winds and light snow to the Sierra Nevada and Eastern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station TT416, 3 miles south-southeast of Conway Summit (elevation 7032 feet) reported a wind gust of 64 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak gust occurred 5 miles NW of Independence.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak trough passed through the Pacific Northwest, bringing gusty winds to the desert slopes in Southern California from the 6th through the 7th. There were no significant impacts reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gusts of over 60 mph reported at the Whitewater Mesonet station for about 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak trough from the Pacific Northwest progressed through Southern California on the 11th and 12th, bringing gusty winds to the Coachella Valley, San Bernardino County Mountains, and San Diego County Deserts. Palm Springs Airport diverted 4 planes early on the 12th due to wind shear on final approach. The opening of the Coachella Festival was delayed due to wind. California Highway Patrol reported a palm tree down in the road, as well as power lines down and power outages in the Coachella Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Palm Springs Airport ASOS reported a gust of 51 mph around 1800 PST on the 12th. Earlier that day, 4 planes were diverted from PSP due to wind shear on final approach. Numerous power outages were reported in Palm Springs, as well as downed trees and power lines.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 52 mph wind gust reported at Means Lake, along with minor tree damage in Lucerne Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mountain wave activity resulted wind gusts over 70 mph for 5 hours with a peak gust of 84 mph in Burns Canyon. Winds were briefly sustained as high as 55 mph at the site. Winds were significantly lighter in the rest of the zone.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A relatively fast moving shortwave trough dug south over the northeastern Pacific the 9th and progressed across the Sierra Nevada the 10th through the 12th. This weather system brought high winds and light snow to the Sierra Nevada and Eastern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station WMSRS, White Mountain Peak (elevation 14246 feet) reported a wind gust of 122 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving spring storm moved into the Sierra Nevada late on the 15th and passed to the east late on the 16th. Gusty winds developed during the early morning hours of the 15th. The cold front associated with the system passed on the night of the 15th causing snow levels to rapidly fall. However, only light snow totals were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station JDPC1, 9 miles northwest of Frenchman Lake (elevation 6812 feet) reported a 58 mph wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak trough from the Pacific Northwest progressed through Southern California on the 11th and 12th, bringing gusty winds to the Coachella Valley, San Bernardino County Mountains, and San Diego County Deserts. Palm Springs Airport diverted 4 planes early on the 12th due to wind shear on final approach. The opening of the Coachella Festival was delayed due to wind. California Highway Patrol reported a palm tree down in the road, as well as power lines down and power outages in the Coachella Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts of 69 mph were reported at Whitewater RAWS, with a gust of 59 mph also reported in Sky Valley between 0650 and 0850 PST. Indian Canyon Drive was closed to all traffic for 7 hours between Garnett Ave. and West Tramview Rd. due to high winds and blowing sand. High winds caused a tractor-trailer to flip on its side at San Rafael Drive and Indian Canyon Drive. All restaurants and gas stations were closed at Indian Canyon Drive and I-10 on the 12th. High winds downed 2 power poles in North Palm Springs. Numerous power outages occured in the vicinity of Indian Canyon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure from the Pacific Northwest brought strong onshore winds to Southern California on the 16th and 17th. Workers at the Coachella Valley Festival were evacuated for a period of time due to high winds and blowing sand. A tractor-trailer flipped in Palm Springs.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts over 45 mph impacted the Coachella Mesonet from 1200 to 2300 PST, with a peak wind gust of 58 mph at 1800 PST. Visibility was down to 1/2 mile in some parts of the Coachella Valley. Workers at the Coachella Valley Festival were evacuated on the evening of the 16th due to high winds and blowing sand.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure from the Pacific Northwest brought strong onshore winds to Southern California on the 16th and 17th. Workers at the Coachella Valley Festival were evacuated for a period of time due to high winds and blowing sand. A tractor-trailer flipped in Palm Springs.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were over 50 mph from 0800 to 2300 PST, with a peak wind gust of 67 mph at Whitewater RAWS at 1600 PST. Surrounding areas had peak wind gusts of around 40 mph. A big rig was blown over at Palm Dr. and Varner Rd. High winds blew a trailer off of a vehicle on Highway 111.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts at Big Bear City Airport were over 35 mph from 1000 to 1600 PST, with a peak wind gust of 48 mph at 1230 PST. Heaps Peak and Running Springs had peak wind gusts of 55 mph around 1400 PST. No significant impacts reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts of over 40 mph occured at Apple Valley Airport between 1000 and 1800 PST, with a peak gust of 52 mph at 1300 PST. Lucerne Valley reported a peak wind gust of 53 mph around 1900 PST. Multiple power lines were downed in the area, resulting in power outages, 3 large trees were damaged in Hesperia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure from the Pacific Northwest brought gusty onshore winds to Southern California on the 18th and 19th. The Coachella Fesitval campsite delayed opening from the 19th to the early morning hours on the 20th due to high winds and blowing sand.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Victorville Airport reported a peak wind gust of 48 mph around 1500 PST on the 19th. No significant impacts reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Volcan Mountain reported a peak wind gust of 64 mph around 0600 PST. Harrison Park reported a peak wind gust of 63 mph around 0700 PST. Boulevard West Mesonet reported a peak gust of 62 mph. No significant impacts reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure from the Pacific Northwest brought gusty onshore winds to Southern California on the 18th and 19th. The Coachella Fesitval campsite delayed opening from the 19th to the early morning hours on the 20th due to high winds and blowing sand.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts at Borrego Springs were greater than 40 mph from 1100 to 1500 PST, with a peak gust of 49 mph at 1330 PST. No significant impacts reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure from the Pacific Northwest brought gusty onshore winds to Southern California on the 18th and 19th. The Coachella Fesitval campsite delayed opening from the 19th to the early morning hours on the 20th due to high winds and blowing sand.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Whitewater RAWS reported a maximum sustained wind of 49 mph at 1150 PST on the 19th. The maximum gust in that time period was 63 mph. California Highway Patrol reported issues using medical aircraft to respond to an auto accident in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure from the Pacific Northwest brought gusty onshore winds to Southern California on the 18th and 19th. The Coachella Fesitval campsite delayed opening from the 19th to the early morning hours on the 20th due to high winds and blowing sand.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts for Palm Springs Airport were over 40 mph from 1800 to 2000 PST, with a peak gust of 56 mph and a sustained wind of 39 mph at 1815 PST. Surrounding areas reported wind gusts of around 30 mph. The campsite at the Coachella Valley Festival delayed opening until the 20th at 0200 PST due to high winds and blowing sand, leaving tourists stranded until the campsite opened.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of short waves training over Modoc County led to localized areas of heavy snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter 1S Adin reported 9.0 inches of snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold upper level trough moved through California on April 16 bringing light precipitation to Central California by early morning. A cold and very unstable airmass pushed into the area by the early afternoon hours. As a result, showers and thunderstorms developed over the San Joaquin Valley and Southern Sierra Foothills. Due to the showery nature of the precipitation, rainfall amounts varied; but generally ranged from a tenth of an inch to half an inch of rain in these areas. There were several reports of small hail and brief heavy rainfall. Higher elevations in the Southern Sierra Nevada picked up between 4 and 8 inches of new snowfall although portions of Yosemite National Park did pick up a bit more with Tuolumne Meadows measuring 14 inches of snow snowfall. Up to an inch of snow fell over the Kern County Mountains above 5000 feet while a few indicator sites measured brief wind gusts above 60 mph. The trough moved east of the area by the morning of April 17 with drier air building in behind it.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter report of 0.65 inches of rainfall in a five hour period. Most of the rain was from an afternoon thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low pressure system crossed Northern California on April 19. This system was moisture deficient and produced only scattered light showers. However, it did produce strong winds in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts. Several locations measured wind gusts above 45 mph while gusts above 60 mph were reported in the Mojave area. A tractor trailer was blown over at the intersection of SR 58 and SR 14 north of Mojave which was closed for a few hours during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bird Springs Pass RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 75 mph.

CZ_NAME: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS EXCLUDING THE SANTA MONICA RANGE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Stone wildfire ignited in the mountains of Los Angeles county. The fire burned 1,352 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Stone Fire burned 1,352 acres in the mountains of Los Angeles county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In mid-October, strong and gusty Santa Ana winds developed across Southern California. In the mountains of Ventura and Los Angeles counties, north to northeast wind gusts up to 66 MPH were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong north to northeast winds developed across the Santa Monica mountains. Some measured wind gusts from local RAWS stations included 66 MPH at Boney Mountain and 62 MPH at South Mountain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In mid-October, strong and gusty Santa Ana winds developed across Southern California. In the mountains of Ventura and Los Angeles counties, north to northeast wind gusts up to 66 MPH were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong north to northeast winds developed across the Ventura county mountains. Automated sensors in the area reported wind gusts in excess of 60 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure aloft brought dry conditions and extreme temperatures to the Coachella Valley and San Diego County Deserts. Temperatures reached 112 in Palm Springs and 113 in Ocotillo Wells on June 13.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The San Diego County Deserts experienced extreme high temperatures on June 12 and 13 as high pressure aloft brought dry and hot temperatures to the region. Ocotillo Wells recorded a temperature of 109 on the 12th and 113 on the 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure aloft brought dry conditions and extreme temperatures to the Coachella Valley and San Diego County Deserts. Temperatures reached 112 in Palm Springs and 113 in Ocotillo Wells on June 13.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Coachella Valley experienced extreme high temperatures due to a high pressure aloft bringing dry and warm conditions to the region. Palm Springs recorded a temperature of 112 on June 13 and 14. Overnight lows were in the mid-80s in the Coachella Valley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A heatwave impacted the Coachella Valley and San Diego County deserts on June 21-22 due to high pressure aloft bringing in dry and hot conditions to those areas. Temperatures in the Coachella Valley reached between 114 and 116 and temperatures in the San Diego County Deserts reached 114-115 on June 22. One person died in Ocotillo Wells Recreational State Park due to heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme temperatures were recorded in the Coachella Valley on June 21 and 22 as high pressure aloft brought dry and hot temperatures into the region. On June 22, Palm Springs recorded a high temperature of 116 and Thermal recorded a high temperature of 114.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A heatwave impacted the Coachella Valley and San Diego County deserts on June 21-22 due to high pressure aloft bringing in dry and hot conditions to those areas. Temperatures in the Coachella Valley reached between 114 and 116 and temperatures in the San Diego County Deserts reached 114-115 on June 22. One person died in Ocotillo Wells Recreational State Park due to heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme temperatures were observed in the San Diego County deserts as high pressure aloft brought hot and dry conditions to the area. Borrego Springs recorded a high temperature of 114 and Ocotillo Wells reported a high temperature of 115 on June 22. An emergency official reported that one person died in Ocotillo Wells Recreational State Park due to a heat-related illness.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Hill Fire started in early November during a strong Santa Ana wind event. The combination of gusty winds and very dry conditions allowed the fire to grow quickly, eventually charring 4,531 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hill Fire burned 4,531 acres in Ventura county, near the community of Camarillo. The fire started during a strong Santa Ana wind event. Northeast winds gusting in excess of 60 MPH along with very dry conditions allowed the fire to spread very quickly. During the fire, four structures were destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and wet atmospheric river approached the west coast of the CONUS on the 5th, which brought gusty winds and significant rains to the Sierra and eastern California the 6th through the 7th. Rainfall totals during this event ranged from 1 to 2 inches in much of northeast California and the lower elevations of the northern Sierra. In the higher elevations, up to 4 inches of rain was reported. In Mono County, liquid totals were mainly less than two-thirds of an inch in the valleys, but the higher elevations of the Sierra saw from 1.50 inches to as much as 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station ECOC1, Echo Peak (elevation 7652 feet) reported 4.40 inches of rainfall in a 24 hour period from 6 April 0900PST to 7 April 0900PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Woolsey Fire burned 96,949 acres in Ventura and Los Angeles counties, destroying over 1500 structures. The fire ignited during a strong Santa Ana wind event and the combination of gusty winds and very dry conditions allowed the fire to spread very quickly.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Woolsey Fire burned 96,949 across in Ventura and Los Angeles county. The fire ignited during a strong Santa Ana wind event. Gusty north to northeast winds (in excess of 60 MPH) and very dry conditions allowed the fire to spread very quickly. In total, the Woolsey Fire destroyed 1,643 structures (including 400 homes) and damaged an additional 364 structures. Three deaths were attributed to the fire. Two deaths occurred when an SUV was overrun by flames and the third death occurred in a destroyed home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty Santa Ana winds buffeted the mountains of Los Angeles county, including the Santa Monica mountains. North to northeast wind gusts up to 72 MPH were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong Santa Ana winds developed across the Los Angeles county mountains. Peak wind gusts reported by the local RAWS network including gusts up to 62 MPH at Oat Mountain and gusts up to 60 MPH at Warm Springs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There was widespread unseasonable heat across the Central Valley over a period of 3 days, with triple digit high temperatures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonable heat, low humidity, and very dry fuels created critical conditions for wildfire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Apple Fire in Tehama County (Off Apple Rd & Paskenta Rd, west of Corning), burned 2,956 acres with 3 residential structures and 2 outbuilding destroyed. The fire was contained by June 14.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and Dry Conditions Northern California Wildfires, June 9-21, 2018.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pawnee Fire in Lake County (Pawnee Rd & New Long Valley Rd, northeast of Clearlake Oaks), burned 15,185 acres with 22 structures destroyed and 1 injury. The fire was contained by July 8.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonable heat, low humidity, and very dry fuels created critical conditions for wildfire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The County Fire in Yolo and Napa counties (east of Lake Beryessa), burned 90,288 acres with 20 structures destroyed and 1 injury. The fire was started by an improperly installed electric livestock fence unit. The fire was contained on July 17.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms developed on this date, beginning in the early morning and continuing into the evening.  At least one thunderstorm dropped large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter in Tennant reported hail ranging from 1/2 inch to 1.0 inch in diameter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoonal moisture combined with surface heating and a weak upper level trigger allowed thunderstorms to develop on this day.  One of them generated severe hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter 4SW of Weed reported 1 drifts of mainly 1/2 inch diameter hail.  Maximum hail size was 1 inch.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure coupled with very dry air brought very hot temperatures to the area during this interval.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Low temperatures in this zone ranged from 53 to 67 degrees and high temperatures ranged from 90 to 105 degrees during this interval.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long-period Southern Hemisphere swell arrived in Southern California on June 9 and brought high surf and strong rip currents to Orange and San Diego County beaches. An unconscious swimmer was rescued in La Jolla from a rip current and transported to a local hospital. Lifeguards rescued hundreds of people from the water during this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lifeguards reported 4-7 ft surf on Huntington and Newport beaches. 6-8 ft surf was reported at Laguna Beach. 8-12 ft surf reported at The Wedge. Orange County lifeguards stated they had hundreds of water rescues during this event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long-period Southern Hemisphere swell arrived in Southern California on June 9 and brought high surf and strong rip currents to Orange and San Diego County beaches. An unconscious swimmer was rescued in La Jolla from a rip current and transported to a local hospital. Lifeguards rescued hundreds of people from the water during this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reports of 5-7 ft surf at Northern San Diego County Beaches and 3-5 ft surf reported at Southern San Diego County Beaches. Lower Trestles had surf of 5-8 ft. Two surfers rescued an unconscious swimmer off the coast of La Jolla. The swimmer had a pulse once rescued and was transported to a local hospital.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure aloft brought in dry and hot conditions to the deserts from June 3rd through 5th. Extreme heat was observed in the Coachella Valley and San Diego County Deserts, and one person died from a heat-related illness.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High pressure aloft brought in dry conditions and extreme temperatures to the Coachella Valley on June 3-5. Temperatures reached 113 in Palm Springs and Thermal on the 3rd and 4th, and decreased to 104 on the 5th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure aloft brought in dry and hot conditions to the deserts from June 3rd through 5th. Extreme heat was observed in the Coachella Valley and San Diego County Deserts, and one person died from a heat-related illness.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High pressure aloft brought in dry conditions and extreme temperatures to the San Diego County deserts from June 3-5. Ocotillo Wells reported temperatures of 111 on June 3 and 110 on June 4. One man died on June 4th from a heat-related illness.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There was widespread unseasonable heat across the Central Valley over a period of 3 days, with triple digit high temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The NWS Experimental HeatRisk reached High readings that prompted a heat warning  for the southern Sacramento Valley. PG&E activated their Emergency Operations Center in support of the June Heat Event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There was widespread unseasonable heat across the Central Valley over a period of 3 days, with triple digit high temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The NWS Experimental HeatRisk reached High readings that prompted a heat warning  for the northern San Joaquin Valley. PG&E activated their Emergency Operations Center in support of the June Heat Event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fire broke out at the Torres Martinez Desert Cahuilla Reservation in the Coachella Valley on June 23rd. Seven homes were destroyed and the fire affected 30 tribal members in total. Members were displaced from their homes and lost all of their possessions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Martinez Fire broke out around 1400 PST on June 23rd. Dry conditions and temperatures in the 120s helped exasperate the fire. Seven homes were destroyed. Approximately 30 tribal members were displaced from their homes and lost nearly all of their possessions. Three firefighters suffered minor injuries in the blaze.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several inches of snow fell in the Sierra, causing minor travel delays.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Accumulating snow fell over the northern Sierra, causing minor travel delays at pass levels. Caltrans reported 5 of snow at their Kingvale Maintenance Yard. Squaw-Alpine Ski Resort and Northstar Ski Resort had 6 of snow, 5 was measured at Tahoe Donner and at Sugar Bowl.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Up to a foot of snow fell in the mountains, with light accumulations down to elevations around 3100 feet, with some wet snow reported as low as 2500 feet. This snow caused some travel difficulties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A member of the public reported a brief funnel cloud between Orland and Hamilton City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Up to a foot of snow fell in the mountains, with light accumulations down to elevations around 3100 feet, with some wet snow reported as low as 2500 feet. This snow caused some travel difficulties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Caltrans reported a 24 hour total of 11 of new snow at Kingvale Maintenance Yard. Chain controls and slowdowns were reported on mountain portions of I80 and Highway 50. Bear Valley Ski Resort measured 8 of snow. A spotter at Camino at 3120 feet measured 3 of new snow over 24 hours. A spotter reported some wet snow falling at 2500 feet, with no accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure strengthened over the region on July 17 resulting a long stretch of days with 100 degree and warmer days across the San Joaquin Valley and the Kern County Deserts. The high strengthened over California on July 24. This resulted in several days of excessive heat over the Kern County Deserts where and Excessive Heat Warning was issued for a five day period, and a significant heat wave persisted across the San Joaquin Valley where emergency cooling centers were opened each afternoon in several municipalities between July 24 and July 28. Heat Advisories were posted for the San Joaquin Valley as well as for the lower elevations of the southern Sierra foothills and Kern County Mountains during this period. The high finally weakened on July 29 and 30 which allowed for temperatures to finally cool down closer to normal levels. The month turned out to be the warmest July on record for Fresno and the second warmest on record for Bakersfield.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 102 and 108 degrees at most locations between July 24 and July 28.

CZ_NAME: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS EXCLUDING THE SANTA MONICA RANGE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In mid-October, strong and gusty Santa Ana winds developed across Southern California. In the mountains of Ventura and Los Angeles counties, north to northeast wind gusts up to 66 MPH were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong north to northeast winds developed across the Los Angeles county mountains. The RAWS sensor at Camp Nine reported a wind gust of 66 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty Santa Ana winds buffeted the mountains of Los Angeles county, including the Santa Monica mountains. North to northeast wind gusts up to 72 MPH were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong Santa Ana winds developed across the Santa Monica Mountains. Peak wind gusts reported by the local RAWS network including gusts up to 72 MPH at South Mountain and gusts up to 67 MPH at Boney Mountain.

CZ_NAME: LOS ANGELES COUNTY COASTS INCLUDING DOWNTOWN LOS ANGELES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Woolsey Fire burned 96,949 acres in Ventura and Los Angeles counties, destroying over 1500 structures. The fire ignited during a strong Santa Ana wind event and the combination of gusty winds and very dry conditions allowed the fire to spread very quickly.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Woolsey Fire burned 96,949 across in Ventura and Los Angeles county. The fire ignited during a strong Santa Ana wind event. Gusty north to northeast winds (in excess of 60 MPH) and very dry conditions allowed the fire to spread very quickly. In total, the Woolsey Fire destroyed 1,643 structures (including 400 homes) and damaged an additional 364 structures. Three deaths were attributed to the fire. Two deaths occurred when an SUV was overrun by flames and the third death occurred in a destroyed home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow brought travel delays in the mountains, with nearly 4 feet of snow at and above pass levels. Heavy rain brought ash flows and debris flows over some recently burned areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow impacted mountain travel over Sierra passes, with snow totals of nearly 4 feet. Caltrans reported a storm total of 46 of snow measured by Castle Peak along I-80. Kirkwood Ski Resort reported 46, Squaw Alpine 45, Bear Valley 25, Kyburz had 10, with 1 down to Camino, elevation 3100'.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow brought travel delays in the mountains, with nearly 4 feet of snow at and above pass levels. Heavy rain brought ash flows and debris flows over some recently burned areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding caused traffic delays and one hour of road closures on northbound and southbound Highway 99 from Neal Road to Estates Drive in Chico. Sheetflow was reported from heavy rain off of recently burned areas from the Camp Fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow brought travel delays in the mountains, with nearly 4 feet of snow at and above pass levels. Heavy rain brought ash flows and debris flows over some recently burned areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storms with heavy rain caused mudslides and debris flows on Highway 70 in the Pulga area. Debris flows clogged drains along the roadway. Trees along on roadway had to be removed. Highway 70 east of the West Branch of the Feather River was closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow brought travel delays in the mountains, with nearly 4 feet of snow at and above pass levels. Heavy rain brought ash flows and debris flows over some recently burned areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused sheet flow from the Camp Fire burn scar, which flooded Highway 99 near Neal Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow brought travel delays in the mountains, with nearly 4 feet of snow at and above pass levels. Heavy rain brought ash flows and debris flows over some recently burned areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow impacted mountain travel with delays and chain controls. There was 32 of snow reported at Lower Lassen Peak.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow brought travel delays in the mountains, with nearly 4 feet of snow at and above pass levels. Heavy rain brought ash flows and debris flows over some recently burned areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were 10 slides into drainage systems along SR70, withing the Camp Fire burned area. The Concow/Pulga area was still under a mandatory evacuation order due to the Camp Fire. An automated gage at Durham reported very heavy rain from 1-2 pm of 1.64 and a second hour between 2-3 pm of 1.80.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Natchez Wildfire was caused by lightning. The time of ignition was around 1830 PDT on 07/15/2018.  As of 0330 PDT on 08/01/18, the fire covered 6174 acres and was 15 percent contained.  0 structures were lost and 9.7 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Natchez Wildfire was caused by lightning. The time of ignition was around 1830 PDT on 07/15/2018.  As of 0330 PDT on 08/01/18, the fire covered 6174 acres and was 15 percent contained.  0 structures were lost and 9.7 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure coupled with very dry air brought very hot temperatures to the area during this interval.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Low temperatures in this zone ranged from 52 to 62 degrees and high temperatures ranged from 92 to 108 degrees during this interval.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Ferguson Fire started on July 13, 2018 at 2136 PDT in the South Fork Merced River drainage, 10 miles north of Mariposa, CA in Sierra National Forest. The cause of the fire is under investigation. The fire started in an area that has steep, rugged terrain with scarcely any road access and a heavy presence of beetle-killed trees.  On the morning of July 14, a heavy equipment operator was killed in a bulldozer rollover accident. The fire grew rapidly under hot and dry weather conditions. Strong inversions each day resulted in smoke issues in the fire area that limited aircraft operations. Smoke impacts from the fire spread throughout Yosemite National Park, the Sierra Nevada and foothill and into the San Joaquin Valley. Highway 140 leading into Yosemite National Park was closed on July 14 and remained closed through the end of July and into August. Smoke impacts in Yosemite resulted in dangerous air quality causing Yosemite Valley and most of the eastern part of the park to be closed to visitors on July 25. This closure continued into early August. Highway 41 leading into Yosemite from the south was also closed. Several communities just outside of Yosemite, including El Portal, Foresta, and the park employee housing at Rancheria Flat were subject to evacuations. From July 24 to 31, additional evacuations and repopulations of other areas continued to occur. On July 29,    another tragic accident occurred when a tree fell, hitting and killing a firefighter.  This fire continued to burn actively into August. By July 31, it had burned 57,041 acres and cost $64.3 Million.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Ferguson fire began July 13, 2018 and continued burning into August. Tragically, 2 firefighters were killed. A CalFire bulldozer operator died on July 14 when his dozer rolled off a sharp ridge. A hotshot from Sequoia/Kings Canyon National Park was killed when he was hit by a falling tree on July 29. One structure was destroyed and 57,041 acres had burned by July 31. The cost of containment was $64.3 Million as of July 31.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Klamathon Wildfire started on 07/05/18 at 0031 PDT by someone burning debris.   As of the last report at 22/0330 PST, the fire covered 38008 acres and was 100 percent contained.  33.5 million dollars had been expended on firefighting efforts. One death was reported and 82 structures were lost.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Klamathon Wildfire started on 07/05/18 at 0031 PDT by someone burning debris.   As of the last report at 22/0330 PST, the fire covered 38008 acres and was 100 percent contained.  33.5 million dollars had been expended on firefighting efforts. One death was reported and 82 structures were lost.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fire broke out near Lake Berryessa in Napa County on July 28th. Due to the fire being located in a densely populated area, evacuations were issued. The fire was contained on August 2nd after burning 135 acres, destroying 8 structures, and damaging 4.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Steele Fire began on July 28th and was contained on August 2nd. Eight structures were destroyed and 4 were damaged http://www.fire.ca.gov/current_incidents/incidentdetails/Index/2184.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Red Flag conditions exacerbated a fire sparked in Yolo County at the end of June that moved into Napa County in the beginning of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An improperly installed electric fence sparked a fire in Yolo County. Under Red Flag conditions the fire spread to Napa County on the morning of July 1st. The County Fire grew to 90,288 acres and destroyed 20 structures and caused 1 injury. Cal Fire incident information http://www.fire.ca.gov/current_incidents/incidentdetails/Index/2101.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A woman drowned on July 1st at Cowell Ranch Beach in Half Moon Bay due to a rip current.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A women drowned attempting to save three children swept out to the ocean by a rip current at Cowell Ranch Beach https://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2018/07/01/woman-dies-saving-children-from-rip-current/.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A downburst caused strong winds that damaged several homes in the Montague area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Montague Fire Department reported that three homes received minor to major damage from winds and falling branches.  A local weather station owned by a member of the public recorded a gust to 70 mph. Power lines were also taken out by the winds and falling branches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoonal moisture combined with surface heating and a weak upper level trigger allowed thunderstorms to develop on this day. One of them generated severe hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter 2SW MacDoel reported hail, most of which were nickel-sized, but a few were quarter-sized.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A southerly flow aloft brought some high level moisture into Central California on July 20. The moisture was sufficient enough for thunderstorms to develop over the higher elevations of the southern Sierra Nevada in the afternoon as the airmass became unstable with daytime heating. A few of the thunderstorms produced locally heavy rainfall over Yosemite National Park.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Overflowing water from a strong thunderstorm which produced heavy rain closed down a section of State Route 120 near Tuolumne Meadows. The duration of the flash flood was around one hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A southerly flow aloft brought some high level moisture into Central California on July 20. The moisture was sufficient enough for thunderstorms to develop over the higher elevations of the southern Sierra Nevada in the afternoon as the airmass became unstable with daytime heating. A few of the thunderstorms produced locally heavy rainfall over Yosemite National Park.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tuolumne Meadows received 0.98 inches of rainfall was measured in a one hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surge of upper level moisture combined with enough lift and instability during the afternoon of July 21 for widespread thunderstorm development to take place over the higher elevations of the southern Sierra Nevada. Brief heavy rainfall was observed with several of the thunderstorms and one storm produced flash flooding near Cedar Grove in Kings Canyon National Park.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported water and debris across Kings Canyon Road in several places between Lewis and Hotel Creeks in Cedar Grove.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure built into central California from the east on July 6 and brought a hot and dry airmass to the region which persisted through July 8. This produced a period of excessive heat across the Kern County deserts. The high weakened on July 9 resulting in a slight moderation of daytime temperatures in the desert areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 108 and 113 degrees at most locations between July 6 and July 8.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early heat wave resulted in people looking for relief from the heat by heading to local waterways.  Due to the time of year, creeks and rivers were running cold, high and fast due to the winter rains and snowmelt.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 21 year old man drowned when he jumped off an embankment in Ripon on the Stanislaus River, he went under and water and didn't come up.  The Stanislaus River, was running fast and cold from the winter rains and melting of snow in the mountains. His body was found by the Ripon Fire Department on May 10th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water flowed over a road at Havasu Landing on the Chemeheuvi reservation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed over the higher elevations of the Southern Sierra Nevada during the afternoon of May 21. A hiker on the cables of Half Dome in Yosemite National Park slipped and fell off of the cables during a thunderstorm while the surface was wet at around 330 pm PST. The nearest weather station reported 0.32 inches of rainfall between 300 pm PST and 400 pm PST.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report on Twitter that a hiker on the cables of Half Dome in Yosemite National Park slipped and fell off of the cables during a thunderstorm. The hiker was found dead from the fall the next day after a search and rescue was performed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a brief break, another push of monsoon moisture fueled another outbreak of thunderstorms across the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin. Many storms produced severe weather and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A lot of water flowed over Highway 168.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a brief break, another push of monsoon moisture fueled another outbreak of thunderstorms across the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin. Many storms produced severe weather and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two vehicles were stuck in a mud flow on Horseshoe Meadows Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture from Tropical Storm Rosa advanced into Southern California on September 30th and brought rain and thunderstorms to the region. The areas that experienced significant rainfall on the 30th were the San Bernardino Mountains and the Coachella Valley. One person was reported missing in the Coachella Valley during the same time period where heavy rainfall of 1.5-3.5 inches in 2 hours occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorms produced radar estimated 2 to 4 inches of rain in Box Canyon near I-10 within Box Canyon. The runoff destroyed a dike operated by Coachella Valley Water District. The moisture was associated with pre Tropical Cyclone Rosa. The thunderstorm produced prolific lightning in the area. Box Canyon had a flash flood which drains from the little San Bernardino mountains. The water eventually drains into the Salton Sea. A vehicle travelling on Box Canyon road was swept away in the flash flood and the driver drowned (within PHX area of responsibility).

CZ_NAME: NORTHEAST SISKIYOU AND NORTHWEST MODOC COUNTIES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clearing skies and a cold air mass allowed temperatures to drop below freezing over northeast California east of the Cascades.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 28 to 30 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large south swell progressed into Southern California on May 22nd and resulted in high surf late on the 22nd and into the 23rd. Highest surf was observed on the south facing beaches of Orange County. San Diego County beaches also observed elevated surf conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At Huntington Beach, high surf of 7-8 ft was reported. The Wedge reported 7-10 ft sets.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large south swell progressed into Southern California on May 22nd and resulted in high surf late on the 22nd and into the 23rd. Highest surf was observed on the south facing beaches of Orange County. San Diego County beaches also observed elevated surf conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mission Beach Lifeguards and Oceanside Pier reported 4-6 ft surf due to the south swell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Marine layer clouds brought drizzle and dense fog to the Cajon Pass on the morning of May 30th. Dense fog reduced visibilities on Interstate 15, and a 30-vehicle crash occurred on Interstate 15 South. 21 people were injured in this incident.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Foggy conditions attributed to a 30-vehicle crash on Interstate 15 near Oak Hill Road and Highway 138 interchange in the Cajon Pass. The crash occurred around 1030 PST when two vehicles became disabled in a collision south of Oak Hill Road. This resulted in a collision of crashes that stretched a mile long. The southbound lanes of Interstate 15 were closed until around 1330 PST. 20 people were injured in this incident.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clearing skies and a cold air mass allowed temperatures to drop below freezing over northeast California east of the Cascades.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported low temperatures ranged from 26 to 31 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A man working in a bucket truck was struck by lightning on this day.  He was around 20 feet above the ground next to a 45 foot tall tree when the tree was struck.  The lightning arced from the tree and hit him in the head and shoulder area.  He was severely injured, but survived.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A man working in a bucket truck was struck by lightning on this day.  He was around 20 feet above the ground next to a 45 foot tall tree when the tree was struck.  The lightning arced from the tree and hit him in the head and shoulder area.  He was severely injured, but survived.  The bolt that hit him was the only one recorded anywhere near that area at that time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper-level low moved into Southern California on May 1, which ushered in cold, northerly flow into the region. Wrap around, heavy snow occurred the morning of May 2nd in the San Bernardino Mountains. Estimated snowfall between 2-5 inches occurred, with snowfall rates as high as 1 inch per hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow fell in the San Bernardino Mountains in morning on May 2nd, producing 2 to 3 inches throughout the mountains, and up to 5 inches in Big Bear, Fawnskin and Snow Valley. Snowfall rates of up to 1 inch per hour occurred during some portions of the event. Chain controls were in effect in the San Bernardino Mountains.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low from the Pacific Northwest progressed into Southern California on May 12th and brought gusty winds to the High Desert. Observed wind gusts at George AFB, just east of Adelanto, peaked at 36 mph. One injury was reported in Adelanto.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observed wind gusts at George AFB of over 28 mph were observed between 1300 PST and 1600 PST on May 12th, with a peak wind gust of 36 mph at 1456 PST. A child was injured in a residential neighborhood in Adelanto around 1400 PST due to a bounce house being blown away onto traffic lanes of 395.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire ignited a few miles south of Winchester in Riverside County on May 17th. Lower relative humidity and wind speeds between 15-20 mph helped exasperate the fire. Evacuations were put in place for six homes near the fire, and one structure was destroyed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Patterson Fire ignited around 1 pm PST on May 17th. Six homes were evacuated around 1500 PST on Hidden Falls Road and Vista Road, and one unoccupied structure was destroyed in the fire. The fire rapidly grew to approximately 1,200 acres by 1830 PST on the 17th. Evacuations were lifted around 2100 PST on the 17th. The fire was contained around 1800 PST on May 18th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Natchez Wildfire was caused by lightning. The time of ignition was around 1830 PDT on 07/15/2018. As of 0330 PDT on 10/01/18, the fire covered 38134 acres and was 84 percent contained. 0 structures were lost and 43.7 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Natchez Wildfire was caused by lightning. The time of ignition was around 1830 PDT on 07/15/2018. As of 0330 PDT on 10/01/18, the fire covered 38134 acres and was 84 percent contained. 0 structures were lost and 43.7 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad area of upper level low pressure moved into the western part of the U.S. on the 16th and persisted through the 17th. Bands of moderate to heavy rain developed north of the main center of the low stretching across the northern Sierra and into far western Nevada on the 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station WRDC1, 2 miles south of Alpine Meadows (elevation 6764 feet) reported 0.60 inches of rainfall from 16 May 0600PST to 1400PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed over southern Mono County and produced heavy rainfall during the overnight hours of the 20th and 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained weather spotter reported 0.61 inches of rainfall from 20 May 2300PST to 21 May 0600PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper low moved south over southern Nevada and persisted in that area through much of the 22nd, which caused showers and thunderstorms to become widespread across western Nevada and the eastern Sierra.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station VGAC1, 3 miles west-southwest of Conway Summit reported 0.60 inches of rainfall from 20 May 2200PST to 21 May 1400PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system centered over southern Nevada provided for a shallow surge of mid-level moisture into central California On September 3 and 4. During the afternoon of the 4th, several thunderstorms developed over the higher elevations of the Southern Sierra Nevada from Yosemite National Park southward to the Lake Isabella area where the atmosphere was unstable. Heavy rainfall was produced by thunderstorms near Kings Canyon and near Lake Isabella which over an inch of rainfall between 100 pm PDT and 5 pm PDT. In addition, isolated thunderstorms brought some light rainfall to the southern Sierra foothills and to the Kern County Deserts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sugarloaf RAWS measured 1.10 inches of rainfall between 111 pm PDT and 511 pm PDT. More than half of the rain fell between 211 pm PDT and 311 pm PDT while a slow moving thunderstorm impacted the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system centered over southern Nevada provided for a shallow surge of mid-level moisture into central California On September 3 and 4. During the afternoon of the 4th, several thunderstorms developed over the higher elevations of the Southern Sierra Nevada from Yosemite National Park southward to the Lake Isabella area where the atmosphere was unstable. Heavy rainfall was produced by thunderstorms near Kings Canyon and near Lake Isabella which over an inch of rainfall between 100 pm PDT and 5 pm PDT. In addition, isolated thunderstorms brought some light rainfall to the southern Sierra foothills and to the Kern County Deserts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A slow moving thunderstorm produced 1.07 inches of rainfall at Lake Isabella between 330 pm PDT and 430 pm PDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The West Fire started on 7/06 in Alpine and quickly spread to over 400 acres in a few short hours. The cause of the fire is unknown. Extreme temperatures from high pressure aloft and low relative humidity helped to exasperate the fire. Evacuations were put into place, and approximately 50 structures were damaged or destroyed. One firefighter was injured. The fire was fully contained on 7/10.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The West Fire started around 1015 PST on 07/06 and quickly spread to 400 acres by 1600 PST. The fire started for unknown reasons alongside eastbound I-8 at West Willows Road in Alpine.  Extreme temperatures and low relative humidity helped exasperate the fire. Most of the Alpine community was evacuated from their homes. The fast-moving brush fire destroyed or damaged approximately 50 structures. One firefighter was injured while battling the blaze. In total, the fire burned 505 acres and was fully contained 7/10 around 1600 PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow brought travel delays in the mountains, with nearly 4 feet of snow at and above pass levels. Heavy rain brought ash flows and debris flows over some recently burned areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported at Honey Run Road and Horse Run Lane in Chico, due to local ponding of water and runoff from the Camp Fire burn scar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow brought travel delays in the mountains, with nearly 4 feet of snow at and above pass levels. Heavy rain brought ash flows and debris flows over some recently burned areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle was reported stuck in flood waters up to mirrors in about 3.5 feet of water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow brought travel delays in the mountains, with nearly 4 feet of snow at and above pass levels. Heavy rain brought ash flows and debris flows over some recently burned areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Butte County Sheriff's Office issued an evacuation order for Honey Run Road due to flooding, from the 200 block to Skyway including Horse Run Lane. Nearly 100 cars were trapped for at least an hour on Honey Run Road, as two separate debris flows and flooding blocked cars from evacuating safely. Officials from the Butte County Sheriffs Office confirmed the backup was up to two miles long. An automated gage at Durham reported very heavy rain from 1-2 pm of 1.64 and a second hour between 2-3 pm of 1.80.||Water rescuers were later called out to Honey Run Road in the lower area of Butte Creek Canyon after a white Jeep Cherokee was reported floating down Butte Creek. |The U.S. Army mobilized 19 high water vehicles to rescue the people who were trapped. Evacuation warnings were in place for the Hamlin Canyon and Lower Neal zones, and on the west side of the county at Hegan Lane south to Highway 162 to the Sacramento River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another low pressure system moved slowly from the central California coast to western Nevada on the 24th and 25th. This system produced two periods of showers and thunderstorms where rainfall totals were maximized across much of eastern California from Alpine County northward to Lassen County and western Nevada from Douglas County northward to the Oregon border. The first period occurred during the late afternoon and evening hours of the 24th, and the second occurred during the morning of the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: COOP observer measured 0.97 inches of rainfall in a 24-hour period from 24 May 0914PST to 25 May 0914PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure built over Central California on May 3 and kept warm temperatures, dry conditions and generally light winds over the area. However, an upper level low pressure system moved into the Pacific Northwest on May 10 then dropped into the Great Basin on May 11. This resulted in increased surface pressure gradients which produced strong winds over portions of the area during the afternoon of May 11. There were a few reports of minor wind damage in the San Joaquin Valley and some low impact indicator stations in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts reported winds gusts exceeding 70 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Indian Wells Canyon RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 84 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The last push of moisture in July triggered scattered thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert. Some storms produced severe weather and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water and debris flowed across Morning Star Mine Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Interaction between an upper trough over the Great Basin and an upper ridge off the California Coast resulted in increased surface pressure gradients over the area from the afternoon of May 17 to the morning of May 18 which in turn produced a period of increased winds over the Kern County Mountains and Deserts. Several reporting stations  reported wind gusts exceeding 45 mph during this time frame.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jawbone Canyon RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 64 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold upper trough moved across Central California on May 1. While it produced only light precipitation over the area during the morning, thunderstorms broke out during the afternoon in the cooler and unstable post-frontal airmass. Thunderstorms produced moderate to locally heavy rain across portions of the Southern Sierra Nevada and adjacent foothills as well as across the Kern County Deserts where up to six tenths of an inch of rain fell. Very little measurable fell over the San Joaquin Valley from this system as only a few stations reported a few hundredths of an inch of rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at North Edwards reported 0.37 inches of rain in 14 minutes from a brief heavy thunderstorm.

CZ_NAME: EAST BAY HILLS AND THE DIABLO RANGE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A system moving into northern Nevada created a strong pressure gradient across the higher elevations of the North and East Bay Hills. Wind gusts were observed over 40 mph across the area the evening of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured gust of 46 mph at Los Vaqueros RAWS.
