EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms on the eastern slopes of the southern Sierra led to large mud slides two days in a row.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large mud slides covered and closed Highway 168 near Aspendell, with about 50 people stranded. The highway was closed for several days.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms on the eastern slopes of the southern Sierra led to large mud slides two days in a row.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: More mud slides occurred across Highway 168 near Aspendell, essentially erasing progress made by crews cleaning up from the previous day's event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extended period of dry weather through the summer and fall with above normal temperatures coupled with a gusty north to northeast wind event created a situation for extremely rapid fire growth. A large wildfire developed, the deadliest and most destructive in history for California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Camp Fire began on the morning of November 8, 2018, by Camp Creek Road, near Pulga in Butte County. The fire was not fully contained until November 25. This fire was the most destructive wildfire in California history, destroying much of the city of Paradise, the community of Concow, and damaging the towns of Pulga and Magalia. There were 18,804 structures destroyed, 13,696 of them single homes, along with 514 commercial structures and 3,718 outbuildings and 153,336 acres burned. There were a total of 86 deaths from the fire, with 12 civilians and 5 firefighters injured. There were 3 people missing as of 1/24/2019, when Butte County Sheriff closed their missing persons call center for the Camp Fire. Damage costs to insured buildings has been estimated to be at least $10 billion. |Conditions which lead to this fire included several recent years with drought conditions, late spring rainfall bringing additional growth of grass for fuel, dry weather for seven months prior to the fire, very low humidity due to several north wind events, record dry fuel and gusty northeast winds the day of the fire. Local wind gusts to 40 to 50 mph were measured nearby at Jarbo Gap, with a peak gust in the early morning of 52 mph. These winds caused the fire to spread very quickly. The fire forced the rapid evacuation of over 27,000 people from Paradise, Magalia, Centerville, Concow, Pulga, Butte Creek Canyon, Berry Creek and Yankee Hill. The fire also threatened the communities of Butte Valley, Chico, Forest Ranch, Helltown, Inskip, Oroville, and Stirling City. All residents were not allowed to return home until December 15, when the final evacuation orders were lifted. |Smoke from the fire was dense at times across much of Northern California, concentrated by strong atmospheric inversions. Air quality was reported by the Air Resources Board as some of the worst on record, causing many schools to close and events to be canceled across the area. Visibility was below 1/2 mile at times.|The cause of the fire is under investigation, though there evidence suggests it occurred near damaged power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dry upper level trough pushed through California on September 11 and 12. This system brought cooler temperatures to the area along with a period of gusty winds between the evening of September 11 through the evening of September 12. Peak gusts were generally between 20 and 30 mph in the San Joaquin Valley while several locations in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts reported gusts between 35 and 50 mph while a few low impact indicator sites reported gusts above 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bear Peak RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 61 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clearing skies and a cold air mass allowed temperatures to drop below freezing over northeast California east of the Cascades.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 31 to 32 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Increased monsoonal moisture in Southern California resulted in thunderstorms across the San Bernardino Mountains. These storms produced cloud-to-ground lightning, which caused a brush fire near Lake Arrowhead. Lightning also struck a tree and caught it on fire in Fawnskin.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported a tree engulfed in flames from a lightning strike on Delamar Mountain Road in Fawnskin.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoonal moisture moved into Southern California on August 15th and resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms across the region. Heavy rain fell in the San Diego County Mountains on August 15th, and became more widespread on August 16th and 17th. Mount Laguna picked up 3.20 inches of rainfall on August 17th. Numerous areas of flash flooding and debris flows were reported throughout Southern California, particularly in the Riverside and San Bernardino County mountain areas. A landspout tornado was reported in the Anza Valley associated with a severe thunderstorm. No injuries or major damages were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reports of a landspout tornado northwest of Anza, CA. No injuries or damages were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Cranston Fire began in late July and continued to actively burn through August 13th, 2018. It started around 1100 PST on 7/25 in the Riverside County Mountains near the town of Idyllwild. Nearby communities in Idyllwild, Mountain Center and Fern Valley were evacuated. In total, the fire scorched 13,000 acres, 5 structures and resulted in many road closures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cranston Fire started on July 25th and continued to burn through August 13th when it was fully extinguished. It started on 7/25 around 1100 PST in the Riverside County Mountains. By 1700 PST on 7/25, the fire had rapidly grown to 1,200 acres. In total, the Cranston Fire burned 13,000 acres, resulted in over 500 people being evacuated, and scorched 5 structures. The cause of the fire was determined to be arson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoonal moisture moved into Southern California on August 15th and resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms across the region. Heavy rain fell in the San Diego County Mountains on August 15th, and became more widespread on August 16th and 17th. Mount Laguna picked up 3.20 inches of rainfall on August 17th. Numerous areas of flash flooding and debris flows were reported throughout Southern California, particularly in the Riverside and San Bernardino County mountain areas. A landspout tornado was reported in the Anza Valley associated with a severe thunderstorm. No injuries or major damages were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Department of Transportation reported that there were dozens of small debris flows in and around the Cranston Fire burn scar on August 15th  but highway 74 was proactively closed based on NWS warnings. On August 17th, there was a large debris flow up to 5 feet deep in the Lake Hemet Campground area from Hurkey Creek. Again highway 74 was closed about 2 hours in advanced based on NWS briefings and the actual Flash Flood Warning.  Very large boulders were reported to have traveled downstream on the upper Hurkey Creek near Fleming Ranch. Evacuations were in order at Hurkey Creek Campground and Sheriff was on site monitoring the potential based on NWS briefings. Video of the debris flow was captured. A storm survey was conducted by NWS following the debris flow. No injuries or major damages reported from this event. Rain gauges in the area reported 1-1.5 inches of rainfall near the Cranston Fire burn scar. Evacuations of the small communities near the Cranston Fire burn scar were put into place on August 15th in anticipation of the heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding and debris flows.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong high pressure positioned over the Great Basin ushered in excessive temperatures into Southern California August 6-9. The desert areas and the Inland Empire experienced the hottest temperatures in this event. The inland areas experienced the brunt of the heat on August 6th-8th, with temperatures beginning to subside on August 9th. The coastal areas experienced their hottest temperatures on August 9th. The heat slowly began subsiding in all areas on August 10th, but remained quite hot throughout the week. Of significance, the Sea Surface Temperatures at La Jolla reached an all-time record high of 79.5F and several buoys reported 78-79F, peaking on August 9th. This is about 10 degrees above normal. The warm SST in July and August resulted in muggy conditions with dewpoints 70 to 72F reported for a few weeks at coastal observations including SAN. The minimum temperature did not drop below 70F at SAN for 36 consecutive days. Many days exceed 85F. August 2018 was the hottest on record for SAN (average temperature) and July and August combined was #2.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Inland Empire experienced temperatures in excess of 100 degrees on August 6th and 7th. Most areas in the Inland Empire experienced temperatures of 100-105 degrees, with the highest values observed in San Bernardino (108 degrees) and Lake Elsinore (111 degrees). The heat began to subside slightly on the 8th, with warm conditions continuing throughout the week.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Coachella Valley experienced the most extreme temperatures in Southern California during this heat event. Thermal hit 117 degrees and Palm Springs reach 115 degrees on August 6th. Similar temperatures were observed on August 7th as well. Heat began to subside on Thursday, August 9th, but it remained quite warm in the Coachella Valley through the entire week.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoonal moisture moved into Southern California on August 15th and resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms across the region. Heavy rain fell in the San Diego County Mountains on August 15th, and became more widespread on August 16th and 17th. Mount Laguna picked up 3.20 inches of rainfall on August 17th. Numerous areas of flash flooding and debris flows were reported throughout Southern California, particularly in the Riverside and San Bernardino County mountain areas. A landspout tornado was reported in the Anza Valley associated with a severe thunderstorm. No injuries or major damages were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reported that Brookside Avenue and Highland Springs Avenue was flooded out on both sides of the road from the heavy rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Large wildfires developed across Northern California early August during a period of high temperatures, and low humidity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Donnell Fire began on August 1, 2018, along Highway 108 in Stanislaus National Forest in Tuolumne County. The cause of the fire is unknown. The fire burned 36,450 acres, 54 structures destroyed and 81 minor structures destroyed. of them homes. Among the destroyed buildings was the historic Dardanelle Resort and Dardanelle Bridge. The fire was not fully contained until early October. There were a total of 9 injuries from the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large fire developed during an extended period of hot, dry weather with gusty winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Delta Fire began on September 5, 2018, near Lakehead by Shasta Lake, in Shasta-Trinity National Forest in Shasta County. The fire was determined to be human caused. The fire burned 63,100 acres and caused evacuations through the area, with 20 structures destroyed and no injuries reported. The fire was not fully contained until October 7. The fire came close to the Carr Fire. The Delta Fire burned into the western perimeter of the Hirz Fire on September 10.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Broad troughing and low grade monsoon moisture triggered an isolated thunderstorm over Inyo County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rocks and mud covered Highway 136.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The outer fringes of the remnants of Hurricane Rosa produced isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water and rocks flowed across Highway 95 in several places north of Vidal Junction. The highway was closed all the way to Needles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Cranston Fire started around 1100 PST on 7/25 in the Riverside County Mountains near the town of Idyllwild. Nearby communities in Idyllwild, Mountain Center and Fern Valley were evacuated. In total, the fire scorched 13,000 acres, 5 structures and resulted in many road closures. The fire was fully contained on August 13.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cranston Fire started on 7/25 around 1100 PST in the Riverside County Mountains. By 1700 PST on 7/25, the fire had rapidly grown to 1,200 acres. In total, the Cranston Fire burned 13,000 acres, resulted in over 500 people being evacuated, and scorched 5 structures. The cause of the fire was determined to be arson. The Cranston Fire was fully contained on 8/13.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Large wildfires developed across Northern California early August during a period of high temperatures, and low humidity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hirz Fire began on August 9, 2018, near Lakehead by Shasta Lake, in Shasta-Trinity National Forest in Shasta County. The fire was determined to be human caused. The fire burned 46,150 acres and caused evacuations through the area, but no structures were destroyed and no injuries were reported. The fire was not fully contained until September 12. The fire came close to the Carr Fire. The Delta Fire burned into the western perimeter of the Hirz Fire on September 10.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed over parts of Mono County on the 1st. The storms were mainly slow-moving and some produced heavy rain and a debris flow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained weather spotter 1 mile southwest of Toms Place reported 0.86 inches of rainfall in a 20 minute period from 1 August 1330PST to 1350PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed over parts of Mono County on the 1st. The storms were mainly slow-moving and some produced heavy rain and a debris flow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained weather spotter reported a debris flow at least 3 feet deep located along Aspen Springs Ranch Drive near Crooked Creek 2 miles west of Toms Place. The debris flow occurred shortly after 1.79 inches of rainfall fell within a 45 minute period from 1 August 1545PST to 1630PST. No damage/cleanup estimates were available.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms from Arizona pushed into Southern California early on July 9th. The thunderstorm collapsed and produced a gust front, which brought strong winds into the Coachella Valley. These winds kicked up a significant amount of dust, reducing visibility to as low as 3/4 of a mile. The intense winds knocked over a power pole, and resulted in a house fire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An intense line of thunderstorms across Arizona pushed to the west- northwest into Southern California around 0000 PST on July 9th. By 0100 PST, the thunderstorms began to collapse. The outflow boundary produced a gust front, which brought some gusty winds and kicked up a good bit of dust and dirt. The gust front pushed into the Coachella Valley around 0130-0200 PST and greatly reduced visibility through 15z. Visibility of  of a mile was reported in Thermal. The intense winds downs a power pole and line onto a house, which caused it to catch fire. A wind gust of 40 knots was reported in Indio. Haze and dust were present in the Coachella Valley for a few hours in the morning of July 9th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fire broke out near Lake Berryessa in Napa County on July 28th. Due to the fire being located in a densely populated area, evacuations were issued. The fire was contained on August 2nd after burning 135 acres, destroying 8 structures, and damaging 4.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Steele Fire began on July 28th and was fully contained on August 2nd. Eight structures were destroyed and 4 were damaged http://www.fire.ca.gov/current_incidents/incidentdetails/Index/2184.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Natchez Wildfire was caused by lightning. The time of ignition was around 1830 PDT on 07/15/2018. As of 0330 PDT on 09/01/18, the fire covered 27076 acres and was 70 percent contained. 0 structures were lost and 34.8 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Natchez Wildfire was caused by lightning. The time of ignition was around 1830 PDT on 07/15/2018. As of 0330 PDT on 09/01/18, the fire covered 27076 acres and was 70 percent contained. 0 structures were lost and 34.8 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Stone Wildfire was started by lightning around 0800 PDT on 08/15/18.  As of the last report at 0330 PST on 08/30/2018, the fire covered 39387 acres and was 100 percent contained.  2 structures were lost and 16.6 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Stone Wildfire was started by lightning around 0800 PDT on 08/15/18.  As of the last report at 0330 PST on 08/30/2018, the fire covered 39387 acres and was 100 percent contained.  2 structures were lost and 16.6 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds developed on the 4th due to a passing trough of low pressure. Gusts reached into the 35 to 45 mph range for many locations with mountaintop gusts in excess of 55 mph. Unfortunately, the stronger westerly winds also brought more smoke into the region from the west. This led to widespread poor air quality for parts of the day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet WMSRS atop White Mountain (elevation 14246 feet) reported a wind gust of 80 mph at 1800PST 4 August.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Holy Fire started around 2:15 PM PST on August 6th and spread rapidly through the Santa Ana Mountains. Hot temperatures and dry conditions helped exasperate the fire even further. Evacuation orders were issued for parts of Trabuco Canyon, including the entire community of Holy Jim. The fire grew in total to over 23,000 acres and was fully contained on September 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Holy Fire began in the Santa Ana Mountains around 2:15 PM PST on August 6th. The hot and dry conditions helped to exasperate the fire further. By the morning of August 7, the fire had increased in size to 4,000 acres and by August 8, it had grown to 6,200 acres. By August 9, more than 21,400 people in 7,400 residences were placed under mandatory evacuation in south Corona, Lake Elsinore, and several communities in the Santa Ana Mountains. Ortega Highway was closed for an indefinite period of time, due to fire danger between Antonio Parkway in San Juan Capistrano and Grand Avenue in the Lake Elsinore. The fire size in total ended up growing to over 23,000 acres. Eighteen structures were destroyed in Orange and Riverside Counties. No major injuries or deaths were reported. The fire was fully contained on September 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dry upper trough moved across the area during the evening of August 27 which brought a period of gusty winds across the west side of the San Joaquin Valley as well as to the Kern County Mountains and Deserts. Several low impact indicator sites measured peak gusts above 45 mph for a few hours. This system also brought much cooler temperatures to the area. Afternoon highs on the 28th were the coolest observed across much of the area since mid June.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bird Springs Pass RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 63 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong high pressure system built westward from the Desert Southwest region on August 6 which provided for two days of hot temperatures across the Kern County Deserts on August 7 and 8. Highs generally ranged between 106 and 111 degrees on both days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 106 and 111 degrees at most locations on August 8 and August 9.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 106 and 111 degrees at most locations on August 8 and August 9.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Ferguson Fire started on July 13, 2018 at 2136 PDT in the South Fork Merced River drainage, 10 miles north of Mariposa, CA in Sierra National Forest. The cause of the fire is under investigation. The fire started in an area that has steep, rugged terrain with scarcely any road access and a heavy presence of beetle-killed trees. On the morning of July 14, a heavy equipment operator was killed in a bulldozer rollover accident while constructing line in a steep canyon. The fire grew rapidly under hot and dry weather conditions. Strong inversions each day resulted in smoke issues in the fire area that limited aircraft operations. Smoke impacts from the fire spread throughout Yosemite National Park, the Sierra Nevada and foothill and into the San Joaquin Valley. Highway 140 leading into Yosemite National Park was closed on July 14 and remained closed through August 14. Smoke impacts in Yosemite resulted in dangerous air quality causing Yosemite Valley and most of the eastern part of the park to be closed to visitors on July 25. This closure continued until August 14. Highway 41 leading into Yosemite from the south was also closed and did not reopen until August 24. Several communities just outside of Yosemite, including El Portal, Foresta, and the park employee housing at Rancheria Flat were subject to evacuations. From July 24 to 31, additional evacuations and repopulations of other areas continued to occur. On July 29, another tragic accident occurred when a tree fell, hitting and killing a firefighter. The weather moderated on August 6, which gave firefighters the opportunity to reinforce containment lines, mop up hot spots, and complete firing operations to keep the fire from spreading further into Yosemite National Park.  The closure of Yosemite National Park for nearly three weeks had local and global impacts on those who had planned to travel to visit during that time. Economically, businesses were impacted in the gateway communities who depend on summer tourist season to sustain them through the year. |By August 18, the fire was contained and had burned 96,901 acres at a suppression cost of $117 Million. There were 19 injuries to firefighters and 10 structures destroyed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Ferguson fire began on the Sierra National Forest just west of Yosemite, and spread to parts of the Stanislaus National Forest as well as into southern and western Yosemite National Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two people were rescued from Ocean Beach by a surfer on the first of August after being pulled into the ocean by a rip current. A third boy swept out to sea was not recovered.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The media reported that three people were pulled into the water at Ocean Beach by a rip current. Two people were rescued by a surfer while a third was missing https://abc7news.com/news/2-rescued-1-boy-missing-in-waters-off-ocean-beach/25936/. The search for the third person was called off the following day https://abc7news.com/news/search-halted-for-teen-in-waters-off-ocean-beach/26586/.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southerly flow pulled moisture into the Desert Southwest, fueling thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert and the Sierra Nevada. Many storms produced flash flooding and/or severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Highway 168 was flooded and impassable just west of Westgard Pass.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southerly flow pulled moisture into the Desert Southwest, fueling thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert and the Sierra Nevada. Many storms produced flash flooding and/or severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Horseshoe Meadows Road was closed at Lubken Canyon Road due to mud slides.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southerly flow pulled moisture into the Desert Southwest, fueling thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert and the Sierra Nevada. Many storms produced flash flooding and/or severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds overturned two big rigs on I-15, injuring one person.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southerly flow pulled moisture into the Desert Southwest, fueling thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert and the Sierra Nevada. Many storms produced flash flooding and/or severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water, rocks, and mud washed onto Highway 95, but the road remained passable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cool air mass and clearing skies allowed temperatures to drop below freezing over many areas east of the Cascades.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported low temperatures ranged from 28 to 30 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system moved into Northern California on June 16. This resulted in increased onshore flow over Central California and a noticeable cooling trend across the area between the 15th (when temperatures were above normal) and the 17th (when temperatures were several degrees below normal for mid June). A strong inland push of marine cooled air resulted in breezy conditions over the west side of the San Joaquin Valley on the afternoon of June 16 where several locations had gusts exceeding 35 mph. Increased pressure gradients produced gusty winds over the Kern County Mountains and Deserts from the afternoon of June 17 through the morning of June 18. Several stations reported gusts exceeding 45 mph while a few locations had peak gusts near 60 mph.The winds diminished by the afternoon of the 18th as the upper low lifted northeast into the Northern Rockies.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jawbone Canyon RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 63 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reached Excessive Heat Warning levels on the 12th and 13th. One hiker suffering from dehydration and heat exposure was rescued from Death Valley National Park on the 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reached Excessive Heat Warning levels on the 12th and 13th. One hiker suffering from dehydration and heat exposure was rescued on the 15th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A brush fire broke out in the Aliso Viejo Canyon Park around 2pm on 6/2/2018. The fire scorched approximately 200 acres and forced evacuations of thousands of residents in the Aliso Viejo and Laguna Beach. No structures were damaged. Five firefighters suffered non-life threatening injuries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brush fire broke out in Aliso Viejo around 1300 PST on June 2nd and spread to around 200 acres. Erratic winds and dry fuels helped to exasperate the fire. Thousands of homes were evacuated in Aliso Viejo and Laguna Beach due to the fire. The Top of the World neighborhood in Laguna Beach was evacuated as well. No structures were damaged in the fire. Five firefighters suffered non-life threatening injuries. Authorities determined that a young boy accidentally set the fire.

CZ_NAME: NORTHEAST SISKIYOU AND NORTHWEST MODOC COUNTIES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clearing skies along with a cool air mass in place allowed temperatures to drop below freezing over some areas east of the Cascades.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 32 to 34 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Patches on dense fog formed during the morning of December 1 in Tulare County. The fog completely dissipated by late morning as an incoming frontal boundary mixed out the atmosphere. Rain and higher elevations snow spread across the region by the afternoon of December 1 with much of the San Joaquin Valley picking up between one and two tenths of an inch of rainfall. Much of the Southern Sierra Nevada picked up between a quarter to three quarters of an inch of precipitation while elevations above 5000 feet picked up between 5 and 10 inches of snowfall north of Kings Canyon and between 3 and 5 inches of snowfall south of Kings Canyon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Visalia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As the low cloud deck that had persisted over the San Joaquin Valley for the previous 3 days continued to lift, the low clouds spread out and formed a a layer of dense fog in upslope areas in the Kern County Mountains during the afternoon on December 10 which impacted travel on Interstate 5 and State Route 58. The fog burned off by late morning on December 11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Tehachapi. California Highway Patrol reported visibility between 25 and 50 feet between San Canyon Rd. and Tehachapi Blvd. and also reported visibility below a quarter mile in the Grapevine area along Interstate 5.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dry shortwave dropped southward just to the east of the Sierra crest as an upper trough deepened over the Desert Southwest during the morning of December 28. Meanwhile, an upper ridge pushed inland into northern California setting up a period of strong offshore Mono type winds along the crest of the Southern Sierra Nevada. This resulted in a closure of the China Peak ski resort as winds gusted around 55 mph at the top of the lifts. Meanwhile the center of the San Joaquin Valley was sheltered form the winds and clear skies overnight some locally dense fog formed and impacted traffic along State Route 99.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Fresno and Madera.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large high pressure ridge strengthened off the California coast on June 22 and slowly built inland through June 24 providing the San Joaquin Valley with it's first prolonged period of triple digit heat in 2018. As a result of the widespread triple digit heat in the San Joaquin Valley during this period, several municipalities opened cooling centers during the afternoon hours. The ridge weakened and moved east of the area on June 25 allowing for cooler air to push into the San Joaquin Valley and end the hot spell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 100 and 105 degrees at most locations between June 22 and June 24.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper trough pushed through California between the evening of June 27 and the  morning of June 29. While this system was moisture deficient and did not produce any precipitation across the area, it did provide for a period of increased winds across the area as onshore pressure gradients strengthened. Several stations measured wind gusts exceeding 40 mph while a few low impact indicator sites briefly reported wind gusts exceeding 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jawbone Canyon RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 71 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long-period southwest swell from Hurricane Fabio brought high surf to Orange County beaches on late on July 4 through July 6. Surf was 5-8 ft with local sets to 10-12 ft at favored locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A long-period southwest swell from Hurricane Fabio brought high surf to Orange County Beaches on July 5-6. Surf of 5-8 feet was reported at southern Orange County Beaches and surf of 6-8 feet, with local sets  10-12 feet, reported at northern Orange County beaches. The Wedge reported surf of 8-12 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The strong winds that took place over the Kern County Mountains and Deserts during the evening hours on May 31 continued into the early morning hours of June 1. The winds diminished by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cache Creek reported a peak wind gust of 58 mph.

CZ_NAME: NORTHEAST SISKIYOU AND NORTHWEST MODOC COUNTIES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cool air mass and clearing skies allowed temperatures to drop below freezing over many areas east of the Cascades.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The only reported low temperature from this zone was 28 degrees in Tulelake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system moved across the Pacific Northwest on June 9 which pushed cooler air into Central California. This produced a strong onshore pressure gradient which resulted in a period of increased winds across the Kern County Mountains and Deserts where several locations measured gusts exceeding 50 mph between the afternoon of June 9 and the morning of June 10. Some stronger gusts were observed mainly at low impact indicator sites.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jawbone Canyon RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 61 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds began early on the 9th as an upper-level trough of low pressure and cold front moved towards northeastern California and the eastern Sierra. Wind gusts peaked as high as 70 mph in wind prone locations along the U.S. Highway 395 corridor, but most locations saw wind gusts in the 35-50 mph range.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: ASOS South Lake Tahoe Airport (elevation 6257 feet) reported a 60 mph wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm plume of moist tropical air brought a very active period of weather to the area between the evening of March 20 and the evening of March 22. This resulted in widespread heavy rainfall across the area on March 21 and 22 which produced flooding at many locations with rock slides and debris flows closing several roads across the area. The most impacted areas being around Mariposa as a result of the Detwiler Fire burn scar and Springville as a result of the Pier Fire burn scar. In addition, thunderstorms developed during the afternoon of March 22 producing flash flooding at many locations as well as funnel clouds. A Flash Flood Emergency was issued for most of western Mariposa County where several buildings were flooded and some areas were evacuated. A small tornado briefly touched down near Dinuba in Tulare County. In addition, several feet of new snow fell above 9000 feet. Below the snow line, much of the Southern Sierra Nevada measured between 4 and 8 inches of rainfall while most of the San Joaquin Valley picked up between 1 and 3 inches of rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported State Route 140 sliding into the Merced River and a large crack in the road.

Below the snow line, much of the Southern Sierra Nevada measured between 4 and 8 inches of rainfall while most of the San Joaquin Valley picked up between 1 and 3 inches of rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reports of road flooding with about 10 cars stuck in high water on Clovis Ave near the State Route 168 underpass in Clovis.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large cold upper low pressure area dropped southeast from the Gulf of Alaska to off the Pacific Northwest coast by the morning of March 1. Several bands of precipitation associated with this system pushed through Central California between the morning of March 1 and the afternoon of March 3. Significant rainfall impacted much of the area during this time frame with several reporting stations in the Southern Sierra Nevada from Fresno County northward picking up more than 2 inches of rainfall with a few locations picking up more than 5 inches of rain. Between 2 and 4 feet of snow fell over the higher elevations of the Southern Sierra Nevada from Fresno County northward during this 60 hour period while some light snowfall fell over the Kern County Mountains and Southern Sierra Foothills on March 3 as the snow level lowered to around 3000 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The SNOTEL at Big Meadows (7600 feet) picked up an estimated 37.2 inches of new snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large cold upper low pressure area dropped southeast from the Gulf of Alaska to off the Pacific Northwest coast by the morning of March 1. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm plume of moist tropical air brought a very active period of weather to the area between the evening of March 20 and the evening of March 22. This resulted in widespread heavy rainfall across the area on March 21 and 22 which produced flooding at many locations with rock slides and debris flows closing several roads across the area. The most impacted areas being around Mariposa as a result of the Detwiler Fire burn scar and Springville as a result of the Pier Fire burn scar. In addition, thunderstorms developed during the afternoon of March 22 producing flash flooding at many locations as well as funnel clouds. A Flash Flood Emergency was issued for most of western Mariposa County where several buildings were flooded and some areas were evacuated. A small tornado briefly touched down near Dinuba in Tulare County. In addition, several feet of new snow fell above 9000 feet. Below the snow line, much of the Southern Sierra Nevada measured between 4 and 8 inches of rainfall while most of the San Joaquin Valley picked up between 1 and 3 inches of rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brief cold air funnel was reported by an NWS employee at the corner of Houston Ave. and Mooney Blvd. in north Visalia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm plume of moist tropical air brought a very active period of weather to the area between the evening of March 20 and the evening of March 22. EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported State Route 49 completely closed due to mudslides between State Route 120 and Bear Valley Rd.  The road was closed for several days due to erosion from a massive amount of water which washed out the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm coverage increased on the 31st with slow-moving storms developing in southern Mono County. A storm remained nearly stationary near June Lake in Mono County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported a debris flow at least 4 feet deep located at State Route 158 (June Lake Loop) approximately 7.3 miles south of the north junction of State Route 158 and US Highway 395. A series of slow-moving thunderstorms trained over the debris flow site for 5 hours from 31 July 1200PST to 1830PST. Mesonet JEMC1, Gem Pass above the debris flow area (elevation 10971 feet) reported 1.29 inches of rainfall over a 5-hour period from 31 July 1200PST to 1700PST. State Route 158 was closed from the afternoon of 31 July to the evening of 8 August. No damage/cleanup estimates were available.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm coverage increased over portions of Mono County the 12th through the 14th. On the 12th, the strongest storms, over parts of central and southern Mono County, produced from around 0.25 to as much as 1.14 inches of rainfall. Thunderstorm coverage decreased the 13th, but then increased the 14th, with many of the storms being located in along the Eastern Sierra. These storms produced around 0.40 to as much as 1.18 inches of rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported that US Highway 6 was washed out with a large boulder in the roadway due to heavy rainfall from nearby thunderstorms. The approximate time of the event was 12 July 1506PST to 1606PST. No damage estimates were available.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: SNOTEL TRUC1, 6 miles north-northeast of Big Chief (elevation 6513 feet) reported 0.50 inches of rainfall in a 24-hour period from 13 July 2000PST to 14 July 2000PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large cold upper low pressure area dropped southeast from the Gulf of Alaska to off the Pacific Northwest coast by the morning of March 1. Between 2 and 4 feet of snow fell over the higher elevations of the Southern Sierra Nevada from Fresno County northward during this 60 hour period while some light snowfall fell over the Kern County Mountains and Southern Sierra Foothills on March 3 as the snow level lowered to around 3000 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported all lanes on a portion of Hunters Valley Road 12NNW Catheys Valley were blocked due to a mudslide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low pressure system strengthened off the Pacific Northwest coast on March 12. This system spread moisture into Central California on March 13 and 14 as a deep upper trough slowly pushed east across the region. Scattered thunderstorms developed during the afternoon of March 13, and one strong thunderstorm which developed in the Southern Sierra Foothills in Tulare County produced heavy rainfall which resulted in Flash Flooding and mudslides near the Pier Fire burn scar near Springville. Mudslides were also reported near the Detwiler Fire burn scar near Mariposa. Several locations in the southern Sierra Nevada measure between an inch to two inches of rainfall. Several inches of new snow fell over the higher elevations of the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains with the snow level lowering to 5000 feet on the 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported boulders blocking the east bound portion of State Route 178.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad area of upper level low pressure moved into the western part of the U.S. on the 16th and persisted through the 17th. Bands of moderate to heavy rain developed north of the main center of the low stretching across the northern Sierra and into far western Nevada on the 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ravendale RAWS, 5 miles south-southeast of Ravendale (elevation 5450 feet) reported 0.62 inches of rainfall in a 24-hour period from 16 May 0500PST to 17 May 0500PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Daytime heating and ample moisture along the periphery of a ridge caused scattered convection over western Nevada and the eastern Sierra July 19th through the 25th. Several storms produced heavy rainfall which led to flash flooding and debris flows. Hail was also reported with some storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported a debris flow containing trees and boulders crossing California Highway 89 below Monitor Pass. A series of thunderstorms moved over the Slinkard Fire burn scar and produced 0.26 inches of rainfall in just over a 2-hour period from 21 July 1337PST to 1552PST at the RAWS located within the burn scar. Over an inch of rain fell on the burn scar the two days prior to the debris flow, which saturated the soil. No damage/cleanup estimates were available.

These storms produced around 0.40 to as much as 1.18 inches of rainfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A funnel cloud was observed by several public observers near Goshen. The duration of the funnel was 5 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved through Southern California on March 10. This system spread precipitation northward into Central California during the afternoon and evening hours and brought half to three quarters of an inch of rainfall to much of the Tehachapi Mountains and a quarter to half of an inch of rainfall to the Kern County Deserts and the south end of the San Joaquin Valley. Areas further north picked up between a tenth to a quarter of an inch of precipitation with light snow accumulations in the southern Sierra Nevada above 8000 feet. Skies then cleared out by the morning of March 11, and areas of dense fog formed over the San Joaquin Valley with several stations reporting visibility below a quarter mile by sunrise. The fog burned off between 830 and 1000 am.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Fresno, Madera, Merced and Atwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad area of upper level low pressure moved into the western part of the U.S. on the 16th and persisted through the 17th. Bands of moderate to heavy rain developed north of the main center of the low stretching across the northern Sierra and into far western Nevada on the 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station FARC1, 2 miles northwest of Floriston (elevation 5188 feet) reported 0.67 inches of rainfall from 16 May 0600PST to 17 May 1930PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a brief break between systems on March 15, another low pressure system brought widespread precipitation to the area on March 16 and 17. The most significant precipitation was in Mariposa County and in the Yosemite Park area where several reporting stations measured over an inch of rainfall. One to two feet of new snow fell above 6000 feet in Yosemite Park. Several other reporting stations in the area picked up between a quarter and half an inch of rainfall. Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours of March 16 and 17, with brief periods of heavy rainfall and small hail being the main impacts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Yosemite National Park rangers measured 24 inches of new snowfall at the Badger Pass ski area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An incoming front brought high winds to northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Callahan RAWS recorded a gust to 65 mph at 14/0916 PST.  The Blue Ridge RAWS recorded a gust to 59 mph at 14/1051 PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An incoming front brought high winds to northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Blue Mountain RAWS recorded a gust to 61 mph at 14/1527 PST.  The Juniper Creek RAWS recorded a gust to 62 mph at 14/1352 PST. The Rush Creek RAWS recorded a gust to 64 mph at 14/1403 PST and a gust to 62 mph at 14/1503 PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An incoming front brought high winds to northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Weed Airport RAWS recorded gusts exceeding 57 mph continuously during this interval.  The peak gust was 71 mph recorded at 14/0948 PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An incoming front brought high winds to the Shasta Valley in northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Weed Airport RAWS recorded a gust to 58 mph at 16/2248 PST.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mariposa Office of Emergency Services reported several homes flooded and roadways washed out. While many roadways were washed out across Northwestern Mariposa County, the homes were generally impacted near Lake Don Pedro, Hornitos, and the City of Mariposa. The two fatalities that did occur in the area were both related to a person driving into a flooded roadway. One was along highway 132 west of Coulterville and the other was near Cathey's Valley where a 72 year old woman was found dead nearly four months later.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Increased monsoonal moisture in Southern California resulted in numerous thunderstorms across the region. Flash flooding, debris flows, and lightning reported in the San Bernardino Mountains. San Diego and Riverside counties saw flash flooding too along with thunderstorm winds that caused damage. Various roads were closed through the afternoon and evening due to flooding and debris flows.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Campo ASOS reported a thunderstorm wind gust of 43 knots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Increased monsoonal moisture in Southern California resulted in numerous thunderstorms across the region. Flash flooding, debris flows, and lightning reported in the San Bernardino Mountains. San Diego and Riverside counties saw flash flooding too along with thunderstorm winds that caused damage. Various roads were closed through the afternoon and evening due to flooding and debris flows.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS station at Palm Springs Airport recorded a 54 knot thunderstorm wind gust around 1753 PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The month of December started with a fast-moving upper level low and cold front sweeping east-southeast across northern California and north-central Nevada. These features brought snow to northeast California and the Sierra Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mammoth Mountain Ski Resort reported 6 inches of snowfall at an elevation of 8909 feet and 10 inches of snowfall at an elevation of 11053 feet in a 24 hour period from 1 December 0700PST to 2 December 0700PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm plume of moist tropical air brought a very active period of weather to the area between the evening of March 20 and the evening of March 22. This resulted in widespread heavy rainfall across the area on March 21 and 22 which produced flooding at many locations with rock slides and debris flows closing several roads across the area. The most impacted areas being around Mariposa as a result of the Detwiler Fire burn scar and Springville as a result of the Pier Fire burn scar. In addition, thunderstorms developed during the afternoon of March 22 producing flash flooding at many locations as well as funnel clouds. A Flash Flood Emergency was issued for most of western Mariposa County where several buildings were flooded and some areas were evacuated. A small tornado briefly touched down near Dinuba in Tulare County. In addition, several feet of new snow fell above 9000 feet. Below the snow line, much of the Southern Sierra Nevada measured between 4 and 8 inches of rainfall while most of the San Joaquin Valley picked up between 1 and 3 inches of rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported a rock slide covering half of the roadway on State Route 168 at Huntington Lake Rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Madera County Public Works reported Road 417 was closed just west of Huron Rd. due to flooding.

Various roads were closed through the afternoon and evening due to flooding and debris flows.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported a flash flood on Fish Creek Wash near Split Creek Road. The dirt road had approximately 1 foot of water flowing across it.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Palm Springs ASOS reported 1.08 inches of rain from 1700 PST to 1900 PST on July 11th. This was a daily record amount of rainfall for that location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Increased monsoonal moisture in Southern California resulted in numerous thunderstorms across the region. Flash flooding, debris flows, and lightning reported in the San Bernardino Mountains. San Diego and Riverside counties saw flash flooding too along with thunderstorm winds that caused damage. EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported that rocks and debris were blocking the roadway at Dillon Road and Bubbling Wells Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved through Southern California on March 10. This system spread precipitation northward into Central California during the afternoon and evening hours and brought half to three quarters of an inch of rainfall to much of the Tehachapi Mountains and a quarter to half of an inch of rainfall to the Kern County Deserts and the south end of the San Joaquin Valley. Areas further north picked up between a tenth to a quarter of an inch of precipitation with light snow accumulations in the southern Sierra Nevada above 8000 feet. Skies then cleared out by the morning of March 11, and areas of dense fog formed over the San Joaquin Valley with several stations reporting visibility below a quarter mile by sunrise. The fog burned off between 830 and 1000 am.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Hanford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low pressure system strengthened off the Pacific Northwest coast on March 12. This system spread moisture into Central California on March 13 and 14 as a deep upper trough slowly pushed east across the region. Scattered thunderstorms developed during the afternoon of March 13, and one strong thunderstorm which developed in the Southern Sierra Foothills in Tulare County produced heavy rainfall which resulted in Flash Flooding and mudslides near the Pier Fire burn scar near Springville. Mudslides were also reported near the Detwiler Fire burn scar near Mariposa. Several locations in the southern Sierra Nevada measure between an inch to two inches of rainfall. Several inches of new snow fell over the higher elevations of the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains with the snow level lowering to 5000 feet on the 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported Flash Flooding and a mudslide on State Route 190 east of Springville at the Powerhouse Bridge. About 3 feet of water covered the bridge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast-moving shortwave trough brought strong winds to the Sierra Nevada and Eastern California on the 14th. Peak gusts ranged from 45 to 55 mph throughout these areas, with wind prone areas seeing wind gusts in excess of 55 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station SE089, 1 mile southwest of Conway Summit reported a 71 mph wind gust. Mesonet station 8822 feet MSL.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station TADC1, 2 miles northeast of Donner Peak reported a 79 mph wind gust. Mesonet elevation 7399 feet MSL.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station WMSRS, at White Mountain Summit reported a 106 mph wind gust. Mesonet elevation 14246 feet MSL.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak warm air advection created light snow across the Sierra and northeast California during the late night hours of the 3rd and early morning hours of the 4th. Additional light snow developed on the afternoon and evening of the 4th and extended into the morning of the 5th as a weak deformation axis developed over the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twenty-four-hour snowfall amounts ranged from 1 to 2 inches at lake level in the Tahoe Basin to as much as 6 inches at the higher elevations around Lake Tahoe.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep shortwave trough moved through the region from early on the 24th through the morning hours of the 25th. This weather system brought moderate to heavy rain in the lower valleys of northeast California and snow to the Sierra Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet MTSC1 2 miles southwest of Glenshire-Devonshire reported 0.89 inches of rainfall over a 24-hour period from 24 December 0700PST to 25 December 0700PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper low moved south over southern Nevada and persisted in that area through much of the 22nd, which caused showers and thunderstorms to become widespread across western Nevada and the eastern Sierra.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portable RAWS NCRC1, 1 mile west-northwest of Topaz Lake (elevation 7451 feet) reported 0.27 inches of rainfall in 15 minutes from 21 May 1652PST to 1727PST, just before two debris flows were reported beneath the Slinkard Fire burn scar. A total of 0.90 inches of rainfall was reported in a two and a half hour time period from 21 May 1652PST to 1922PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Martinez Fire broke out on the Torres Martinez Reservation in Mecca around 1400 PST on July 23rd. Seven homes were destroyed and 30 tribal members were displaced. Three firefighters suffered minor injuries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Martinez Fire broke out around 1400 PST on July 23rd. Dry conditions and temperatures in the 120s helped exasperate the fire. Seven homes were destroyed. Approximately 30 tribal members were displaced from their homes and lost nearly all of their possessions. Three firefighters suffered minor injuries in the blaze.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Enhanced monsoonal moisture and instability over the mountains brought numerous thunderstorms to the San Bernardino Mountains. Heavy rain from those thunderstorms resulted in multiple debris flows across state route 38. One debris flow was reported on Valley of the Falls Drive near Forest Falls, and the other debris flow was reported west of Mountain Home Village.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms formed in the San Bernardino Mountains due to enhanced monsoonal moisture on July 7th. Heavy rain from the thunderstorms resulted in multiple debris flows on State Route 38. The first debris flow was reported on State Route 38 near Valley of the Falls Drive in Forest Falls. This debris flow was approximately 11 feet deep and 25 feet wide. State Route 38 closed at Valley of the Falls Drive due to the debris flow. No injuries were reported, but at least one vehicle was stuck in the debris flow.  Another debris flow was reported on State Route 38 and Frustration Creek west of Mountain Home Village.  This debris flow was approximately 100 feet wide and 10 feet deep.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large cold upper low pressure area dropped southeast from the Gulf of Alaska to off the Pacific Northwest coast by the morning of March 1. Several bands of precipitation associated with this system pushed through Central California between the morning of March 1 and the afternoon of March 3. Significant rainfall impacted much of the area during this time frame with several reporting stations in the Southern Sierra Nevada from Fresno County northward picking up more than 2 inches of rainfall with a few locations picking up more than 5 inches of rain. Between 2 and 4 feet of snow fell over the higher elevations of the Southern Sierra Nevada from Fresno County northward during this 60 hour period while some light snowfall fell over the Kern County Mountains and Southern Sierra Foothills on March 3 as the snow level lowered to around 3000 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wawona picked up an estimated 18.0 inches of new snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large cold upper low pressure area dropped southeast from the Gulf of Alaska to off the Pacific Northwest coast by the morning of March 1. Several bands of precipitation associated with this system pushed through Central California between the morning of March 1 and the afternoon of March 3. Significant rainfall impacted much of the area during this time frame with several reporting stations in the Southern Sierra Nevada from Fresno County northward picking up more than 2 inches of rainfall with a few locations picking up more than 5 inches of rain. Between 2 and 4 feet of snow fell over the higher elevations of the Southern Sierra Nevada from Fresno County northward during this 60 hour period while some light snowfall fell over the Kern County Mountains and Southern Sierra Foothills on March 3 as the snow level lowered to around 3000 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gin Flat picked up an estimated 46.0 inches of new snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper low moved south over southern Nevada and persisted in that area through much of the 22nd, which caused showers and thunderstorms to become widespread across western Nevada and the eastern Sierra.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A collapsing core within a thunderstorm produced heavy rainfall over the Slinkard burn scar west of Topaz Lake, Nevada, which caused two pronounced debris flows off the burn scar onto U.S. Highway 395 near the California/Nevada state line. The debris flows were up to 5 feet deep in a few places and closed the highway for over 18 hours while crews removed the flow. The portable RAWS site above the Slinkard Fire burn scar (NCRC1; elevation 7451 feet) recorded 0.27 inches of rainfall in 15 minutes at the time two debris flows were reported (21 May 1727PST). A total of 0.90 inches of rainfall eventually fell on the burn scar in a two and a half hour time period from 21 May 1652PST to 1922PST. No cleanup estimates were available from the California Department of Transportation.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported rocks fallen onto the roadway at the middle of a 4 lane section of State Route 168 below Shaver Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm coverage increased over portions of Mono County the 12th through the 14th. On the 12th, the strongest storms, over parts of central and southern Mono County, produced from around 0.25 to as much as 1.14 inches of rainfall. Thunderstorm coverage decreased the 13th, but then increased the 14th, with many of the storms being located in along the Eastern Sierra. These storms produced around 0.40 to as much as 1.18 inches of rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained weather spotter 1 mile southwest of Toms Place measured 0.98 inches of heavy rain from 12 July 1634PST to 13 July 0800PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Increased monsoonal moisture in Southern California resulted in numerous thunderstorms across the region. Flash flooding, debris flows, and lightning reported in the San Bernardino Mountains. San Diego and Riverside counties saw flash flooding too along with thunderstorm winds that caused damage. Various roads were closed through the afternoon and evening due to flooding and debris flows.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from monsoonal thunderstorms resulted in a rock slide in the San Bernardino Mountains. Highway 18 was closed for approximately 4 hours between Big Bear Lake and Snow Valley due to numerous rock slides in the Arctic Circle. One vehicle was reported to be stuck on the highway because of a large boulder stuck underneath their car.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Minor coastal flooding occurred at high tide in Orange County late on July 11th. No damages to homes were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor coastal flooding occurred during high tide between 26th street and 38th street in Newport Beach during late on July 11th. No damage to homes was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Natchez Wildfire was caused by lightning. The time of ignition was around 1830 PDT on 07/15/2018. As of 0330 PDT on 10/01/18, the fire covered 38134 acres and was 84 percent contained. 0 structures were lost and 43.7 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Natchez Wildfire was caused by lightning. The time of ignition was around 1830 PDT on 07/15/2018. As of 0330 PDT on 10/01/18, the fire covered 38134 acres and was 84 percent contained. 0 structures were lost and 43.7 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clear skies combined with a cool and very dry air mass to bring freezing temperatures to parts of northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The only reported low temperature in this zone was 32 degrees at Callahan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Increased monsoonal moisture in Southern California resulted in thunderstorms, heavy rain, and debris flows across the region, particularly in the mountain areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported a mudslide along Highway 18 northeast of Big Bear City that was 6 feet deep and extending 20 feet across the highway. 12 vehicles were stranded in the mudslide. Highway 18 was closed between Big Bear and Lucerne Valley due to the debris flow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Increased monsoonal moisture in Southern California resulted in thunderstorms, heavy rain, and debris flows across the region, particularly in the mountain areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Monsoonal moisture brought thunderstorms to the San Bernardino Mountains on July 12th. This resulted in flash flooding on Highway 18 near mile marker 65 (Mitsubishi Cement Corporation Plant). numerous vehicles stranded due to significant flow of water and debris. Highway 18 was closed in both directions through the afternoon on July 12th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Increased monsoonal moisture in Southern California resulted in thunderstorms, heavy rain, and debris flows across the region, particularly in the mountain areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CalTrans and California Highway Patrol reported flash flooding on Valley of the Falls Drive near Highway 38. Concerns for debris flow movement and heavy rain forced the closure of Valley of the Falls Drive through the afternoon on July 12th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Increased monsoonal moisture in Southern California resulted in thunderstorms, heavy rain, and debris flows across the region, particularly in the mountain areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One day total rainfall from Mesonet 7 mi NE of Cherry Valley (yucc1) of 1.84 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station LDRC1, 11 miles northeast of Old Station reported a wind gust of 58 mph. Mesonet elevation 5672 feet MSL.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong broad upper level high pressure centered over Nevada and unusual weak offshore flow in July brought extreme hot temperatures and dry conditions to Southern California from July 6th through 8th. Inland Orange County, San Diego Valleys, Inland Empire and the deserts experienced the most extreme temperatures. July 6th was the hottest day during this event, with Thermal and Chino reaching 120 degrees, and San Bernardino and Riverside Airport reaching 118 degrees. July 7th and 8th remained quite hot -- only a few degrees cooler than July 6th. Heat began to subside significantly on July 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Even the desert was hot on July 6, 120F reported at Thermal and 119F at Palm Springs. These were shy of the 123-124F all-time highs. Palm Springs managed to reach 115F the following day.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported a mud slide along northbound State Route 41 at Jackson Rd. near Fish Camp after brief heavy rain moved over the area.

The most impacted areas being around Mariposa as a result of the Detwiler Fire burn scar and Springville as a result of the Pier Fire burn scar. A Flash Flood Emergency was issued for most of western Mariposa County where several buildings were flooded and some areas were evacuated. A small tornado briefly touched down near Dinuba in Tulare County. In addition, several feet of new snow fell above 9000 feet. Below the snow line, much of the Southern Sierra Nevada measured between 4 and 8 inches of rainfall while most of the San Joaquin Valley picked up between 1 and 3 inches of rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cal Trans reported a road closure due to a mudslide on State Route 190 about 8.4 miles west of Camp Nelson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large cold upper low pressure area dropped southeast from the Gulf of Alaska to off the Pacific Northwest coast by the morning of March 1. Several bands of precipitation associated with this system pushed through Central California between the morning of March 1 and the afternoon of March 3. Significant rainfall impacted much of the area during this time frame with several reporting stations in the Southern Sierra Nevada from Fresno County northward picking up more than 2 inches of rainfall with a few locations picking up more than 5 inches of rain. Between 2 and 4 feet of snow fell over the higher elevations of the Southern Sierra Nevada from Fresno County northward during this 60 hour period while some light snowfall fell over the Kern County Mountains and Southern Sierra Foothills on March 3 as the snow level lowered to around 3000 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The SNOTEL at Volcanic Knob (10500 feet) picked up an estimated 32.3 inches of new snowfall.

Several bands of precipitation associated with this system pushed through Central California between the morning of March 1 and the afternoon of March 3. EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported a road closure at State Route 49 and Bear Valley Road as a result of mud, rock and dirt covering the intersection.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike early morning in Oakdale damaged trees and a mobile home.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike in Oakdale ignited a fire in several Italian cypress trees. The flames spread to nearby vegetation and then to a mobile home, which sustained moderate damage. A second mobile home sustained minor heat damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorms developed over the northern Sierra Nevada with some large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail covered the ground to a depth of just over 2 inches. Most of the hail was pea size, but the larger hailstones were as large as nickels and quarters. The hail for about 15 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low pressure system strengthened off the Pacific Northwest coast on March 12. This system spread moisture into Central California on March 13 and 14 as a deep upper trough slowly pushed east across the region. Scattered thunderstorms developed during the afternoon of March 13, and one strong thunderstorm which developed in the Southern Sierra Foothills in Tulare County produced heavy rainfall which resulted in Flash Flooding and mudslides near the Pier Fire burn scar near Springville. Mudslides were also reported near the Detwiler Fire burn scar near Mariposa. Several locations in the southern Sierra Nevada measure between an inch to two inches of rainfall. Several inches of new snow fell over the higher elevations of the Southern Sierra Nevada and Tehachapi Mountains with the snow level lowering to 5000 feet on the 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported a mudslide caused a partial closure of State Highway 49 near Bagby.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a brief break between systems on March 15, another low pressure system brought widespread precipitation to the area on March 16 and 17. The most significant precipitation was in Mariposa County and in the Yosemite Park area where several reporting stations measured over an inch of rainfall. One to two feet of new snow fell above 6000 feet in Yosemite Park. Several other reporting stations in the area picked up between a quarter and half an inch of rainfall. Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours of March 16 and 17, with brief periods of heavy rainfall and small hail being the main impacts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter report of 12 inches on new snow in Fish Camp.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm plume of moist tropical air brought a very active period of weather to the area between the evening of March 20 and the evening of March 22. This resulted in widespread heavy rainfall across the area on March 21 and 22 which produced flooding at many locations with rock slides and debris flows closing several roads across the area. The most impacted areas being around Mariposa as a result of the Detwiler Fire burn scar and Springville as a result of the Pier Fire burn scar. In addition, thunderstorms developed during the afternoon of March 22 producing flash flooding at many locations as well as funnel clouds. A Flash Flood Emergency was issued for most of western Mariposa County where several buildings were flooded and some areas were evacuated. A small tornado briefly touched down near Dinuba in Tulare County. In addition, several feet of new snow fell above 9000 feet. Below the snow line, much of the Southern Sierra Nevada measured between 4 and 8 inches of rainfall while most of the San Joaquin Valley picked up between 1 and 3 inches of rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported road closure due to rocks and mud on State Route 223 at State Route 58. Several vehicles were stuck in mud.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong broad upper level high pressure centered over Nevada and unusual weak offshore flow in July brought extreme hot temperatures and dry conditions to Southern California from July 6th through 8th. Inland Orange County, San Diego Valleys, Inland Empire and the deserts experienced the most extreme temperatures. July 6th was the hottest day during this event, with Thermal and Chino reaching 120 degrees, and San Bernardino and Riverside Airport reaching 118 degrees. July 7th and 8th remained quite hot -- only a few degrees cooler than July 6th. Heat began to subside significantly on July 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Santa Ana fire station climate site reached 114F on July 6, this was an all-time high. A scorching 115F was reported at Yorba Linda. On July 7, it still reached 109F at Yorba Linda.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong broad upper level high pressure centered over Nevada and unusual weak offshore flow in July brought extreme hot temperatures and dry conditions to Southern California from July 6th through 8th. Inland Orange County, San Diego Valleys, Inland Empire and the deserts experienced the most extreme temperatures. July 6th was the hottest day during this event, with Thermal and Chino reaching 120 degrees, and San Bernardino and Riverside Airport reaching 118 degrees. July 7th and 8th remained quite hot -- only a few degrees cooler than July 6th. Heat began to subside significantly on July 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On July 6, temperature at Chino ASOS reached 120F. This is the highest recorded reading for this location and possibly for an ASOS not in the desert. Ontario ASOS reached 117F, the prior highest reading was 114F. Riverside Airport hit 118F and Lake Elsinore reach 119F. On Saturday July 7, the temperatures cooled to 114 at Chino, 113 at Riverside and 112 at Ontario.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Building surface high pressure across northern California and Oregon interacting with an upper trough across the Great Basin resulted in gusty northerly winds across the region. This along with dry humidity resulted in Red Flag conditions across the North and East Bay Hills as well as the Santa Cruz Mountains. Gusts over the highest peaks exceeded 70 mph with widespread gusts above 1000 feet between 40-50 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Station at Mt St Helena was gusting between 45-65 mph during this time frame with a peak gust of 70 mph.

CZ_NAME: SOUTHERN MONTEREY BAY AND BIG SUR COAST
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cal Fire rescued two people caught in a rip current at Monastery Beach.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cal Fire rescues two people caught in a rip current at Monastery Beach https://www.sfgate.com/news/bayarea/article/Cal-Fire-Rescues-Swimmer-Lifeguard-From-Rip-13290065.php.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorms developed over the northern Sierra Nevada with some large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail as large as nickels was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Increased monsoonal moisture in Southern California resulted in numerous thunderstorms across the region. Flash flooding, debris flows, and lightning reported in the San Bernardino Mountains. San Diego and Riverside counties saw flash flooding too along with thunderstorm winds that caused damage. Various roads were closed through the afternoon and evening due to flooding and debris flows.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported lightning from numerous thunderstorms near Lucerne Valley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Increased monsoonal moisture in Southern California resulted in numerous thunderstorms across the region. Flash flooding, debris flows, and lightning reported in the San Bernardino Mountains. San Diego and Riverside counties saw flash flooding too along with thunderstorm winds that caused damage. Various roads were closed through the afternoon and evening due to flooding and debris flows.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter measured 0.45 inches of rainfall in 20 minutes from a thunderstorm near Pine Valley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Increased monsoonal moisture in Southern California resulted in thunderstorms, heavy rain, and debris flows across the region, particularly in the mountain areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station (f2736) reported a 24-hour rainfall total of 1.56 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Increased monsoonal moisture in Southern California resulted in thunderstorms across the San Bernardino Mountains. These storms produced cloud-to-ground lightning, which caused a brush fire near Lake Arrowhead. Lightning also struck a tree and caught it on fire in Fawnskin.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two cloud-to-ground strikes occurred outside of a rain shaft. Highway Patrol reported brush fire start just west of Lake Arrowhead. Other strikes were detected just to the east and also outside of the main rain shaft near Big Bear Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong broad upper level high pressure centered over Nevada and unusual weak offshore flow in July brought extreme hot temperatures and dry conditions to Southern California from July 6th through 8th. Inland Orange County, San Diego Valleys, Inland Empire and the deserts experienced the most extreme temperatures. July 6th was the hottest day during this event, with Thermal and Chino reaching 120 degrees, and San Bernardino and Riverside Airport reaching 118 degrees. July 7th and 8th remained quite hot -- only a few degrees cooler than July 6th. Heat began to subside significantly on July 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Intense heat on July 6 (and offshore flow) resulted in breezy east winds and a high of 117F at Ramona ASOS. The previous record high was 111F. At Escondido the high was 112 and Santee 110, these were just shy of all-time highs. San Diego Public Health and 211 services share statistic which showed a sharp jump in heat related 911 and 211 information calls. 211 San Diego can provide vouchers for those in need of cool shelter during heat waves. The destructive West Fire also occurred in Alpine, San Diego County on July 6. Alpine had highs of 109 and 104 for July 6 and 7th with wind gusts to 30 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall around the Woolsey Fire burn scar produced significant mud and debris flows. Per law enforcement, mud and debris closed the Pacific Coast Highway at Leo Carrillo Beach.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain over the Woolsey Fire burn scar resulted in a significant mud and debris flow across the Pacific Coast Highway. California Highway Patrol (CHP) reported Highway 1 (the Pacific Coast Highway) was closed around Leo Carrillo Beach due to a mud and debris flow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm plume of moist tropical air brought a very active period of weather to the area between the evening of March 20 and the evening of March 22. A Flash Flood Emergency was issued for most of western Mariposa County where several buildings were flooded and some areas were evacuated. A small tornado briefly touched down near Dinuba in Tulare County. In addition, several feet of new snow fell above 9000 feet. Below the snow line, much of the Southern Sierra Nevada measured between 4 and 8 inches of rainfall while most of the San Joaquin Valley picked up between 1 and 3 inches of rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter measured 0.91 inches of rainfall between 900 pm on March 21 and 700 am on March 22 with periods of heavy rain during this time frame.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge over Southern California plus light winds resulted in dense fog in San Diego County in the early morning hours of September 8th and 9th. Northern San Diego County experienced dense fog on the 8th, while southern San Diego County had fog on the 9th. Both mornings, the most dense fog occurred between 5 AM and 7 AM PST. Fog was particularly dense near Miramar Airport, Carlsbad Airport, Montgomery Field and Brown Field.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dense fog with visibility 1/4 mile or less was observed at Carlsbad Airport between 5 AM and 7 AM PST on the 8th. Fog began to clear after sunrise.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long period west to northwest swell increased the risk of sneaker waves and brought rough surf to the Central Coast and Bay Area. This resulted in three water rescues along San Francisco Beaches. One surfer did not survive.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A surfer was pulled from the water at Ocean Beach in the early afternoon. Rescuers performed CPR on the scene before transferring him to a trauma center. The surfer later died http://www.ktvu.com/news/person-pulled-from-water-at-ocean-beach.

CZ_NAME: SOUTHERN MONTEREY BAY AND BIG SUR COAST
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A paraglider landed in the surf zone and was swept out to sea ahead of a large powerful swell that arrived mid-week.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A paraglider was swept out to sea near Sand City in rough surf and was not found https://www.kion546.com/news/search-continues-for-missing-paraglider-near-sand-city-beach-1/932571571.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Hurricane Rosa brought a long-period south swell to Southern California on October 1 and 2. This swell resulted in high surf, particularly on the southwest facing beaches of Orange County. Surf gradually lowered on October 2.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lifeguards at Huntington Beach reported 8-10 ft surf on October 1, and 6-10 ft surf at Newport Beach.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As the low pressure system that was responsible for the strong winds on December 4 and 5 and the snow which disrupted travel over the Kern County Mountains on December 6 moved east of our area, high pressure built in bringing clearing skies and diminished winds to the San Joaquin Valley on the morning of December 7. This resulted in the formation of widespread dense fog over the San Joaquin Valley which adversely impacted travel on several major highways including on State Routes 99, 41, 180 and 152 and caused several school districts to ether delay morning bus service or open late. The fog dissipated in most of the valley by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several school districts either delayed bus service or opened late due to dense fog.

This resulted in the formation of widespread dense fog over the San Joaquin Valley which adversely impacted travel on several major highways including on State Routes 99, 41, 180 and 152 and caused several school districts to ether delay morning bus service or open late. The fog dissipated in most of the valley by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Fresno, Madera, Merced and Atwater. Several school districts either delayed bus service or opened late due to dense fog.
