EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Periods of snow caused travel problems and delays on mountain highways during the busy holiday travel period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were 1.03 inches of rain over 12 hours in East Quincy.

CZ_NAME: COASTAL NORTH BAY INCLUDING POINT REYES NATIONAL SEASHORE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An amplifying ridge over the Pacific and a deep upper trough over the Great Basin provided the set up for strong northerly flow over most of central and northern California. Winds gusted as high as 78 mph up on Mt Saint Helena with widespread gusts of 40 to 60 mph reported. These winds prompted both Wind Advisory and Gale Warnings across much of the region. Numerous downed trees were reported and a fatality occurred on the San Francisco Bay as a result of these conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two people in their 40s were on a row boat on Richardson Bay during a gale warning when both fell out of the boat, possibly from waves. They were both brought to the hospital where the woman suffered from hypothermia but survived and the man was pronounced dead at the hospital. Neither were wearing a life jacket https://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/article/One-man-dead-in-Richardson-Bay-boat-accident-13501280.php.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Santa Ana Wind event impacted Southern California on October 15th. Multiple mesonet sites reported winds in excess of 58 mph, with the highest wind gust of 82 mph at Fremont Canyon. Orange County reported over 200 downed trees. There was one fatality from a fallen tree crushing a vehicle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet recorded a wind gust of 71 knots in Fremont Canyon between 0751 and 0851 PST on October 15th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Santa Ana Wind event impacted Southern California on October 15th. Multiple mesonet sites reported winds in excess of 58 mph, with the highest wind gust of 82 mph at Fremont Canyon. Orange County reported over 200 downed trees. There was one fatality from a fallen tree crushing a vehicle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station se081, 4 miles ENE of Tustin reported a 50 knot wind gust between 0640 and 0740 PST on October 15th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge off the coast of Southern California brought marine layer clouds and dense fog during the night and morning hours between October 25 through 29. No major impacts were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported 1/2 mile visibility near University of San Diego between 0600 and 0900 PST on October 26th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge off the coast of Southern California brought marine layer clouds and dense fog during the night and morning hours between October 25 through 29. No major impacts were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fullerton Airport ASOS reported 1/4 mile visibility or less between 0500 and 0800 PST on October 28th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge off the coast of Southern California brought marine layer clouds and dense fog during the night and morning hours between October 25 through 29. No major impacts were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: San Diego Lindbergh Field ASOS reported 1/4 mile visibility between 0200 and 0400 PST on October 28th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge off the coast of Southern California brought marine layer clouds and dense fog during the night and morning hours between October 25 through 29. No major impacts were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Carlsbad Palomar Airport ASOS reported less than 1/4 mile visibility between 0400 and 0700 PST on October 28th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge off the coast of Southern California brought marine layer clouds and dense fog during the night and morning hours between October 25 through 29. No major impacts were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow caused travel delays during the busy Thanksgiving holiday travel period. This was the first significant snow event of the season.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: More than a foot of snow fell above 6500 feet over the the northern Sierra, bringing travel delays and chain controls on mountain highways such as I80 and Highway 50. This occurred during the busy Thanksgiving holiday. Highways over seasonal passes were closed, including SR-4 over Ebbetts Pass, SR-89 over Monitor Pass, and SR-108 over Sonora Pass. Kirkwood Ski Resort measured a total of 25 through the event at an elevation of 9800', while most ski peaks saw a little more than a foot. The Heavenly Ski Resort closed on Thanksgiving due to the snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful west to northwest swell impacted the central coast from Dec 16th to Dec 20th prompting a High Surf Warning and a High Surf Advisory along the coast. This was also accompanied by an upper level low that produced gusty winds and heavy rainfall. This led to large breaking waves up to 50 feet at Mavericks and caused damage to a bay front restaurant. There were also multiple water rescues during this surf event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large waves crash into a window at a restaurant in Pacifica shattering the glass and flooding a room https://abc7news.com/weather/massive-waves-hit-bay-area-beaches/4915867/.

CZ_NAME: SOUTHERN MONTEREY BAY AND BIG SUR COAST
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful west to northwest swell impacted the central coast from Dec 16th to Dec 20th prompting a High Surf Warning and a High Surf Advisory along the coast. This was also accompanied by an upper level low that produced gusty winds and heavy rainfall. This led to large breaking waves up to 50 feet at Mavericks and caused damage to a bay front restaurant. There were also multiple water rescues during this surf event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: State parks lifeguard responds to swimmer in distress at Carmel Beach. The swimmer was rescued with no injuries https://www.kion546.com/news/state-parks-lifeguard-saves-swimmer-at-carmel-beach/938070425.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The month of December started with a fast-moving upper level low and cold front sweeping east-southeast across northern California and north-central Nevada. These features brought snow to northeast California and the Sierra Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thirty-six-hour snowfall amounts ranged from 4 inches at lake level in the Tahoe Basin to as much as a 12-14 inches (Homewood Mountain and Squaw Valley Ski Resorts) at the higher elevations around Lake Tahoe.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain brought ponding of water on area roads. Mountain snow caused chain controls and delays on Sierra passes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Downtown Sacramento set a daily record for rainfall, 1.17 inches of rain, breaking the old record of 0.95 inches set in 2002.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain brought ponding of water on area roads. Mountain snow caused chain controls and delays on Sierra passes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Red Bluff set a daily record for rainfall, 1.77 inches of rain, breaking the old record of 1.25 inches set in 1962.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain brought ponding of water on area roads. Mountain snow caused chain controls and delays on Sierra passes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were chain controls in place on Interstate 80, Highway 50, State Route 4 (SR-4) in Calaveras County and Alpine County, SR-88 in Amador and Alpine counties and SR-108 in Tuolumne County. Snow amounts reported were 8 inches at Dodge Ridge, 6 inches at Castle Peak, 5 inches at Donner Ski Ranch, and 4 inches at Sugar Bowl.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Periods of snow caused travel problems and delays on mountain highways during the busy holiday travel period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was 1.49 inches of rain over 10 hours in Shingletown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Periods of snow caused travel problems and delays on mountain highways during the busy holiday travel period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was 12 inches of snow reported at Northstar Ski Resort. Holiday travel was impacted by long delays and chain controls.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure strengthened over the area on December 8. With winds remaining light in the San Joaquin Valley and skies having cleared out the previous afternoon. Widespread dense fog developed in the San Joaquin Valley during the early morning hours impacting travel along several of the major highways in the valley. While the fog lifted into a low clouds deck across most the the valley, the dense fog persisted in the Merced and Atwater areas into the afternoon and reformed during the evening. Visibility finally improved during the early morning of December 9 as the fog lifted into a low cloud deck.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Fresno, Madera, Merced and Atwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure strengthened over the area on December 8. With winds remaining light in the San Joaquin Valley and skies having cleared out the previous afternoon. Widespread dense fog developed in the San Joaquin Valley during the early morning hours impacting travel along several of the major highways in the valley. While the fog lifted into a low clouds deck across most the the valley, the dense fog persisted in the Merced and Atwater areas into the afternoon and reformed during the evening. Visibility finally improved during the early morning of December 9 as the fog lifted into a low cloud deck.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Hanford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wildfire smoke brought areas of dense smoke, with visibility levels at times dropping to less than a half mile. Hazardous air quality was measured across much of the Central Valley and Delta, causing numerous school and outdoor event cancellations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dense smoke dropped visibilities down to a mile or less across across the southern Sacramento Valley. Air quality measurements were in the Unhealthy to Very Unhealthy range.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wildfire smoke brought areas of dense smoke, with visibility levels at times dropping to less than a half mile. Hazardous air quality was measured across much of the Central Valley and Delta, causing numerous school and outdoor event cancellations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dense smoke dropped visibilities down to a mile or less across across the northern Sacramento Valley. Air quality measurements were in the Unhealthy to Very Unhealthy range.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture from Tropical Storm Sergio advanced into the Coachella Valley late on October 12th and resulted in widespread thunderstorms with heavy rain into the morning of October 13th, flash flooding, and hail. Many flash floods were reported across the area, as well as quarter-sized hail in Indio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reported flash flooding at Varner Drive and Date Palm Drive and requested that the road be closed to traffic.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front moved through into Christmas morning bringing scattered showers and gusty winds to the region. One report was received of a tree falling onto a house in Atherton.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell on a house in the early morning in Atherton. A pine tree fell through the roof and into a bedroom. No injuries https://www.sfgate.com/news/bayarea/article/Nobody-Injured-Christmas-Morning-After-Tree-Falls-13490931.php.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge off the coast of Southern California brought marine layer clouds and dense fog during the night and morning hours between October 25 through 29. No major impacts were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported visibility of less than a mile in Brea between 0500 and 0800 PST on October 28th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge off the coast of Southern California brought marine layer clouds and dense fog during the night and morning hours between October 25 through 29. No major impacts were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Carlsbad Palomar Airport reported less than 1/4 mile visibility between 0000 and 0500 PST on October 28th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge off the coast of Southern California brought marine layer clouds and dense fog during the night and morning hours between October 25 through 29. No major impacts were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fullerton Airport ASOS reported 1/4 mile visibility between 0100 and 0600 PST on October 28th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge off the coast of Southern California brought marine layer clouds and dense fog during the night and morning hours between October 25 through 29. No major impacts were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brown Field ASOS reported 1/4 mile visibility from 2300 on October 28th to 0500 on October 29th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Up to 4 feet of snow fell at Sierra pass levels, with light accumulations down into the upper foothills.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Caltrans reported 46 inches of snow at Castle Peak, 22 inches at Kingvale. Pacific House received 3.0 inches of snow, Kyburz 2.25 inches, Camino 7 inches. This brought chain controls and delays on mountain highways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Periods of snow caused travel problems and delays on mountain highways during the busy holiday travel period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was 11 inches of snow reported at Alpine Meadows Ski Resort. Holiday travel was impacted by long delays and chain controls.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold inside slider moved into Southern California on New Year's Eve, bringing rain and snow to the region. San Diego County received most of the precipitation from this event. San Diego coastal areas received 0.25-0.50, valley and mountain areas received 0.50-1.0. The mountain areas of San Diego County received 1-2 inches of snow above 4000 ft. High winds were also observed during this event. Gusts of 50-60 mph were recorded in the Riverside and San Diego County Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple spotter reports of a waterspout/funnel cloud in Carlsbad around 1400 PST on December 31st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure strengthened over the area on December 8. With winds remaining light in the San Joaquin Valley and skies having cleared out the previous afternoon. Widespread dense fog developed in the San Joaquin Valley during the early morning hours impacting travel along several of the major highways in the valley. While the fog lifted into a low clouds deck across most the the valley, the dense fog persisted in the Merced and Atwater areas into the afternoon and reformed during the evening. Visibility finally improved during the early morning of December 9 as the fog lifted into a low cloud deck.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Visalia, Porterville and Bakersfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wildfire smoke brought areas of dense smoke, with visibility levels at times dropping to less than a half mile. Hazardous air quality was measured across much of the Central Valley and Delta, causing numerous school and outdoor event cancellations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dense smoke dropped visibilities down to a mile or less across across the northern San Joaquin Valley. Air quality measurements were in the Unhealthy range.

A dense fog advisory was issued for the San Francisco Bay coastline, the Santa Clara Valley, and over the San Francisco Bay south of the Bay Bridge. Visibilities were down to a quarter of a mile or less.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dense fog at KSFO, ASOS reported 1/4 mile visibility and fog.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful west to northwest swell impacted the central coast from Dec 16th to Dec 20th prompting a High Surf Warning and a High Surf Advisory along the coast. This was also accompanied by an upper level low that produced gusty winds and heavy rainfall. This led to large breaking waves up to 50 feet at Mavericks and caused damage to a bay front restaurant. There were also multiple water rescues during this surf event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Surfer at Mavericks wipes out in large wave and needs to be rescued https://abc7news.com/sports/what-its-like-to-wipe-out-on-a-50-foot-wave/4918957/. Time is estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Large tidal fluctuations, referred to as King Tides, impacted the California coast the weekend of the 22nd to the 24th. Low lying areas and roadways were flooded as a result of the extreme high tides.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of Shoreline Highway off of 101 were closed by CalTrans due to flooding brought by King Tides https://abc7news.com/weather/christmas-eve-brings-rain-to-bay-area-roadway-headaches-and-accidents-/4961312/. Timing is estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold dry air mass brought clear skies and calm winds to the region allowing temperatures to drop below freezing overnight into the 29th across parts of the CWA. This prompted the issuance of a freeze warning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Marquez RAWS station recorded temperatures between 22 and 28 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough from the northwest moved into Southern California on December 24th and 25th, bringing heavy rain, snow above 4000 ft and high winds. Coastal areas received 0.25-0.50 of rain, valley areas received up to an inch of rain, and mountain areas up to 1.50 of rain. Winds gusted to 50-70 mph in the mountains and deserts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Burns Canyon recorded a peak wind gust of 61 knots between 0251 and 0351 PST on December 25th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long-period west-northwest swell moved into Southern California on December 17th and continued through the 19th. Sets of 6-9 ft were observed in Orange and San Diego County on Friday the 18th. Ocean Beach Pier in San Diego County was closed due to the high surf.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lifeguards at Huntington Beach reported 6-8 ft surf December 17th and 18th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long-period west-northwest swell moved into Southern California on December 17th and continued through the 19th. Sets of 6-9 ft were observed in Orange and San Diego County on Friday the 18th. Ocean Beach Pier in San Diego County was closed due to the high surf.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lifeguards at Mission Beach and Solana Beach reported 6-8 ft surf on December 17th and 18th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level high and light winds brought dense fog to SoCal in the early morning hours of December 22nd and 24th. John Wayne Airport reported visibility of 1/16th of a mile, and Carlsbad Airport reported visibility of 1/4 of a mile.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: John Wayne Airport reported 1/16 SM visibility around 0500 PST on December 22nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moisture plume with a weak atmospheric river arrived on December 5th and brought rain to the region. On December 6th, a strong closed upper level low pressure brought an unstable air mass into Southern California with showers and thunderstorms, especially Orange and San Diego Counties. Rainfall of 1 inch per hour amounts occurred in Costa Mesa and downtown San Diego as well as adjacent cities. The main storm system on December 6th brought widespread rain to the entire region. All mountains and the coast and valleys areas received 1-3 inches and some spots receiving over 4 of rainfall over higher terrain. The most significant mud and debris flows occurred at recent Holy burn scar areas, and many reports of flash flooding across the region. Another strong cold front brought widespread rain on Christmas Day though the impacts were minimal. Snow fell as low as 4000 feet with mountains receiving 1 to 4 inches of snow including the San Diego mountains. Burns Canyon in the high deserts of San Bernardino County had a wind gust to 70 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported flash flooding along Highway 55 at Paularino Ave. in Costa Mesa. Reported that approximately 1 ft of water was along the right side of the road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: John Wayne Airport reported 2.56 inches of rainfall in about 2 hours on December 6th. This is a 1 in 100 year return interval. Cars in nearby Costa Mesa were seen completely submerged completely or stalled in deep water up to the windows.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong southwest jet mixed down to the mountains in Kern County during the early morning of December 14. Downslope winds then developed over the Grapevine area and impacted travel along Interstate 5. Only a few stations had wind gusts exceeding 45 mph, but the California Highway Patrol station near Grapevine measured a peak gust of 73 mph. The winds diminished by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Grapevine CHP station reported a peak wind gust of 73 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front that was associated with a moist upper trough pushed across central California on December 17. This system brought moderate to locally heavy rainfall from Fresno County northward the late evening of December through the morning of December 17 where several stations reported a half inch to an inch and a quarter of rainfall, and there were several reports of mainly nuisance flooding during this time period. The precipitation mainly fell as snow above 6500 feet where several stations in the Southern Sierra Nevada north of Fresno County picked up between 3 and 6 inches of new snow. Further south the rainfall was less plentiful with most locations receiving between a few hundredths of an inch to a quarter of an inch of rain by the time the precipitation ended by early afternoon on December 17.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported flooding at the intersection of Shain Ave. and Brannon Ave. near Dos Palos.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upslope flow behind the departing trough banked up against the Tehachapi Mountains during the evening of December 17 producing areas of dense fog which impacted travel along the major passes for a few hours. Visibility was reduced to a few hundred feet in the Grapevine area where California Highway Patrol paced traffic for nearly four hours on Interstate 5. The fog lifted into a stratus deck around midnight on December 18 and visibility along the passes rapidly improved.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported dense fog along Interstate 5 between Fort Tejon and Gorman and paced traffic for approximately four hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The month of December started with a fast-moving upper level low and cold front sweeping east-southeast across northern California and north-central Nevada. These features brought snow to northeast California and the Sierra Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two trained spotters 5 miles west-northwest of Susanville reported between 3 to 4.5 inches of snowfall in a 12-hour period between 0000PST and 1200PST 1 December.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moisture plume with a weak atmospheric river arrived on December 5th and brought rain to the region. On December 6th, a strong closed upper level low pressure brought an unstable air mass into Southern California with showers and thunderstorms, especially Orange and San Diego Counties. Rainfall of 1 inch per hour amounts occurred in Costa Mesa and downtown San Diego as well as adjacent cities. The main storm system on December 6th brought widespread rain to the entire region. All mountains and the coast and valleys areas received 1-3 inches and some spots receiving over 4 of rainfall over higher terrain. The most significant mud and debris flows occurred at recent Holy burn scar areas, and many reports of flash flooding across the region. Another strong cold front brought widespread rain on Christmas Day though the impacts were minimal. Snow fell as low as 4000 feet with mountains receiving 1 to 4 inches of snow including the San Diego mountains. Burns Canyon in the high deserts of San Bernardino County had a wind gust to 70 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The San Diego River at Fashion Valley went from 5 ft to 12 ft (minor flood stage) between 1700 and 2200 PST on December 6th. Avenida del Rio and Fashion Valley Road were both flooded out December 6th and 7th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Notable heavy rainfall rates at the Holy Fire burn scar. Coldwater Canyon received 0.35 of rainfall in 30 minutes. McVicker Canyon received 0.35 in 15 minutes. USGS 30-minute burn scar rainfall thresholds were exceeded in 60 canyons, and the 1-hour thresholds were exceeded in 5 canyons.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper ridge was centered over California on the morning of December 20. With clear skies, light winds and inversion conditions all present, an area dense fog formed over the San Joaquin Valley from south of Fresno to north of Wasco. Several observations of visibility below an eighth of a mile were reported by airport equipment or by law enforcement, and as a result of the dense fog, traffic was paced on some of the major highways and several school districts either had delayed openings or delayed bus service. The fog finally lifted by late morning and visibility improved during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several school districts opened late or delayed bus service.

The fog finally lifted by late morning and visibility improved during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Merced and Atwater. Several school districts opened late or delayed bus service.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Hanford and Lemoore. Several school districts opened late or delayed bus service. California Highway Patrol reported visibility below 200 feet on State Route 198 between the Kings/Tulare County border and 12th Ave. and paced traffic for much of the morning. California Highway Patrol reported visibility below 500 feet on State Highway 41 between State Highway 198 and Flint Ave and and paced traffic for much of the morning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although the upper ridge that was centered over California weakened and shifted east during the morning of December 21, areas of dense fog formed in the central and south San Joaquin Valley and impacted travel along the State Route 99 corridor between Merced and Visalia. Only a few school districts in Tulare County delayed bus service as the fog coverage was not as extensive as during the previous morning. The fog dissipated by late morning as a cold front moved through the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Madera.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although the upper ridge that was centered over California weakened and shifted east during the morning of December 21, areas of dense fog formed in the central and south San Joaquin Valley and impacted travel along the State Route 99 corridor between Merced and Visalia. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Fresno, Madera and Merced.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Areas of dense fog formed during the morning of December 27 as clear skies and light winds prevailed over the San Joaquin Valley. The fog resulted in some minor vehicle accidents in the Fresno area as the fog reduced visibility to a few hundred feet. However, the fog dissipated in the San Joaquin Valley by late morning as a cold front pushed southward through central California. Areas of dense fog persisted through the early afternoon along the valley facing slopes of the Tehachapi Mountains as a result of strong upslope flow that accompanied the front. The cold front also produced a period of gusty winds along the west side of the San Joaquin Valley as well as along and below the passes in Kern County where several stations measured gusts above 35 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Fresno, Madera and Atwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A flash flood from moisture well ahead of Tropical Cyclone Rosa stranded hikers in Forest Falls. The hikers tried to wait out the high flows as it appeared unsafe to cross the running water from nearby thunderstorm runoff. The flows continued until after dark and the hikers required assistance from local first responders.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms formed over Forest Falls late on Sunday September 30th. About 2 inches was estimated on radar. The runoff towards Mill Creek was significant can caused hikers to be stranded after dark as the water flow was not safe to cross. First responders were called to aid in the recovery. There was video posted on Facebook.

CZ_NAME: MOUNTAINS OF SAN BENITO COUNTY AND INTERIOR MONTEREY COUNTY INCLUDING PINNACLES NATIONAL PARK
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold dry air mass brought clear skies and calm winds to the region allowing temperatures to drop below freezing overnight into the 29th across parts of the CWA. This prompted the issuance of a freeze warning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pinnacles National Park RAWS station recorded temperatures of 28 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An amplifying ridge over the Pacific and a deep upper trough over the Great Basin provided the set up for strong northerly flow over most of central and northern California. Winds gusted as high as 78 mph up on Mt Saint Helena with widespread gusts of 40 to 60 mph reported. These winds prompted both Wind Advisory and Gale Warnings across much of the region. Numerous downed trees were reported and a fatality occurred on the San Francisco Bay as a result of these conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Media reported a downed tree in Santa Cruz that damaged a car, breaking the back window and damaging the bumper https://www.kron4.com/news/bay-area/police-warning-of-high-winds-downed-trees-in-santa-cruz/1681307091.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An amplifying ridge over the Pacific and a deep upper trough over the Great Basin provided the set up for strong northerly flow over most of central and northern California. Numerous downed trees were reported and a fatality occurred on the San Francisco Bay as a result of these conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large pine tree blew over and smashed into a car in Niles Community Park. No injuries reported. Multiple other locations reported downed trees as well. Time is estimated https://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2018/12/31/blustery-winds-batter-entire-bay-area/.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree down on Liberty Street between Walnut Ave and Sundale Dr.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful west to northwest swell impacted the central coast from Dec 16th to Dec 20th prompting a High Surf Warning and a High Surf Advisory along the coast. This was also accompanied by an upper level low that produced gusty winds and heavy rainfall. This led to large breaking waves up to 50 feet at Mavericks and caused damage to a bay front restaurant. There were also multiple water rescues during this surf event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Monterey Bay Buoy recorded wave heights between 17 and 26 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As the low pressure system that was responsible for the light to moderate precipitation across the area on December 1 moved out of the area on the morning of December 2, high pressure built inland and brought clearing skies and decreased winds to the San Joaquin Valley. With residual moisture from the previous day's storm in place dense fog formed during the morning in portions of the central and south San Joaquin Valley. The fog lifted by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Fresno and Merced.

CZ_NAME: SANTA CLARA VALLEY INCLUDING SAN JOSE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold overnight temperatures into Christmas morning in the low to mid 40s across Santa Clara County caused two cold exposure deaths around San Jose.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Medical Examiner out of Santa Clara county reported two fatalities believed to be caused by cold exposure around San Jose. Time is estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure over Arizona brought a few scattered showers and thunderstorms to the San Diego County deserts on October 7th. These showers resulted in a rock and mud slide on highway 78 near Buttes Pass Road in San Diego County. There were no reported damages or injuries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CalTrans reported rocks and mud across Highway 78 near Buttes Pass Road. No injuries or damages were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge over Southern California plus light winds resulted in dense fog in San Diego County in the early morning hours of September 8th and 9th. Northern San Diego County experienced dense fog on the 8th, while southern San Diego County had fog on the 9th. Both mornings, the most dense fog occurred between 5 AM and 7 AM PST. Fog was particularly dense near Miramar Airport, Carlsbad Airport, Montgomery Field and Brown Field.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility of 1/4 SM or less was observed in the valley areas of San Diego County at NKX, SDM, and MYF on the morning of September 9th.  This dense fog was observed from 2 AM to 7 AM PST at those ASOS sites, and began clearing after sunrise.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge off the coast of Southern California brought marine layer clouds and dense fog during the night and morning hours between October 25 through 29. No major impacts were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Imperial Beach ASOS reported 1/4 mile visibility between 0500 and 0800 PST on October 27th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge off the coast of Southern California brought marine layer clouds and dense fog during the night and morning hours between October 25 through 29. No major impacts were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: John Wayne Airport ASOS reported less than 1/4 mile visibility between 0300 and 0800 PST on October 27th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Interior valley fog that drifted into the East Bay brought visibility down to less than 1/4 mile. This prompted a Dense Fog Advisory to be issued for the East Bay valleys.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A quarter mile visibility or less was reported at Livermore Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Interior valley fog that drifted into the East Bay brought visibility down to less than 1/4 mile. This prompted a Dense Fog Advisory to be issued for the East Bay valleys.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Concord airport recorded visibility of a quarter mile or less.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread dense fog impacted the Bay Area blanketing the Bay and interior valleys. Numerous reports of dense fog with visibility less than 1/4 mile. A Dense Fog Advisory was issued for the North and East Bay Valleys as well as the San Francisco Peninsula and surrounding bay coastline. Fog caused numerous diverts at KSFO.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility at KSFO a quarter of a mile or less caused 19 diverts at the airport.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Los Alamitos ASOS reported 1/8 mile visibility between 0500 and 0800 PST on October 27th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold inside slider moved into Southern California on New Year's Eve, bringing rain and snow to the region. San Diego County received most of the precipitation from this event. San Diego coastal areas received 0.25-0.50, valley and mountain areas received 0.50-1.0. The mountain areas of San Diego County received 1-2 inches of snow above 4000 ft. High winds were also observed during this event. Gusts of 50-60 mph were recorded in the Riverside and San Diego County Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Volcan Mountain reported a peak wind gust of 56 knots between 0300 and 0400 PST on December 31st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although the upper ridge that was centered over California weakened and shifted east during the morning of December 21, areas of dense fog formed in the central and south San Joaquin Valley and impacted travel along the State Route 99 corridor between Merced and Visalia. Only a few school districts in Tulare County delayed bus service as the fog coverage was not as extensive as during the previous morning. The fog dissipated by late morning as a cold front moved through the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Hanford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front pushed southward through central California during the afternoon of  December 21. A brisk northwest flow behind the front resulted in upslope low clouds and areas of dense fog in the south end of the San Joaquin Valley and along the valley facing slopes of the Tehachapi Mountains during the morning of December 22. Traffic was impacted for a few hours along States Route 99 and 58 in Bakersfield and along State Route 58 in Tehachapi. The low clouds and fog lifted by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Tehachapi.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front pushed southward through central California during the afternoon of  December 21. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Bakersfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large low pressure system dropped slowly southward off the California coast on December 4  and 5. This resulted in a strong offshore pressure gradient over central California which produced strong winds in the downslope prone areas in Kern County. Several reports of peak gusts exceeding 40 mph were reported in the Kern County Mountains and the south end of the San Joaquin Valley between the late morning of December 4 through the early morning of December 5.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The California Highway Patrol station in Grapevine reported a peak wind gust of 58 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure built inland into Central California during the morning of December 18. With light winds and clearing skies, dense fog developed toward daybreak along the State Route 99 corridor between Atwater and Fresno and briefly around Hanford. The fog dissipated by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Fresno, Madera, Merced and Atwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dense fog formed in the Tehachapi area during the evening of December 23 as a result of upslope clouds banking up along the nearby valley facing mountain slopes. The fog impacted travel along State Route 58 for a few hours before dissipating overnight.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Tehachapi.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved through central California during the evening of December 24 and the morning of December 25. The Christmas Storm produced half and inch to an inch of liquid precipitation across much of the Southern Sierra Nevada while most of the San Joaquin Valley picked up between one and three tenths of and inch of rain while the Tehachapi Mountains picked up between a quarter to half an inch of liquid precipitation. The precipitation fell mainly as snow above 6000 feet, but amounts were generally light. A few stations along the southern Sierra crest picked up between 4 and 6 inches of new snow. This system also produced strong winds on Christmas morning over the Kern County Mountains and deserts where several locations reported gusts exceeding 40 mph while a few low impact indicator sites measured gusts near 70 mph. Finally, as winds diminished behind the system in the San Joaquin Valley, area of dense fog formed toward daybreak near Fresno and Porterville; but the fog dissipated by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Fresno.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The low pressure system which was responsible for the strong winds in portions of the central California interior on December 4 and 5 made an eastward turn on December 6 and pushed inland across southern California. This resulted in showers pushing inland across southern California during the morning of December 6. Instability which resulted from the proximity of the low resulted in the snow level lowering to 4000 feet, and while accumulations were generally light, the snow produced hazardous travel conditions which resulted in several accidents and vehicles becoming stuck. Several roads were closed in the Kern County Mountains (including Interstate 5 in the Grapevine area) until the damaged and disabled vehicles could be removed by early afternoon when the snow tapered off.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several reports of 1 to 3 inches of snow were reported in the Kern County Mountains above 4000 feet. The snow resulted in several roads being closed for a portion of the day including Interstate 5 from south of Grapevine in Kern County to Castaic in Los Angeles County afters several vehicles became either stuck or were involved with accidents. The impacted roads were cleared in the afternoon and Interstate 5 was re-opened when the snow tapered off.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Areas of dense fog formed during the morning of December 27 as clear skies and light winds prevailed over the San Joaquin Valley. The fog resulted in some minor vehicle accidents in the Fresno area as the fog reduced visibility to a few hundred feet. However, the fog dissipated in the San Joaquin Valley by late morning as a cold front pushed southward through central California. Areas of dense fog persisted through the early afternoon along the valley facing slopes of the Tehachapi Mountains as a result of strong upslope flow that accompanied the front. The cold front also produced a period of gusty winds along the west side of the San Joaquin Valley as well as along and below the passes in Kern County where several stations measured gusts above 35 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Tehachapi.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold and dry northerly flow aloft prevailed over Central California ahead of an offshore upper ridge. This resulted in strong radiational cooling taking place in the San Joaquin Valley on the mornings of December 29 and December 30 with the dry low level air resulting inhibiting fog formation. As result, temperatures dropped below the freezing mark across much of the San Joaquin Valley on both mornings resulting in this being the first widespread freeze of the season in the valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several locations reported minimum temperatures between 28 and 32 degrees on December 29 and December 30.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong shortwave trough dropped down through the Great Basin during the morning of December 31. With high pressure pushing inland into northern California behind the trough, offshore Mono type winds developed over the higher elevations of the southern Sierra Nevada which down-sloped into the foothills. This resulted in several drought weakened trees being knocked down in the foothills near North Fork and Oakhurst where locally strong wind gusts exceeding 60 mph were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cascadel Heights measured a peak gust of 68 mph.

A cold front associated with this system dropped southward through Central California during the morning of December 12. While this system was dry and did not have any precipitation associated with it, it did produce strong winds over the Kern County Mountains and Deserts for a brief period. Several stations reported gusts exceeding 35 mph while a few low impact indicator sites reported wind gusts above 50 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Blue Max RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 66 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Large wildfires developed across Northern California at the end of July during a period of high temperatures, low humidity and unusually dry fuels. A powerful fire whirl developed with the Carr Fire, creating significant wind damage to western Redding and rapid fire growth. The Mendicino Complex became the largest wildfire in California history. A state of emergency was declared at state and federal levels due to the fires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A powerful fire whirl developed within the Carr Fire in western Redding, CA on July 26th, with winds estimated in excess of 143 mph, equivalent to an EF3 tornado. The fire whirl was estimated to be on ground from 7:308:00 p.m. The fire whirl caused extensive tornado-like damage while rapidly spreading the fire. The winds crumpled high tension electrical transmission towers, damaged homes, and debarked and uprooted trees. Wind damaged areas included locations untouched by fire, and included signs of ground scouring. The damage path was 2 miles long, with an estimated width of about half a mile. Three people were killed inside their Redding home after the structure's walls were blown out and the roof collapsed on the occupants. Several other homes suffered significant roof damage. A firefighter was killed while driving his vehicle near the fire whirl. Three bulldozers were impacted by flying debris, rocks, embers, smoke and intense heat, with the operators suffering injuries including burns and cuts from broken glass.

CZ_NAME: MOUNTAINS SOUTHWEST SHASTA COUNTY TO NORTHERN LAKE COUNTY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Large wildfires developed across Northern California at the end of July during a period of high temperatures, low humidity and unusually dry fuels. A powerful fire whirl developed with the Carr Fire, creating significant wind damage to western Redding and rapid fire growth. The Mendicino Complex became the largest wildfire in California history. A state of emergency was declared at state and federal levels due to the fires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mendocino Complex Fire (made up of the River and Ranch Fires) spread across Colusa County, Glenn County, Lake County, and Mendocino County, becoming the largest wildfire in California history at 459,123 acres. The Mendocino Complex Fire was not contained until September 18. There were 157 residential buildings destroyed, 123 others destroyed. In addition, there were 13 residential buildings and 24 other buildings damaged. The fires caused at least $56 million in insured property damage. The city of Lakeport, communities of Kelseyville, Lucerne, Upper Lake, Nice, Saratoga Springs, Witter Springs, Potter Valley, and Finley, parts of Hopland, and the tribal communities of Hopland Rancheria and Big Valley Rancheria were evacuated. There was 1 firefighter killed (on August 13), 4 firefighters were injured.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Large wildfires developed across Northern California at the end of July during a period of high temperatures, low humidity and unusually dry fuels. A powerful fire whirl developed with the Carr Fire, creating significant wind damage to western Redding and rapid fire growth. The Mendicino Complex became the largest wildfire in California history. A state of emergency was declared at state and federal levels due to the fires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Carr Fire began on the afternoon of July 23, 2018, at the intersection of Highway 299 and Carr Powerhouse Road, near French Gulch in Shasta County. The fire is reported to have been started accidentally by a vehicle towing a trailer that had a tire blow out, causing the steel rim to scrape along the pavement, generating sparks that ignited dry vegetation along the edge of the highway. Local winds generated by the fire are reported to have caused the fire to spread quickly.||At the end of July, the fire was the sixth most destructive fire in California history at 112,888 acres, with 1,378 structures destroyed, 965 of them homes. The fire was not fully contained until August 30, reaching 229,651 acres in size with a total of 1,079 residences, 22 commercial structures, 503 outbuildings destroyed. There were also 190 residences, 26 commercial structures, and 61 outbuildings damaged. About 38,000 people were evacuated from their homes. There were a total of 8 deaths from the fire, 3 of them firefighters. A large fire whirl in Redding has been reported as being responsible for 4 of the deaths, and this has been listed as a separate event. Damage costs to insured buildings are estimated at $1.5 billion for the Carr Fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter storm impacted Southwestern California in early January. This storm generated heavy rainfall with totals ranging from 1-4 inches across the coasts and valleys with up to 7 inches over some foothill and mountain areas. At times, the rainfall was very intense, generating mud and debris including a deadly mud and debris flow in the community of Montecito. In the mountains, significant snowfall occurred at the resort level with over 6 inches of snow accumulation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Intense rainfall generated a large and deadly mud and debris flow in the community of Montecito, around the burn scar of the Thomas fire. Automated rain gauges in the area indicated very intense rainfall, reaching as high as 0.54 inches in 5 minutes. The intense rainfall resulted in a mud and debris estimated to be 15 feet high. This event resulted in the confirmed deaths of 21 residents (2 missing) as well as destroying 128 residences and damaging 307 others. Highway 101 was closed for days due to the mud and debris.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow caused travel delays during the busy Thanksgiving holiday travel period. This was the first significant snow event of the season.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: About a foot of snow fell in the Lassen National Park area, bringing travel delays and closing the park road. This occurred during the busy Thanksgiving holiday. Lower Lassen Peak SNOTEL reported 11 of new snow, the first significant accumulation of the season. Manzanita Lake Campground closed due to the snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wildfire smoke brought areas of dense smoke, with visibility levels at times dropping to less than a half mile. Hazardous air quality was measured across much of the Central Valley and Delta, causing numerous school and outdoor event cancellations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dense smoke dropped visibilities down to a mile or less across across the central Sacramento Valley. Air quality measurements were in the Unhealthy to Very Unhealthy range. The Butte County Office of Education closed all public schools in the county through Friday, Nov. 23. Chico State University suspended classes until Monday, Nov. 26.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A heatwave brought excessive heat warning conditions to much of southeast California.

An upper low moved across California and western Nevada providing forcing for showers and thunderstorm across the region. The combination of a moist atmosphere, instability and diffluent forcing from the low allowed for isolated storms with localized heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CO-OP Observer station TAAC1 near Tahoma reported 0.89 inches of rainfall in a 24-hour period from 3 October 0600PST to 4 October 0600PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Santa Ana Wind event impacted Southern California on October 15th. Multiple mesonet sites reported winds in excess of 58 mph, with the highest wind gust of 82 mph at Fremont Canyon. Orange County reported over 200 downed trees. There was one fatality from a fallen tree crushing a vehicle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture from Tropical Storm Sergio made its way into Southern California on October 12th and 13th, bringing heavy rain to the region. The Riverside County mountains and the Coachella Valley received the most precipitation in the region, with some areas exceeding 1 inch of rainfall. The Coachella Valley Water District dyke was blown out and resulted in damage to the infrastructure.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from Tropical Storm Sergio resulted in flash flooding in the Coachella Valley. The runoff destroyed a dike operated by the Coachella Valley Water District for a second time.

A heatwave developed across parts of southern California, resulting in excessive heat warning conditions.

High pressure ridging brought hot temperatures across the area, 5 to 10 degrees above normal. Some locations had high temperatures reaching 105-110, with temperatures remaining in the mid to upper 70s overnight. Heat Warnings and Advisories were issued. Heat Risk Criteria reached Moderate levels across the forecast area, with some areas in the northern Sacramento Valley and adjacent foothills reaching High to Very High levels.||Isolated nocturnal thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to the mountains, causing a rock slide.||A period of less extreme heat came earlier in the month. A 2 year old boy died in a hot car on July 7 in south Sacramento. The high temperature in downtown Sacramento reached 100 that day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The NWS Experimental Heat Risk reached Moderate to High readings for several days prompting a Heat Advisory for northern Shasta County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Major flash flooding occurred in the Morongo Basin. A spotter recorded 2.27 inches of rain between midnight and 630 AM PDT. Many roads were flooded or washed out, and numerous vehicles, including a fire truck, were either washed off the roads or stuck in flood waters and/or mud. Three water lines were broken, leaving many customers without water for up to 36 hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 28 to 33 degrees.

CZ_NAME: EAST BAY HILLS AND THE DIABLO RANGE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Building surface high pressure across northern California and Oregon interacting with an upper trough across the Great Basin resulted in gusty northerly winds across the region. This along with dry humidity resulted in Red Flag conditions across the North and East Bay Hills as well as the Santa Cruz Mountains. Gusts over the highest peaks exceeded 70 mph with widespread gusts above 1000 feet between 40-50 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Poverty RAWS reported wind gusts between 45-59 mph during this time frame.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system pushed into the Pacific Northwest on October 5 then dropped southeast into the Great Basin on October 6 providing the Kern County Mountains and Deserts with a period of strong winds during the afternoon and evening hours as a cold front associated with this system pushed through central California. Several reporting stations had wind gusts exceeding 45 mph, and a few low impact indicator sites had gusts around 60 mph. In addition, scattered showers brought some precipitation to the mountains and Kern County Deserts with the several locations in the Southern Sierra Nevada picking up a few tenths of an inch of rainfall while the Kern County Mountains and Deserts generally picked up a few hundredths of an inch of rainfall. Breezy conditions prevailed on the west side of the San Joaquin Valley during the morning of October 7 where several stations measured gusts around 40 mph. The winds diminished by the afternoon of October 7 as the low moved into the Desert Southwest region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bear Peak RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 58 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jawbone Canyon RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 59 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system dropped southward along the California coast on October 2 spreading precipitation across the Central California Interior. Most of the San Joaquin Valley received a few hundredths of an inch of rainfall while the Southern Sierra Nevada picked up a few tenths of an inch with some locally higher amounts. The low slowly tracked toward the Southern California coast on October 3 which provided for enough instability for scattered thunderstorms to break out over the area during the afternoon. The thunderstorms produced moderate to heavy rainfall across portions of the San Joaquin Valley and Southern Sierra Nevada. There were numerous reports of flooding during the afternoon and evening of October 3 and Flash Flooding was reported near Kettleman City and Huron along the west side of the San Joaquin Valley. A Flash Flood Emergency was issued for the Ferguson Fire burn scar where there several reports of debris flows and roads being washed out. There were several reports of one to two inches of rainfall in the San Joaquin Valley and Southern Sierra Nevada from the October 3 thunderstorms. With a warm airmass prevailing over the area, snow levels were above 11000 feet and snowfall was confined to the higher peaks in the Southern Sierra Nevada. The low moved east of the region on October 4 bringing an end to the precipitation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported flash flooding near the intersection of Interstate 5 and Jayne Ave.

There were numerous reports of flooding during the afternoon and evening of October 3 and Flash Flooding was reported near Kettleman City and Huron along the west side of the San Joaquin Valley. A Flash Flood Emergency was issued for the Ferguson Fire burn scar where there several reports of debris flows and roads being washed out. There were several reports of one to two inches of rainfall in the San Joaquin Valley and Southern Sierra Nevada from the October 3 thunderstorms. With a warm airmass prevailing over the area, snow levels were above 11000 feet and snowfall was confined to the higher peaks in the Southern Sierra Nevada. The low moved east of the region on October 4 bringing an end to the precipitation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported flash flooding at the intersection of Sutter Ave. and and Jayne Ave. Traffic was backed up 1 mile due to flash flooding.

CZ_NAME: EAST BAY HILLS AND THE DIABLO RANGE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Building surface high pressure across northern California and Oregon interacting with an upper trough across the Great Basin resulted in gusty northerly winds across the region. This along with dry humidity resulted in Red Flag conditions across the North and East Bay Hills as well as the Santa Cruz Mountains. Gusts over the highest peaks exceeded 70 mph with widespread gusts above 1000 feet between 40-50 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Poverty RAWS site measured wind gusts 45-51 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of strong, gusty offshore winds and dry humidity produced another round of Red Flag conditions across the North and East Bay Hills.  Strongest wind gusts were felt on Mt Diablo and near the Sonoma/Napa/Lake border of around 50 mph. A persistent upper ridge just off the west coast has made for periodic episodes of these gusty dry northerly winds throughout the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hawkeye RAWS station gusting between 45-50 mph during the evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of strong, gusty offshore winds and dry humidity produced another round of Red Flag conditions across the North and East Bay Hills.  Strongest wind gusts were felt on Mt Diablo and near the Sonoma/Napa/Lake border of around 50 mph. A persistent upper ridge just off the west coast has made for periodic episodes of these gusty dry northerly winds throughout the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hawkeye RAWS was gustying between 50-60 mph during this time frame with a peak gust of 73 mph. Gusty winds prompted power companies to proactively turn off power to prevent wildfires https://www.pgecurrents.com/2018/10/14/extreme-wind-forecast-pg-potentially-in-north-bay-later-tonight/.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surfer was rescued off of Pleasure Point on Wednesday afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A surfer was rescued from head-high waves off Pleasure Point https://www.santacruzsentinel.com/2018/10/25/surfer-rescued-from-head-high-waves-off-pleasure-point/?utm_campaign=socialflow&utm_medium=social&utm_content=tw-scsentinel&utm_source=twitter.com.

The thunderstorms produced moderate to heavy rainfall across portions of the San Joaquin Valley and Southern Sierra Nevada. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved into southern California on October 13 and moved slowly inland on October 14. While the precipitation with this system mainly stayed to the south of our area, it interacted with an upper ridge that was building into the Pacific Northwest  to produce a strong offshore gradient over central California which resulted in a brief period of strong mono-type northeast winds over the Southern Sierra Nevada during the late evening of October 14 and the early morning of October 15. Several dead trees were blown down near North Fork and Bass Lake in Madera County resulting in some brief road closures and some damage to a few structures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported several dead trees blown down 2 miles NW of Bass Lake.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported a tree fell into a house 3 miles SSE of Bass Lake. Numerous dead trees were reported downed in the area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported a tree downed and blocking road 222 near Bass Lake. Sustained winds of 43 mph with a peak gusts of 53 mph were reported at the nearby Cascedel Heights Weather Station around 2 hours earlier.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clear skies combined with a cool and very dry air mass to bring freezing temperatures to parts of northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported low temperatures ranged from 23 to 43 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clear skies and a very dry air mass allowed temperatures to drop below freezing over some northern California valleys.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 25 to 33 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dry upper trough pushed through California on October 29. This system brought a noticeable cooling trend to the area with diurnal temperatures lowering by several degrees   from the previous day and a period of strong winds along the west side of the San Joaquin Valley where there were several gusts between 30 and 40 mph and over the higher elevations of Kern County where a few locations had peak gusts around 50 mph. The wind slowly diminished on October 30 as the through moved to the east of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cache Creek reported a peak wind gust of 61 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Pacific low pressure system plus leftover moisture from the remnants of Hurricane Rosa produced thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert. Some storms produced flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Highway 127 was flooded with water, mud, and debris.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Highway 62 was flooded at mile marker 112.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although not as prevalent as the day before, patches of dense fog formed in the San Joaquin Valley toward daybreak. The fog impacted travel along State Route 99 between Turlock and Atwater and along State Route 198 between Visalia and Hanford. The fog also prompted several school districts in western Fresno County to delay morning bus service.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Hanford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper trough approached the California coast on November 28 spreading moisture into central California. A subtropical jet brought a deep moisture fetch into central California by the morning of November 28 producing moderate to heavy precipitation over  the area which continued into the afternoon. The rainfall resulted in debris flows and mudslides near recently burned areas in the southern Sierra foothills including over the Ferguson Burn area which resulted in the closure of State Highway 140 near El Portal. The trough moved inland on November 29 producing another round of moderate to heavy precipitation with several stations in the Southern Sierra Nevada and adjacent foothills measuring between 2 and 5 inches of rainfall while much of the San Joaquin Valley and Kern County Mountains received half and inch to an inch and a half of rain during the two day period. Snow levels lowered to 5500 feet on November 29, and several reports of a foot and a half to 3 feet of new snowfall estimated by SNOTELs. Strong winds also impacted the area on November 29 and several stations measured winds gusts exceeding 55 mph while a few low impact indicator sites measured gusts around 70 mph. As a colder, unstable post-frontal airmass pushed into the area during the afternoon of November 29, isolated thunderstorms moved through the San Joaquin Valley producing brief downpours, small hail and gusty winds. The precipitation tapered off by the early morning of November 30 as the trough moved out  of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California highway Patrol reported roadway flooding on southbound State Route 99 just north of Goshen.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper trough approached the California coast on November 28 spreading moisture into central California. A subtropical jet brought a deep moisture fetch into central California by the morning of November 28 producing moderate to heavy precipitation over  the area which continued into the afternoon. The rainfall resulted in debris flows and mudslides near recently burned areas in the southern Sierra foothills including over the Ferguson Burn area which resulted in the closure of State Highway 140 near El Portal. The trough moved inland on November 29 producing another round of moderate to heavy precipitation with several stations in the Southern Sierra Nevada and adjacent foothills measuring between 2 and 5 inches of rainfall while much of the San Joaquin Valley and Kern County Mountains received half and inch to an inch and a half of rain during the two day period. Snow levels lowered to 5500 feet on November 29, and several reports of a foot and a half to 3 feet of new snowfall estimated by SNOTELs. The rainfall resulted in debris flows and mudslides near recently burned areas in the southern Sierra foothills including over the Ferguson Burn area which resulted in the closure of State Highway 140 near El Portal. The trough moved inland on November 29 producing another round of moderate to heavy precipitation with several stations in the Southern Sierra Nevada and adjacent foothills measuring between 2 and 5 inches of rainfall while much of the San Joaquin Valley and Kern County Mountains received half and inch to an inch and a half of rain during the two day period. Snow levels lowered to 5500 feet on November 29, and several reports of a foot and a half to 3 feet of new snowfall estimated by SNOTELs. Strong winds also impacted the area on November 29 and several stations measured winds gusts exceeding 55 mph while a few low impact indicator sites measured gusts around 70 mph. As a colder, unstable post-frontal airmass pushed into the area during the afternoon of November 29, isolated thunderstorms moved through the San Joaquin Valley producing brief downpours, small hail and gusty winds. The precipitation tapered off by the early morning of November 30 as the trough moved out  of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Graveyard Meadow SNOTEL picked up an estimated 20 inches of new snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid/upper level low moved through the region at the end of November. A cool unstable air mass allowed for the development of scattered thunderstorms across the region that produced lightning and small hail. An associated surface low approached the coast during this time causing high surf and gusty winds. Some locations saw wave heights above 25 feet. This system caused roadway flooding, minor debris flows, and downed trees along with damage from gusty winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: BB sized hail reported at the NWS office.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime-sized hail reported on the San Francisco Peninsula https://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2018/11/29/potent-storm-brings-heavy-rain-pounding-surf-high-winds-and-flooding/.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wildfire smoke from the Camp Fire in northern California brought widespread unhealthy air quality to the Central Coast and the Bay Area through late November. A persistent upper ridge over the eastern Pacific kept conditions fairly stagnant with light offshore winds ushering in smoke to the area. It was not until an upper trough brought a fresh air mass and precipitation that conditions returned to normal on November 21st. The poor air quality resulted in multiple events across the region being canceled, delays at major airports, and numerous closures of schools as well as places of employment.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wildfire smoke prompts school closures in San Francisco https://abc7news.com/bay-area-schools-close-due-to-poor-air-quality-caused-by-smoke-from-camp-fire/4697038/.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought wind, snow, heavy rain, and some debris flows to Southern California from November 29th through 30th. Strong wind associated with the frontal boundary made its way through Southern California on the 29th, with heavy rain behind it. These rains resulted in numerous flash floods and debris flows, closing roadways and impacting traffic. A few inches of snow fell in the San Bernardino Mountains on November 30th. Fawnskin reported 3 inches, Green Valley Lake reported 4 inches, and Big Bear Resort reported 4-8 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Media reported highway 60 (Pomona Ave.) at Etiwanda Ave. was flooded due to heavy rain with accidents reported in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought wind, snow, heavy rain, and some debris flows to Southern California from November 29th through 30th. Fawnskin reported 3 inches, Green Valley Lake reported 4 inches, and Big Bear Resort reported 4-8 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The storm that brought a soaking rain to much of the area and the first significant snowfall of the season to the higher elevations of the Southern Sierra Nevada was followed by a second storm which reached central California on November 23 and brought widespread rainfall to the area which continued through the early morning of November 24. Although this storm did not produce as much precipitation as the previous system, it still produced another half inch to locally two inches of additional rainfall to the Southern Sierra Nevada and adjacent foothills, and up to foot of new snow fell above 8000 feet. Much of the San Joaquin Valley was rain shadowed, but several stations measures between one and two tenths of an inch of additional rainfall. Meanwhile, strong winds impacted the Kern County Mountains from the afternoon of November 23 through the early morning of November 24. Several stations reported wind gusts exceeding 40 mph while a few low impact indicator sites measured gusts around 60 mph. By the afternoon of November 24, decreased winds and drying took place across the area as the storm moved to the east of the area with high pressure building in behind it.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bird Springs Pass RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 61 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Skies cleared out over much of the San Joaquin Valley between during the evening of November 24 and the early morning hours of November 25 as high pressure build inland into central California. With recent rainfall and diminished winds fog formed toward daybreak over the San Joaquin Valley except for the far south end where upslope clouds persisted. Areas of dense fog with visibility between an eighth and a quarter mile were prevalent for a few hours in the morning across much of the valley between 700 am and 930 am. By 1000 am most of the fog had lifted into stratus and later burned off.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Fresno, Madera and Atwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As high pressure strengthened over the area on November 25, stronger radiational cooling took place on the morning for November 26 allowing for widespread dense fog to form in the San Joaquin Valley and prompted the first Dense Fog Advisory issuance of the season as travel on State Route 99 was adversely impacted by the fog. Fog reducing visibility from 1/16 to 1/8 of a mile was widespread by sunrise. The fog slowly burned off during the late morning hours and had completely dissipated by noon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Fresno, Madera, Merced and Atwater. A spotter reported visibility as low as 150 feet near Sanger.

A cool unstable air mass allowed for the development of scattered thunderstorms across the region that produced lightning and small hail. An associated surface low approached the coast during this time causing high surf and gusty winds. Some locations saw wave heights above 25 feet. This system caused roadway flooding, minor debris flows, and downed trees along with damage from gusty winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Los Gatos RAWS measured 50-54 mph gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An offshore wind event brought elevated fire concerns for the region in early November. One small fire broke out in Santa Cruz County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small 17 acre fire broke out that became known as the Rincon Fire off of Highway 9 north of Santa Cruz. One firefighter was injured https://www.ksbw.com/article/update-rincon-fire/24683131?utm_campaign=KSBW&utm_content=5be1f9ec04d30130ee666ef9&utm_medium=twitter&utm_source=trueAnthem:+New+Content.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wildfire smoke from the Camp Fire in northern California brought widespread unhealthy air quality to the Central Coast and the Bay Area through late November. A persistent upper ridge over the eastern Pacific kept conditions fairly stagnant with light offshore winds ushering in smoke to the area. It was not until an upper trough brought a fresh air mass and precipitation that conditions returned to normal on November 21st. The poor air quality resulted in multiple events across the region being canceled, delays at major airports, and numerous closures of schools as well as places of employment.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Unhealthy air quality from wildfire smoke prompted closures of all Santa Rosa city and Petaluma City schools https://abc7news.com/health/poor-air-quality-triggers-dozens-of-school-closures-in-bay-area/4653739/.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface high pressure centered over Idaho and Nevada brought strong offshore winds to Southern California from November 8th through 13th. The highest wind gust from the event was 85 mph at Sill Hill on November 12th. The air mass on November 8-10th was extremely dry with dewpoints observed at -25 to -40F between 6000 and 9000 feet (matched NKX sounding data). Fuel moisture measured by the USFS was at historical lows (100 and 1000 hour). Power was cut from many wildfire prone communities in anticipation of high winds. Some power lines were knocked over from the winds, but there were no significant fire starts. USFS reported several small wildfires during night hours but they were able to quick control the blazes before spreading.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sill Hill Mesonet reported a wind gust of 74 knots between 0800 and 0900 PST on November 12th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a significant dry period of 45 straight dry days across most of the central California interior. A low pressure system pushed inland over northern California on November 21 and brought a period of generally light to moderate precipitation to the area from the afternoon of November 21 through the morning of November 22 as an associated cold front pushed southward through central California. The precipitation fell mainly in the form of snow above 7000 feet resulting in this system being the first significant winter storm of the season for the higher elevations of the Southern Sierra Nevada where 8 to 16 inches of snow fell. Much of the San Joaquin Valley picked up between a quarter to three quarters of an inch of an inch of rainfall after going totally dry for a month and a half. There were several reports of nuisance flooding although damage was minimal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported four trees fell onto Road 222 near Road 426 south of Bass Lake, likely due to rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wildfire smoke from the Camp Fire in northern California brought widespread unhealthy air quality to the Central Coast and the Bay Area through late November. A persistent upper ridge over the eastern Pacific kept conditions fairly stagnant with light offshore winds ushering in smoke to the area. It was not until an upper trough brought a fresh air mass and precipitation that conditions returned to normal on November 21st. The poor air quality resulted in multiple events across the region being canceled, delays at major airports, and numerous closures of schools as well as places of employment.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Livermore ASOS reports 3/4 mile visibility. Wildfire smoke prompts closing of Lawrence Livermore Lab.

Monsoon thunderstorms developed across portions of eastern Riverside county during the afternoon hours on August 15th; some of the stronger storms generated gusty and damaging outflow winds that affected areas around the community of Desert Center. A trained spotter indicated that gusty winds estimated to be in excess of 70 mph downed a number of power poles and flipped 3 mobile trailers approximately 5 miles to the northeast of Desert Center and near the Desert Center airport. One of the trailers was completely destroyed. No injuries were reported as a result of the wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with strong and damaging outflow winds developed and moved across the community of Desert Center during the afternoon hours on August 15th. According to a trained weather spotter, at 1640PST outflow winds estimated to be as high as 75 mph downed 8 power lines and flipped over 3 mobile trailers. One of the trailers was completely demolished. The damage occurred about 5 miles to the northeast of the town of Desert Center and near the Desert Center airport. The damage was east of Highway 177 and north of Interstate 10. No injuries were reported due to the extensive damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoon thunderstorms with locally heavy rain developed over portions of Joshua Tree National Park during the middle of the afternoon on August 16th. The stronger storms generated intense rainfall that was sufficient to cause episodes of flash flooding within the park. Some of the most significant flash flooding occurred about 5 miles of Lost Horse and just south of the Riverside - San Bernardino county line. Park and forest service personnel reported flash flooding with water running 1 foot deep over Park Boulevard between Geology Tour Road and Sheep Pass Campground. There were numerous flows through various dirt roads resulting in washouts. Significant flooding also occurred near Skull Rock with water flowing over Park Boulevard. At 1530PST there was a public report of flash flooding about 8 miles north of the Cottonwood Visitors Center; flooding was occurring over Pinto Basin Road between mile markers 10 and 20. Flash Flood Warnings were issued as a result of the significant flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with locally heavy rain developed over portions of Joshua Tree National Park during the early to middle afternoon hours on August 16th. Some of the storms generated intense rain that led to episodes of flash flooding just south of the San Bernardino County line and  5 to 8 miles east of Lost Horse. According to a report from the public, at 1400PST significant flash flooding occurred near Skull Rock with water observed flowing across Park Boulevard. Shortly after that, at 1420PST, park and forest service personnel reported flash flooding as water 1 foot deep was flowing over Park Boulevard between Geology Tour Road and Sheep Pass campground. There were also numerous flows through all of the dirt roads leading to numerous washouts. Fortunately no accidents were reported as a result of the flash flooding. A Flash Flood Warning was issued for the area at 1254PST until 1600PST.

According to a report from the public, flash flooding was observed about 8 miles north of the Cottonwood Visitor's Center and along Pinto Basin Road. The flooding was between mile markers 10 and 20; most of the flows going across the road were spaced out between one and one and one half miles. The report indicated that the flooding occurred at about 1530PST. A Flash Flood Warning was issued for the area at 1504PST and was in effect through 1800MST.
