Tropical moisture spread north into Imperial County, ahead of Hurricane Rosa, on September 30th and the moisture led to the development of isolated thunderstorms. Some of the stronger storms produced gusty and damaging winds that impacted the areas around the Imperial Valley. During the late afternoon, one storm at the El Centro Naval Air Facility measured a wind gust to 59 mph. Strong wind just to the south and in the town of Seeley damaged a number of trees; large branches at least 4 inches in diameter were blown down onto area roads. A Severe Thunderstorm Warning was issued at the time of the wind damage. No injuries were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tropical moisture spread into Imperial County during the day on September 30th and as a result, isolated thunderstorms developed during the afternoon in the area around the Imperial Valley. Some of the stronger storms produced strong and gusty outflow winds. The official ASOS weather station at the El Centro Naval Air Facility measured a wind gust to 59 mph due to a thunderstorm moving through the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with locally heavy rain developed over the far eastern portions of Imperial County during the late evening hours on August 9th. Some of the storms generated rainfall rates in excess of one inch per hour which led to some flash flooding near the lower Colorado River Valley and over far northeast portions of the county. Shortly before midnight the California Highway Patrol reported flooding along Highway 78, about 12 miles to the southwest of Palo Verde and just to the west of the Cibola National Wildlife Refuge. No reports of accidents were received due to hazardous driving conditions on the highway and a Flash Flood Warning was not in effect at the time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with locally heavy rain developed over far northeast portions of Imperial County during the evening hours on August 9th. The storms produced peak rain rates in excess of one inch per hour which were sufficient to cause an episode of flash flooding. According to local law enforcement, at 2353PST the California Highway Patrol reported flooding along Highway 78, about 12 miles to the southwest of Palo Verde and west of the Cibola National Wildlife Refuge. No accidents were reported as a result of the hazardous driving conditions on the highway and a Flash Flood Warning was not in effect.

Deep tropical moisture started to spread north and into far southeast California during the day on September 30th; the moisture spread into the area ahead of Hurricane Rosa and led to the development of isolated thunderstorms. Due to the tropical nature of the moisture, the storms that developed produced very heavy rain which led to an episode of flash flooding in eastern Riverside County, to the southwest of Joshua Tree National Park and just north of the Salton Sea. At 1925PST, the California Highway Patrol indicated that Box Canyon Road was closed at Mecca Copia Trail due to flash flooding. The patrol indicated that there were significant flooding issues further downstream with major damage done to Box Canyon Road. It was also reported that a man was swept off of Box Canyon Road and to his death due to flash flooding of a large wash running across the road, between Interstate 10 and Highway 111.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain developed across portions of eastern Riverside County during the evening hours on September 30th. The stronger storms produced intense rain that led to flash flooding to the southwest of Joshua Tree National Park and to the north of the Salton Sea. At 1925PST (2025 PDT) the California Highway Patrol reported that Box Canyon Road was closed at the Mecca Copia Trail due to flash flooding. Significant impacts were reported to have occurred further downstream. Major damage was reportedly done to the Box Canyon Road forcing the road to be closed for days. It was also reported that a man was swept to his death driving along Box Canyon Road between Interstate 10 and Highway 111.  He was returning from a camping trip in Joshua Tree National Park. His damaged car was found by the road later the next day with no trace of the man to be found. A Flash Flood Warning was issued for the area at 1909MST and it remained in effect until 2215MST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with strong and gusty outflow winds developed along the lower Colorado River Valley and to the north of Yuma during the evening hours on July 9th. Some of the storms generated winds that were measured to be in excess of 70 mph. The strong winds did not produce any damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with gusty outflow winds developed along the lower Colorado River Valley during the evening hours on July 9th; some of the stronger storms were located just to the north of the town of Yuma and south of Castle Dome Landing. A mesonet automatic weather station measured a wind gust to 71 mph with one of the the strong storms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical moisture spread north into Imperial County, ahead of Hurricane Rosa, on September 30th and the moisture led to the development of isolated thunderstorms. Some of the stronger storms produced gusty and damaging winds that impacted the areas around the Imperial Valley. During the late afternoon, one storm at the El Centro Naval Air Facility measured a wind gust to 59 mph. Strong wind just to the south and in the town of Seeley damaged a number of trees; large branches at least 4 inches in diameter were blown down onto area roads. A Severe Thunderstorm Warning was issued at the time of the wind damage. No injuries were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tropical moisture spread north and into Imperial County during the day on September 30; the moisture moved in ahead of Hurricane Rosa and led to the development of isolated thunderstorms. Some of the stronger storms produced gusty and damaging outflow winds in the community of Seeley, to the west of the Imperial Valley. According to a trained weather spotter, at 1613PST outflow winds estimated to be as high as 60 mph damaged a number of trees in Seeley. The winds blew down several branches with diameters of at least 4 inches and some branches landed in the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level low pressure system moved into far southeast California during the early morning hours on October 13th and triggered the development of widespread showers and thunderstorms. Many of the stronger thunderstorms produced intense and very heavy rain that led to episodes of flash flooding across portions of eastern Riverside County.  Park and Forest Service personnel reported many paved roads in Joshua Tree National Park flooded and washed out starting shortly after midnight. Flash flooding was also observed just north of the Salton Sea, with roadway flooding near the Salton Sea State Recreation Area. In addition, local law enforcement reported flash flooding near Interstate 10 at about 0230 PST, about 10 miles east of Desert Center. Multiple Flash Flood Warnings were issued for the area during the early morning hours. Fortunately, no accidents or injuries were reported due to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vigorous upper level low pressure system moved into eastern Riverside County shortly after midnight and triggered the development of numerous showers with embedded thunderstorms. Some of the stronger storms generated very heavy rain, with peak rain rates in excess of 2 inches per hour. The intense rain led to flash flooding just north of the Salton Sea and near the Salton Sea State Recreation Area. According to local law enforcement, at 0005PST flash flooding was observed at State Route 111 and Bay Drive. No accidents were reported due to the flash flooding. A Flash Flood Warning was in effect at the time of the flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late evening thunderstorms developed over far eastern portions of Riverside County on August 9th and some of the stronger storms produced gusty outflow winds reaching as high as 60 mph that stirred up significant amounts of blowing dust leading to dust storm conditions. The dense blowing dust affected areas along the lower Colorado River Valley including the community of Blythe. The official ASOS automatic weather station at the Blythe airport recorded a wind gust to 60 mph and also measured visibility down to one quarter of a mile at 2323PST; a Dust Storm Warning had been issued earlier for the area but the warning expired at 2300PST. Despite severely restricted visibility and hazardous driving conditions, no reports of accidents were received.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with gusty outflow winds affected the far eastern portion of Riverside County during the late evening hours on August 9th, including the community of Blythe. Some of the stronger storms generated gusty outflow winds that stirred up areas of dense blowing dust resulting in dust storm conditions along Interstate 10. At 2326PST the official ASOS weather station at the Blythe Airport measured a visibility of one quarter mile in dense blowing dust. A Dust Storm warning had been issued earlier for the area but it expired at 2300PST.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with strong outflow winds developed over far eastern Riverside County during the late evening hours on August 9th and one of the stronger storms affected areas around the community of Blythe. At 2226PST the official ASOS weather station at the Blythe airport measured a wind gust of 60 mph.

Many of the stronger thunderstorms produced intense and very heavy rain that led to episodes of flash flooding across portions of eastern Riverside County.  Park and Forest Service personnel reported many paved roads in Joshua Tree National Park flooded and washed out starting shortly after midnight. EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level low pressure system moved east and into Joshua Tree National Park around Midnight on October 12 and triggered the development of widespread showers along with embedded thunderstorms. Some of the stronger storms generated intense rain with peak rain rates over 2 inches per hour. The heavy rain led to episodes of flash flooding across Joshua Tree National Park during the very early morning hours on October 13. According to the Park and Forest Service, at 0030PST flash flooding caused most of the paved roads, including Pinto Basin Road and Highway 62 near the town of Joshua Tree, to become closed. Pretty much all of the dirt roads around Joshua Tree National Park were also closed. Flash Flood Warnings were issued for the park due to the heavy rain and flooding. Fortunately there were no reports of accidents or injuries in the park due to the flash flooding.

The low triggered the development of numerous showers and embedded thunderstorms, and some of the stronger storms generated intense rain with peak rain rates in excess of 2 inches per hour. The heavy rain led to episodes of flash flooding, including one along Interstate 10. According to local law enforcement, at 0233PST flash flooding occurred on East Corn Springs  Road near Interstate 10. Fortunately there were no accidents or injuries due to the flooded road. A Flash Flood Warning was in effect at the time of the flooding.
